PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the President and senators in Parliament assembled, your humble petitioners showeth that the proposed Australia Card will have a dramatic impact on the lives of all Australians, and your petitioners therefore request a national referendum on the Australia Card Bill before the proposal is resubmitted to Parliament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Jones (from 329 citizens), Powell (from 225 citizens) and Puplick (from 52 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition from certain citizens of Western Australia respectfully showeth:

That in view of the number of expert witnesses and Government departments that have cast doubts on the cost, inadequate safeguards and purported benefits of the Health Department's claims for the proposed Australia Card and in view of the demonstrated inability of the bureaucracy in general, and the Health Department in particular, to protect the privacy of information entrusted to them and in view of the gross infringement of an individual's civil liberty that would be created by the proposed Card:

Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled will neither pass nor reject nor fail to pass the Australia Card Bill but rather refer the Bill to an open Senate inquiry that is held in public and that after all the facts have been considered a national referendum be held on the Australia Card Bill.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Identity Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
(1) That we are totally opposed to the introduction of the Labor Government's Identity Card.

(2) That this form of national and compulsory identification will be intrusive, costly for taxpayers and business and will not be effective in combating the growing problems of tax evasion, illegal immigrants or social security.

(3) That we are deeply concerned at the Labor Government's inability to provide effective and efficient methods to combat tax and social security fraud without resorting to expensive, ineffective and authoritarian measures which are alien to the Australian way of life.
(4) That we call upon the Labor Government to improve management systems within the Australian Taxation Office and other departments to crack down on tax evasion and fraudulent practices.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Chaney (from 12 citizens) and Messner (from 18 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Identity Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned citizens, respectfully showeth:
That we are totally opposed to the introduction of the Government's Identity Card;

That this form of national and compulsory identification will be intrusive, costly for taxpayers and business and will not be effective in combating the growing problems of tax evasion, illegal immigrants or social security;
That we call upon the Government to improve management systems within the Australian Tax Office and other Departments to crack down on tax evasion and fraudulent practices.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned Australian citizens shows that:
An ID Card numbering system for all Australians would give future governments tremendous power to collect sensitive information and use it against us.

Criminal elements could benefit by forging cards and documents needed to obtain them, or by illegally accessing the data in the system. The dangers are much greater than with current systems such as Medicare, as the Australia Card number could link so many different confidential records.
The cost to government and private enterprise of implementing the ID Card would be enormous, outweighing any gains. Tax cheats can be stopped more effectively by better checks in the present system.
Your petitioners therefore pray that you will reject the Australia Card Bill.
As in duty bound your petitioners will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Jones (from 30 citizens) and Messner (from 101 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that we strongly oppose the introduction of the Australia Card or any other form of National Identification Numbering System.

We believe that the introduction of a National Identification Numbering System is not only totally unnecessary but is a severe threat to our civil liberties and privacy. We condemn the Government's actions on this matter, particularly as no reasonable nor responsible justifications for the proposal have been forthcoming from the Government.
We humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should reject any proposal for a National Numbering System.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and the members of the Senate assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia sheweth that whereas:
1. The present Australian national flag is not distinctively and uniquely Australian and is confused with other national flags.
2. The people of Australia have never had an opportunity to express their views on an appropriate Australian national flag in a referendum.
3. The present Australian national flag does not properly represent Australia as a sovereign, independent nation.
4. The present Australian national flag incorrectly proclaims Australia as a colony, homeland, protectorate, dominion or government department of Great Britain.
5. The first condition in the flag competition of 1901 required that the design should show Australia's loyalty to the British Empire. The British Empire no longer exists.
6. A public opinion poll held in 1984 using the Gallup Method revealed that 52 per cent of Australians surveyed wanted a competition for a new design for the Australian flag.
7. There is no inherent link between Australia proclaiming a unique and distinctive flag and the political issue of Australia moving to a republican form of government.
8. The adoption of a truly Australian national flag would serve as a focal point for Australia's bicentennial celebrations in 1988.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will:
(a) Appoint a Committee of the Parliament with representatives from both Houses and all parties to invite and consider proposals for the design of a new Australian national flag, and

(b) Require that Committee to make recommendations on the form of a minimum cost referendum in which the electors will be given the opportunity to vote for a flag from a selection of at least three designs, one of which will be the present Australian national flag.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Coulter (from seven citizens), McLean (from 22 citizens), Powell (from 23 citizens) and Sanders (from 14 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Smoke Free Air Travel
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
We the undersigned,
(i) are greatly disturbed by the dangers to health posed by passive smoking, and evidence of which is being documented daily by medical authorities around the world;

(ii) note that environmental tobacco smoke has been identified as the major pollutant in aeroplane cabins, and that its direct threat to health is recognised in the special leave provisions for flight attendants specifically on grounds of upper respiratory infections;

(iii) appreciate the Government's undertaking to legislate for smoke-free travel on aeroplanes, but are dismayed at the apparent reluctance to follow up the Minister for Aviation's December announcement with action; and

(iv) call upon the government to make smoke-free aeroplane travel a reality without further delay, and to ensure that smoke-free areas which cannot be contaminated by recycled pollutants, are available at all aerodromes.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Human Embryo Experimentation Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

The petition of the undersigned expresses concern that some scientists in Australia are intent on undertaking destructive experimentation on human embryos. This subject was examined exhaustively by the 1985-1986 Select Committee on Senator Harradine's Human Embryo Experimentation Bill which received 270 submissions and more than 2,000 pages of evidence. The report of the Senate Committee recommended in October 1986 that the Commonwealth Government make unlawful any destructive experiment which frustrated the development of the human embryo.

Your petitioners therefore request the Senate and the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to implement without delay the major recommendation of the Senate Select Committee to outlaw destructive experiments on human embryos.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Watsonia Army Barracks, Victoria
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that:

1. The Watsonia Army Barracks contains a satellite communication dish, that sends to the United States the information, gathered by the ``joint high frequency stations'' in Australia and New Zealand, indicating the position of the Soviet naval ships and submarines. This information from Watsonia is combined with data from satellites and underwater sensors to calculate the location of the Soviet vessels with great accuracy.

2. This would make it possible for the US nuclear naval ships and submarines to destroy all nuclear Soviet naval ships and submarines, while the US nuclear submarines, naval ships and bombers launch their missiles in a ``first strike'' attack.
3. This makes Watsonia a potential nuclear target. A nuclear attack on Watsonia would have a disas- trous effect on Melbourne.
4. The ``joint US-Australia'' bases in Australia endanger rather than protect us. They also add a new menace to the nuclear arms race, that must be stopped.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should close the `joint Australian-US' electronic communication facility in the Watsonia Army Barracks.

PETITION.TITLE: Pine Gap Defence Space Research Facility
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. We, the undersigned, call on the Federal Government to give notice to terminate the lease of the US base at Pine Gap before October 1986.
We believe that in the interests of world peace and the Australian people, this lease should be terminated and the base closed because Pine Gap is a spy base and a war base:

Since it was opened in 1969, it has eavesdropped on Australian telephone and telex communications. Information obtained in this way was used by the CIA to destabilise the Whitlam Government in late 1975.

It provides communications facilities for CIA activity in countries throughout the world, much of which is connected with overthrowing other countries governments. Last year it became clear Pine Gap was spying on Greece.
The electronic and photographic information its satellites receive is used to select nuclear targets in the territory of the Soviet Union and its allies.
Many US military activities short of nuclear war are also co-ordinated by Pine Gap. These include the war against Vietnam and the invasion of Lebanon by US marines in 1984.
Pine Gap spends only a tiny percentage of its time monitoring arms control agreements, and even then the data gathered is so top-secret Australia has no access to it.
Pine Gap's role will be expanded under Reagan's Star Wars scheme to extend the arms race to outer space, threatening the existence of our planet.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate would be aware of continuing uncertainty in the stock market today with Australian shares having now lost about 40 per cent of their value since the beginning of last week. In this state of continuing great uncertainty, how can the Government justify closing off options which would give it greater flexibility to respond to rapidly changing circumstances? In particular, does the Minister agree that it would be absurd for the Government not to seek a further deferment of the national wage case hearing, at least until early next year, to give it time to make a proper assessment of the dramatic developments of the past two weeks on the Australian economy?

—As I said yesterday, the Government does not see any need for a mini-Budget at this stage. We have no plans to have one before the end of 1987. However, we reserve the option of an early economic statement in 1988. The question as to the implications of the events in the stock market for the national wage case will be the subject of extensive consideration by the Government and the Cabinet this afternoon, and I do not propose to make any further comment on that subject until then.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I note the Minister's answer and, given that the wage case decision, on which the present hearings will be based, requires no more than consideration in October of a possible across the board rise, does the Minister not agree that simple prudence requires postponement of any decision in circumstances of great uncertainty?
—I have nothing to add to my previous answer.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Can the Minister inform the Senate of the situation in French occupied Polynesia? Does the Government have any information to verify media reports that the strike called by Polynesian waterside workers affected the shipment of materials to Mururoa Atoll, which is the centre of French nuclear testing activities? In view of the Australian Government's strong public opposition to the French nuclear testing program in the South Pacific-the latest test occurred only last week-will the Australian Government express its appreciation of the Polynesian workers who have publicly demonstrated their opposition to the nuclear testing program? Whilst in no way condoning the reported violence, will the Government express to the French Government its concern that French Foreign Legion troops, and other military forces, were required to suppress the aspirations of a significant number of Polynesian people who support independence and the cessation of the nuclear testing program?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As to the developments in French Polynesia, we are of course aware of reports relating to the violence and disorder in the town of Papeete in French Polynesia on 23 October, including paramilitary police and gendarmes mobiles who were sent to the territory from New Caledonia. Two hundred Foreign Legion troops from Mururoa were flown to Tahiti, and a state of emergency has been declared on the islands of Tahiti and Moorea until further notice. A curfew has been imposed from 1900 to 0500 hours in the communes surrounding the port area in the main city, and is likely to remain for the next seven to 10 days. I am aware of the fact also that paramilitary police forces did break up a picket line set up by striking dock workers, following which the dock workers proceeded to rampage through the port and town, causing substantial damage and injury. French Ministers are reported as claiming that the situation is under control, and denying that there is any political importance to the riots. Our post in Noumea, which has responsibility for French Polynesia, is keeping us informed of developments. No tourist has been harmed in the various incidents which have taken place. The local authorities have made arrangements for tourists to move from the airport to hotels.

ANSWER.PARA: In relation to the most recent nuclear test in French Polynesia, I remind honourable senators that the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Mr Hayden, yesterday made a public statement strongly condemning French nuclear testing in the South Pacific, and called once again for international support for a comprehensive nuclear test ban. That followed the report that France had carried out another nuclear test at the Mururoa Atoll, the fifth this year. As to the particular matters about further possible representations to the French Government that Senator Schacht raises, I will refer those questions to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate. Having in mind the further very large falls overnight on Wall Street and London, and the further fall on the Australian stock exchange this morning, will the Government now accept that markets are looking to the Government for some signs of action to deal with the fundamental economic problems of the Australian economy, which have been exposed by the crash in our financial markets? Will Senator Evans agree that in these circumstances stoicism is one thing, but that the Government's present posture is more akin to that of the rabbit in front of the boa constrictor-frozen into immobility? In particular, why does the Government persist in closing off its option in regard to an early mini-Budget, to be brought down before the Parliament rises for the Christmas recess?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Intelligent stoicism is very much to be preferred to vulgar populist grandstanding of the kind that we have just heard from Senator Stone and from so many of his colleagues in recent days. The reality is that movements in share market prices in Australia are not reflections of any particular developments in the real Australian economy. Our economic policy settings are well and truly in place and have been in place for some time. The efficacy of them is demonstrated, among other things, by the consumer price index figures released today, which demonstrate that inflation is manifestly on course in terms of the budgetary targets that were set. Balance of payments improvement, continued growth in output and employment and reduction in inflation of the kind I have just mentioned are all crucial elements in maintaining the climate of economic confidence which this Government, contrary to its predecessors, has restored and developed.

ANSWER.PARA: Of course, the situation is one that demands constant and careful monitoring. Of course, the Government will do just that and make its response to emerging further developments as they occur. As I said yesterday, the whole climate of fiscal responsibility which this Government has stood for and put in place-most conspicuously with the last Budget, a balanced Budget-contrasts fairly dramatically with some of the much less effective, much less aggressive and much less energetic policy responses of other economies around the world. We stand to lose nothing by way of contrast of our performance with that of every other Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development country in recent times, and we will weather this internationally imposed storm-it is not a domestically imposed one-as best we can.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In the light of the answer given by the Minister, why, therefore, does he find himself in persistent disagreement with the views expressed this morning by the Chairman of the Australian Stock Exchange and by one of our most respected businessmen, Sir Arvi Parbo, both of whom are calling for an early mini-Budget?

—It would not be the first time that either I or the Government had disagreed with the economic nostrums and prescriptions of Sir Rode-rick Carnegie, Sir Arvi Parbo or any one of a dozen other industry figures who have particular axes to grind or particular views to put. We, of course, listen to their views. We take them seriously. The whole consultative process with the business community has been conducted with much greater efficacy and mutual confidence than was ever able to be managed by honourable senators opposite when they were in government-not least by Senator Stone when he was previously incarnated as Secretary to the Trea-sury. We have, I repeat, absolutely nothing to apologise for in our conduct of this country's macroeconomic policy, and I make no such apology.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to the Minister's answer yesterday to a question regarding the call by the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, for a mini-Budget and his offer to provide a detailed list of spending cuts. Has the Minister seen a transcript of an interview between the shadow Finance Minister, Senator Stone, and Mike Carlton on radio this morning? Will the Minister extend to Senator Stone the same invitation he made yesterday to Mr Howard to specify where the Opposition would propose making those spending cuts?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the transcript and the relevant section has Senator Stone saying that what is needed are `real cuts in the Commonwealth's own spending programs, not cuts in programs for State governments but cuts in the Commonwealth's own spending'. In relation to that, I point out that health and education are functions where some of the expenditure is direct expenditure by the Commonwealth and some of it is payments to the States. I am not sure precisely what Senator Stone had in mind, but in the functions of benefits to individuals, and excluding those paid under the health and education function, expenditure is $20.7 billion-that is, more than 25 per cent of Commonwealth outlays-public debt interest expenditure is $7.9 billion and defence expenditure is $7.4 billion. That totals $36 billion, which is almost one-half of the total Commonwealth Budget outlays in areas which are unquestion- ably the Commonwealth Government's own spending. When we add to that the cost of administration of the Commonwealth Government, we indeed have probably 80 per cent or more of what can be classified as the Commonwealth Government's own spending. Therefore, it follows that if there are to be very significant cuts in the Commonwealth's own spending programs, cuts will have to be made in the three big areas of defence, public debt interest and pensions.

ANSWER.PARA: I note, however, that the Opposition is still committed to a policy of increasing expenditure on pensions by abolishing the assets test. That measure will cost an extra $300m a year. I do not know whether Senator Stone proposes reducing the Commonwealth superannuation scheme pension or imposing an income test on that pension so that retired departmental secretaries who receive a pension of $33,000 or $34,000 a year and also a parliamentary salary will lose part or all of that Commonwealth superannuation scheme pension. I do not know whether he intends to cut family allowances or even the family assistance scheme which is due to start, I think, next month. Finally, I would certainly welcome Senator Stone's proposals for cuts in specific Commonwealth Government expenditure programs. In particular, I would welcome his clarifying whether he intends to cut the age pension, to cut or means test the Commonwealth superannuation scheme pension, to abolish the family allowance or not to proceed with the family assistance scheme.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for the Environment and the Arts: Is it a fact that logging is now taking place in areas on the interim list of the National Estate in the Eden region? Also, what measures is the Government taking now and what measures will it take in the future to protect the National Estate from the clear-felling practices associated with the Daishowa woodchip mill in Eden?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —No land presently on the National Estate Register is being logged in the Eden area and I am advised that all National Estate land in the Eden area is within national parks and no national parks are within State timber forests. So it would appear that the National Estate in the Eden area is not being logged at the moment. As far as the interim list to which Senator Sanders has referred is concerned, I am advised by the New South Wales Department of Forests that no logging has occurred on land on that list either. Rather, there are complaints from conservation groups which want land added to that list and some logging is going on in those areas but they have not yet been listed.

ANSWER.PARA: There are no plans for logging to begin in any area on the interim list until the current deliberations of the New South Wales Government are finished. I am assured that that decision will come down very shortly. That is worth mentioning because the final environmental impact statement on the Daishowa woodchip project was completed in December 1986. Following an examination of that statement it became obvious that it would not be possible for the Commonwealth to proceed in making a final recommendation prior to the State Government's decision which would indicate just how much of the resource is to be used. Therefore, in accordance with the procedures under the Act, agreement was sought with the company for the Commonwealth to delay making its final recommend- ations. The company has seen me in recent weeks and it suggested that that agreement has been stretched to the limit by the length of time it has taken. However, as I have said, I believe that the result of State investigations will be known to us all very shortly. Therefore, the environmental impact assessment can be completed and the final recommendations will be made to my colleague the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister for the Environment and the Arts been drawn to Press announcements concerning the Premier of Queensland's proposal to hand over an area of 8,000 hectares of the central Queensland coast, identified as the proposed Bayfield national park, to the Yeppoon tourist resort developer, Mr Iwasaki? What action will the Commonwealth Government take on this matter? Is there any possible conflict of interest for the Premier of Queensland with his proposal?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —My attention and I am sure everyone else's attention has been drawn to those Press reports. They suggest a possible handover of an 8,000-hectare area, identified as the proposed Bayfield national park, to Mr Yohachiro Iwasaki. The area involved is north of the Iwasaki international tourist development, which was the subject of an environmental impact assessment under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act in 1978. The Commonwealth's approval under the Government's foreign investment policy was announced by the then Treasurer, John Howard, on 30 July 1978. I want to quote a couple of paragraphs from that statement made by the former Treasurer. He said:

ANSWER.PARA: Any land to be acquired by the company was to be limited to the boundaries set out in the franchise agreement submitted to the Foreign Investment Review Board in April, 1978. Federal Government approval would need to be obtained before the company acquires, makes any arrangements, signs any contracts, or negotiates to acquire any additional land in any part of Australia.

So, Mr Howard was being very strict with Mr Iwasaki on that occasion. Since that time, on several occasions Mr Iwasaki has sought to grab some more land. The last occasion was in 1984. The additional land sought by Mr Iwasaki was allegedly to secure an assured water supply for the resort complex. The provisions of the Commonwealth environment protection Act which I administer would apply to such a proposal if a Commonwealth decision were required. However, at this stage no proposal has been put before us, and I await such a proposal with some interest.

In relation to the question of conflict of interest, I would be the last person to suggest that that would be possible. It is worth noting that the Premier's son-in-law, Mr Lester Folker, was made a director of the Iwasaki company in 1984, but the Premier of Queensland has said that there is no conflict of interest and, of course, I would accept that. However, this raises a number of other questions. While I may accept the Premier's words in relation to conflict of interest, that having his son-in-law on the board is not in any way influencing him to give away half of Queensland, I would say that there is a bit of a problem, though, on the question of hypocrisy.

In the past couple of months I have been subjected to an extraordinary campaign in north Queensland, part of it being that the Commonwealth Government was handing over the World Heritage listing area to foreign interests-that it was giving it all away. Colonel Gaddafi's name was mentioned as one of those who would benefit from World Heritage listing. Having said that, we now find that the Queensland Premier is prepared to hand over a vast tract of land to a Japanese company. The World Heritage listing hands over no control but, of course, what the Queensland Premier suggests would. However, given the number of people who are at the moment picking on the Queensland Premier, the number of people who have been trying to get rid of him, the trouble that he has had with his own party, and the extraordinary criticism of him by the Liberal Party, I would hate to join in that parade of picking on the Queensland Premier, and I shall say no more.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Special Minister of State to the speech that she made when launching the women's policy of the Australian Labor Party on 26 July this year in which she condemned the reintroduction of negative gearing proposed by the Liberal and National parties as a `rort for the rich which would be paid for by cuts in essential services to women'. I also refer the Minister to her media release of 16 October, just three months later, in which she said, `The decision to allow negative gearing will help housing investors and boost supply'. How does the Minister account for this startling reversal in her attitude to negative gearing?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am trying to recollect what I said at the launching of the women's policy in July. It was a very happy event, I recall that. I seem to recollect that when commenting on the effects of the Liberal Party's proposed tax policy I did draw attention to the effects that those proposals would have on services for the poor and for women. I recollect that I was referring to the whole gamut of tax proposals that the Liberals were trying to entice the Australian electorate with. For example, they were promising to knock off the fringe benefits tax and the capital gains tax provisions, and they were promising to remove the assets test and do a number of other things. I seem to recall that Mr Carlton and Mr Howard put forward a package of taxation measures. Of course, they were promising tax cuts and at the same time exhorting us to make huge cuts in services and programs. Certainly it is the case that in launching our women's policy I drew to the attention of Australian women the inconsistencies, and indeed the contradictions, between the promises of all of the rorts-the fringe benefits tax being removed and the capital gains free provisions and so forth being brought back-and at the same time the promise to reduce the deficit. So I do not think that any specific item was the particular object of my attention; rather, it was the general approach taken by John Howard, which my colleague the Minister for Finance has pointed to often enough in this place. On the one hand the Liberals were saying to the people in the Australian electorate, `You will have to pay virtually no taxes next year. You can have all your rorts back, but at the same time we will magically reduce the deficit and cut back services-but we will not tell you which ones'. Certainly the launching of that policy was extremely successful. The women of Australia showed a very intelligent appreciation of the contradictions in what the Liberals were putting forward and they voted significantly to ensure the election of the third Hawke Government.

ANSWER.PARA: I move on to negative gearing, about which I have had a number of questions in this place. I explained, I thought at illuminating length, to Senator Watson a couple of weeks ago that we changed the negative gearing provisions on the first occasion in the context of overall tax reform. That was done at a time when we had not yet implemented a capital gains tax and, 18 months later, after monitoring the effects of those very dramatic tax reforms that we had put in place, we decided that there was no longer a case for restricting negative gearing in the housing sector. We decided because of the many changes that had taken place in the housing sector since the tax reforms, and other reforms in the economy, that it was a time to allow investment in housing, in the private rental market, to operate on similar terms to investment in other areas of the economy. So we once again allowed negative gearing. But I remind the Senate that we are now doing that in the context of the Government getting significant revenues from the effect of the capital gains tax on properties and on real estate, and it is now reasonable to put investment housing on the same footing as investment in other areas of the economy. It is certainly the case, and this view is accepted by the real estate institutes and the various housing organisations, that there will be growth in the availability of private rental accommodation partly as a direct result and partly as an indirect result of the negative gearing decision.

In conclusion, the overall effects of the various tax reforms which the Hawke Government has put in place have meant for women voters and for Australians generally a much improved level of home ownership and a much improved capacity for people to get their first home, and of course for women voters a much improved package of assistance to women with young children.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Does the Minister deny that on 26 July she actually said, among other things, that the Liberals would introduce negative gearing, and went on to refer to it as a `rort for the rich . . . paid for by cuts in essential services to women'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have the Press release of that launch here in front of me now. It stated:

ANSWER.PARA: Launching Labor's policy for women in Melbourne, Senator Ryan said the consequences of the Opposition's plans for changes to the taxation and health systems-
Senator Michael Baume will remember the health systems-
would be devastating for women.
I was referring to the package. I said:
Howard's tax cuts are a grab bag of promises which will provide no net advantage to women . . . `The rorts for the rich would be paid for by cuts in essential services to women'.
That is absolutely right.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister to table the document from which she has been quoting, which is not the document that was referred to in the question.
—I am happy to table the document. I understand that it was helpfully provided to me by somebody on the other side of the chamber.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. In view of the recent need for extra flights for tourists wishing to return to Australia, and anticipated heavy demand for flights in 1988, can the Minister advise what action Qantas Airways Ltd is taking to deal with this dramatic growth in demand for air travel to Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to be able to advise the Senate that Qantas Airways Ltd has today announced additional international flights in response to the increase in demand for air travel to Australia. Qantas will operate an additional 34 flights over the coming summer months. This is in addition to the 43 supplementary services which I referred to in the Senate just a week ago, on 21 October. Taken together with some 60 additional New Zealand services previously planned and announced, this will bring the number of additional Qantas services to 137 over the peak period. This will provide an extra 51,000 seats in each direction. Destinations served by the supplementary flights will be Tokyo, Hong Kong, Athens, Los Angeles, Singapore, Harare, Tahiti, Kuala Lumpur and Manila. I would add that Qantas said today that further capacity on top of all that would be provided should there be a good response to the present program of additional supplementary flights.

ANSWER.PARA: In addition, officials of my Department, Qantas and Tourism Australia are now consulting closely to monitor whether further additional capacity is required in the short and medium term. The Government is, of course, also ready to give prompt consideration to proposals for supplementary services from the 34 foreign airlines flying to Australia. I have no doubt that in those circumstances, and in view of the response Qantas is showing to the present difficult situation with the boom in international air travel, most of the difficulties which have been the subject of recent Press and public attention will not persist.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AFFIRMATIVE ACTION AND EQUAL EMPLOYMENT OPPORTUNITY

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women. Does the Affirmative Action Agency, which polices the private sector and tertiary education institutions, have a staff of 24? What is the staffing level in the remnants of the equal employment opportunity (EEO) unit that was in the Public Service Board and is now in the Public Service Commission? Is it a fact that the number of staff in the important equal employment opportunity unit has been slashed to nine? In view of the imbalance, does the Minister consider that staff in the Public Service and its authorities are in less need of equal employment opportunity than are those in the private sector?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must begin by correcting a couple of errors in the way in which Senator Newman framed her question. The Affirmative Action Agency does not police the implementation of the Affirmative Action Act. It monitors and advises corporations that employ more than 100 staff and higher education institutions and assists them in their preparation of their affirmative action plans, and of course will receive annual reports from them. Also, the coverage of the education field, which is the responsibility of affirmative action, is not tertiary education, which includes technical and further education; it is higher education, which includes universities and colleges of advanced education (CAEs). I am not entirely sure whether 24 is the precise number of staff in the Affirmative Action Agency, but it sounds right to me. I would take this opportunity to say that, although it is a relatively small staff, members seem to be doing an extremely good job and have harmonious relationships with the private sector. I have heard many unsolicited comments in favour of the work of the Affirmative Action Agency and Val Pratt and her team as I have spoken to chief executives. With regard to higher education, there are the 19 universities and 46 CAEs which they are assisting to develop and report on their affirmative action plans.

ANSWER.PARA: The equal employment opportunity unit in the Commonwealth Public Service is now placed within the Public Service Commission. The number of staff specifically allocated to this unit is nine. The reason why there has been a change in the structure and the size of that unit is that legislation covering the Commonwealth Public Service generally has now been in place for over two years and the EEO plans of Commonwealth departments are very well developed. The employment policies which are to take account of various groups, not just women but also Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders, disabled persons and people of non-English speaking backgrounds, are well in place. The need for constant advice, monitoring and assistance from a central agency is, of course, not as great as it was when the legislation was first passed. It is also the case that each department and Commonwealth agency is now required to take upon itself more of the EEO aspects of recruitment, training, promotion and so forth, so the implementation of the EEO requirements is now decentralised throughout the Commonwealth Public Service rather than centralised within a particular agency. It is nonetheless the case that there will be a central overall monitoring of EEO within the Commonwealth Public Service and the unit of nine people within the Commonwealth Public Service Commission is very well placed to do that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations aware of repeated calls from right wing ideologues for an ending to penalty rates for evening and weekend work in the hospitality industries? Do such calls reflect the widespread views of employers in those industries? Is there a logical economic rationale for those penalty rates?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to the last part of the question, I think that any sensible disciple of the free market would concede that there is an economic rationale for penalty rates. Indeed, such people should assume that in a perfectly free market a higher pay rate per hour would be needed to attract the labour required to work at inconvenient times, such as night shifts and weekends. Indeed, that is clearly recognised in a report in the Australian of 3 August this year which quotes a Mr Brian Burch, who is the resident manager of the Intercontinental Hotel in Sydney. The Australian reported Mr Burch as saying that, although penalty rates made life difficult for the hotelier, abolishing them would not be the solution. Mr Burch was quoted as saying:

ANSWER.PARA: We are already finding it hard to get staff on weekends and if penalty rates were abolished it would be even harder to get anyone.

Mr Burch, from his actual experience, is confirming what any rational person who understands the free market theory would have expected in the first place. Probably more importantly, I am not sure that any proper quantitative assessment has been done but I understand that the great bulk of people who are employed in the hospitality industry during weekends and probably on night shifts are casual employees anyway and therefore not likely to be greatly affected by the overtime rates or even penalty rate provisions.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. I refer to the recent announcement of a Government plan to investigate the way women are portrayed in the media, particularly in advertising. Will the Minister consider funding research into how the portrayal of men in the media, advertising and literature can demean the status of women-for example, by portraying a womaniser in a positive light? Will the Minister approach the Prime Minister and ask for his advice on the steps which need to be taken to change attitudes towards the respect for or exploitation of women in the light of Blanche D'Alpuget's authoritative biography of the Prime Minister? That biography records the following:

QUESTION.PARA: There was much that was known about Hawke-his drunken bad temper, his womanising, including outrageous public propositioning of women when he was drunk.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps I should explain to Senator Walters why it is that the Government, through the Office of the Status of Women, has decided to investigate the way in which women are portrayed in advertising. The reason why we have taken this step-it is an investigative step; we are not making any assumptions about what we will discover-is that, when I was conducting consultations with women all over Australia, and Senator Walters will be very well aware of them, to see what expectations and aspirations they had for themselves and their families from now until the year 2000, I constantly received complaints from women about some advertisements in the media, not all, and about the portrayal of women or women's sexuality in some advertisements. I was surprised that there was such a broad-based expression of resentment. It came from country women, from women of different ethnic backgrounds and from older women. It certainly was not a complaint that came from only one section of women or just from feminists.

ANSWER.PARA: There was a feeling of unease about two areas: the gratuitous use of women's sexuality in some forms of advertising and the caricaturing of housewives as being very silly people who were absorbed with trivial concerns and so forth. Because there was a substantial body of complaint about this I have asked the Office of the Status of Women to do a research project in which there will be some monitoring of media advertisements to see what basis there is in fact for the concerns that women have expressed. If there proves to be a basis in fact, if there proves to be a part of advertising which confirms the kinds of complaints that women have made, my intention then is to have a discussion with the advertising industry to see whether we can agree to discard that sort of advertising and to proceed to other sorts of advertising. Obviously, there are many advertisements which are effective and which do not affect women. I do not think that the problem, to the extent that it is shown to be a problem, will be difficult to solve. I am sure that the advertising industry wants to advertise in a way which is effective and which does not offend or put off the intended consumers and that we should have a happy and constructive outcome.

As to the other part of Senator Walters's question, I have not received consistent complaints about the portrayal of different kinds of men and the different behaviour of males. I do not think Senator Walters's reference to the official biography of Bob Hawke is to the point, so I will not comment on it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister for Home Affairs been drawn to the comments of Mr Don Cameron in the other place last night in which he attacked the integrity of the commissioners of the Australian Electoral Commission? Can the Minister assure the Senate that these commissioners are absolutely impartial? What substance is there in Mr Cameron's claim that the 1984 Federal redistribution was biased in favour of the Australian Labor Party? Is this the same Mr Cameron who made wild allegations about the fairness of the 1977 Federal redistribution?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —My attention has been drawn to the comments made by Mr Cameron last night. In his rather erratic speech he made several wild accusations that have no substance in fact. His first allegation relates to the integrity of the commissioners. He implied that they were stooges of the Labor Party. It might be instructive to go through the methodology of how those commissioners are appointed. Firstly, legislation requires that the chief of the Electoral Commission will be a Federal Court of Australia judge. The procedure for choosing that individual is that the Chief Judge of the Federal Court supplies a short list of names to the government of the day. The government then chooses one of, usually, three names supplied by the Chief Judge of the Federal Court of Australia. So the government would have very little discretion if it wanted to politicise the Electoral Commission by picking one of its favourite judges. The two judges who have so far served on the Electoral Commission, Mr Justice St John and Mr Justice Morling, are both people of the highest integrity and the choice of them at the time was not criticised by anyone opposite in politics.

ANSWER.PARA: The second person who serves on the Electoral Commission is the Chief Statistician. Again, we have had two of those serve over the last four years, Roy Cameron and Ian Castles, both of whom probably served their substantive careers and gained their promotions under Liberal governments. Again, there has been no criticism of their integrity. The third member of the Commission is the Chief Electoral Officer, Professor Colin Hughes. At the time of his appointment in 1984 all political parties affirmed their belief that he was a fair and impartial person, well qualified in his knowledge of Australian electoral law and well suited to serve on the Commission. I reject absolutely any accusation that those individuals have not approached their task with absolute impartiality.

The second point of Mr Cameron's accusations is that the Queensland redistribution of 1984 was in some way biased against the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia. I well remember that when those proposals came out the Queensland details were one of the last sets to come out. Western Australia's were already out and the Liberals were crying foul because on balance, when one added up the figures, they were slightly disadvantaged. But, in the case of Queensland, at that stage in 1984 the Australian Labor Party held 10 of the 19 seats. The Parliament was expanded to 24 and on 1983 figures Labor would have held nine seats out of 24, so on the same figures under which we achieved 10 out of 19, we went to nine out of 24. What was the reaction of the Liberal and National parties then? They were dancing in the streets with joy. The State Director of the Liberal Party was publicly quoted as saying what a magnificent redistribution it was. The wheel always turns in these things. In the 1987 election a small swing to Labor saw it pick up four seats; and now the whinges come. The reality of our picking up four seats in Queensland is that we worked those four seats with particularly brilliant candidates and particularly astute campaigns. The Liberals and the Nationals lost four seats in Queensland, the new jewel in the crown of the coalition of conservatives, and they are now in a minority.

A further inaccuracy from Mr Cameron was that he now says that the Labor Party has 58 per cent of the Federal seats in Queensland. A very quick calculation with one's calculator will tell one that we have 54 per cent of the seats. It appears to me that Mr Cameron's only experience with figures is related to girls jumping out of birthday cakes. He is not too good with a calculator.

As to the last part of the question, I must acknowledge one thing: Mr Cameron is a great survivor, but he is also the greatest whinger I have seen in Federal politics. He made similar wild allegations about the 1977 redistribution. He made allegations in 1977 that the boundaries were fixed and that the fix was put in by his own colleagues. We know how much loyalty there is in the Liberal Party. At the time I almost believed Mr Cameron that his Party may have tried to dud him in that way. Through those accusations, he forced the appointment of a royal commission by the Fraser Government. His accusations were rejected by the royal commissioner and the charge against Mr Eric Robinson was thrown out. The commissioner at the time said that he had no reason to believe that Mr Cameron's views should be given any more weight than the views of those against him. Of course, as a side show to that, Senator Withers, who has recently departed from this chamber, was politically assassinated as a result of that inquiry. So what happened through those wild allegations targeted at Mr Robinson was that they hit someone else.

TALK.START.PARA: —Quite unfair.

—Senator Peter Baume says that Senator Withers was unfairly treated. I have said so on several occasions in this chamber. He was hanged for a very minor offence. Let me say two other things. Mr Cameron's late conversion to electoral reformism is amazing. During the 15 years that the Liberal Party was in coalition with the Bjelke-Petersen National Party Government, I do not recall Mr Cameron criticising the redistributions or the electoral boundaries in Queensland. He was typical of that attitude of the Queensland Liberal Party which was wimpish, which was craven and which failed to stand up and say, `We need fair electoral boundaries in Queensland'. The Liberal Party now in Queensland whinges, but for 15 years it slept in the same bed as the electoral rorters of the National Party. I have a rough idea what is motivating Mr Cameron's attack on the Electoral Commission. We have had lots of problems in trying to locate a divisional returning office in his electorate. Over the last few weeks he has made a variety of hints that, if we do not relocate a divisional returning office in his electorate, he will seek to get even. I do not mind his seeking to get even in a public and direct way, but to impugn the integrity of the electoral commissioners in the 1984 redistribution is a fairly pathetic way to go.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister Assisting the Minister for Community Services and Health to her answer to Senator Harradine's question last week relating to the question of medical practitioners agreeing to terminate pregnancies on the basis that the parents want a child of a sex other than that of the existing foetus, and to her response indicating that she had no information on this matter and would refer the question of Medicare payments to the Minister for Community Services and Health. I further refer the Minister to her Press release of 29 July 1987 where she said:

QUESTION.PARA: I will be taking the lead in policy development in this area.

That is, in the bioethics area. As the Minister has indicated that she is taking the policy development lead in this area, why is she referring the matter to Dr Blewett, and can she now answer the question?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter referred to in Senator Harradine's question is a matter of medical practice already in place; it is not a new thing. If what was reported in the Press is actually happening-I express my shock and horror that women would make a decision on those grounds-it is a matter of State law that regulates access to abortion and it is a matter of Commonwealth payments for Medicare. What I have referred to Dr Blewett is the question of what Senator Harradine was interested in; that is, whether the procedures were covered by Medicare payments. I presume that they are, but I do not know, and I have referred that matter to Dr Blewett.

ANSWER.PARA: A new responsibility for me is the development of a Commonwealth position covering the area of bioethics. It is in response to the inquiry of the Senate Select Committee on Human Embryo Experimentation into reproduction technology and the various recommendations that are made there. We are now at the stage of looking at the way in which the Commonwealth can usefully develop a position in the field of bioethics, probably by way of accepting the Senate Committee's recommendation to have an expert advisory body to which medical matters that raise complex ethical issues could be referred. Again it is not an area where the Commonwealth would be anticipating legislating; it is an area where the States could legislate. Victoria has already legislated but has recently amended its legislation. I understand that South Australia intends to legislate quite soon and I will be having discussions with the South Australian Government later this week about that.

But at this stage the Commonwealth is seeking to play a useful role in the consideration of ethical issues that arise, and arise with a very complex character, as a result of new medical technologies that are available. Certainly, research reported in the Press gave rise to Senator Harradine's concern that women are able to use the results of amniocentesis tests and, as a result of those tests, they find out the sex of the baby and may then decide not to proceed with the pregnancy. They are in the position of being able to make that choice because of a new technology, although it is not such a new technology; it is not one of the very new technologies that were of particular concern to the Senate Committee. But it certainly raises ethical issues and it may be the sort of issue that a Commonwealth advisory body could develop a position on to advise the States. But legislation in this area is a State matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate Committee said there should be legislation in the Commonwealth sphere.
—The Commonwealth is considering that at this stage. We are not contemplating legislation but rather the setting up of an expert advisory body which could assist on matters.
—That would not be in accordance with the Senate Committee's recommendations.

—As I said, the Commonwealth is considering that Committee report. One of its recommendations was an advisory council and that is the one we are giving particular consideration to at the moment. If there were such a body, the ethical issue that arises from this particular reported use of the information gained from amniocentesis would be a kind of issue that could be referred to it. At this stage I think the response I made to Senator Harradine is the appropriate response: insofar as Medicare payments are available for the procedures, that is a Commonwealth matter-and I have referred that to Dr Blewett. Insofar as there may be legislation for the State of New South Wales to respond to this matter, that is a matter that I understand the New South Wales Government is looking into.

—Has the Minister representing the Minister for Defence read the directive dated 8 May 1984 from Admiral William Crowe, former United States Navy Commander-in-Chief in the Pacific, which ordered Pacific commanders to remove evidence in case of a nuclear weapons accident abroad involving United States warships and to treat such accidents as those involving conventional explosives? Further, is the Minister aware of the fact that the nations mentioned included Australia, along with seven other Pacific states, and that the document says that the United States has a representative in Australia responsible for dealing with nuclear weapons accidents here? Can the Minister say what the Government proposes to do in the event of a nuclear weapons accident in an Australian port, in light of this report? Have United States naval commanders been ordered to cover up the real nature of such an accident? Can the Minister also say whether the United States Government does have such a representative in Australia responsible for dealing with nuclear weapons accidents in this country?

—I have not read the instruction, but I understand that it provides broad policy and administrative guidelines for the US Pacific command activities on nuclear weapons safety. The instruction makes no specific reference to Australia, other than to include CINCPAC-Commander-in-Chief, Pacific-representatives in Canberra in a list of CINCPAC representatives and area commanders with responsibilities in the Indian Ocean and Pacific region. The instruction makes it clear that the host government would be informed of any nuclear weapons emergency. The Australian Government, in accordance with its sovereign responsibility, would take full charge of the management of any accident on Australian territory. For reasons which the Government has stated on many occasions, the Government considers that a nuclear weapons accident in any Australian port is extremely unlikely.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Why should the Australian Government be satisfied with United States assurances on this or any other matter, when its stated policy is to deliberately deceive its allies? That is its stated policy in this document that I have referred to.
—I think the assumptions on which the question are based are not accurate, and I have no further comment.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Is the Minister aware of an article in the October edition of the Pacific Islands Monthly entitled `Fiji at Flashpoint'? In view of the allegations made in that article by the deposed Deputy Speaker of the Fijian House of Representatives that the men who arrested him and his colleagues were not Fijian, and other allegations of police and military brutalisation, predominantly against members of the Indian community in Fiji, can the Minister inform the Senate whether the Government has any information on these series of allegations? What action does the Government propose to take with regard to them?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There have been reports of a number of actions taken against Fiji Indians by the military forces in that country in particular. We are aware that a growing number of civil servants, both senior Fiji Indian and others, have been summarily dismissed, and the dismissals or enforced resignations are becoming more common at lower levels. We are also aware of persistent reports that some Fiji Indians in particular are subjected to harassment by Taukei youths and petty criminals, apparently again in some cases with the connivance of elements of the military. Short term detentions continue of former coalition supporters, trade unionists and other citizens who may have connections to identified opponents of the regime. The ban on activity on Sunday, other than attendance at church, discriminates against the very large numbers of non-Christian Fiji citizens. Colonel Rabuka has announced on a number of occasions that the political and civil rights of Fiji Indians will be protected and that Fiji Indians are welcome to remain in Fiji. We simply hope that these assurances will be heard and acted upon.

ANSWER.PARA: Australia is concerned about infringements of international human rights standards, wherever they may occur. We are particularly concerned that there may have been violations in Fiji of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. The Government has repeatedly made clear-both directly and, of course, most recently at the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting through the Prime Minister-that the best interests of the people of Fiji will be served by as rapid a return as possible to the parliamentary processes.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. I refer the Minister to the Government's Register of Women which is maintained by the Office of the Status of Women. Can the Minister inform the Senate of the purpose of the Register of Women, and does the Government plan to extend the use of the Register so as to enable women to obtain better access to employment and business opportunities?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Register of Women, held by the Office of the Status of Women, is one project about which I am happy to say there is bipartisan support. In fact, the Register first started being built up in the period of the Fraser Administration. Its purpose is to provide a readily available list of women-and their qualifications-who are prepared to serve on government boards, statutory authorities, commissions and the like. It has been the policy of our Government to seek, wherever possible, to have up to 50 per cent of appointments to such boards and authorities filled by women. But in many areas it has not been possible to get anywhere near to the 50 per cent because of an inadequacy of information about competent and experienced women in the community who are willing to accept such appointments. During 1986-87, the computer system used for the Register was enhanced and a new registration form was introduced. At the end of June 1987, records were held for over 1,600 women, and updating of details has been sought. In August of 1987, about 170 women occupied 15 per cent of available appointments to statutory positions and authorities endorsed by Cabinet and the Executive Council. In 1987-88, emphasis will be placed both on increasing the number of potential appointees on the Register and on increasing the use made of the Register's current information.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government welcomes nominations. In fact, we are particularly seeking nominations from women with a business background, from women from ethnic minority groups and from Aboriginal and Islander women, because they are the groups which are under-represented on the Register. But women with any background relevant to a government appointment are invited to fill out a form and make their details known to the Register. I point out, in the light of recent debates we have had in this place and for the benefit of potential registrants, that the information made available to government will not be divulged to persons outside of the public sector without the consent of those persons. I hope, as I said, that there will be some bipartisan action on this matter and that names of appropriate women will come forth from all members of this chamber and from the women's organisations with which members of this chamber have active relations.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. Following the answer she has just given to Senator Crowley, I refer the Minister to the statement announcing the appointment of the new Austrade board, which followed the Government's announcement that it was giving increased emphasis to the appointment of women on boards. Why are there no women on the Austrade board? Was the Minister or the Office of the Status of Women consulted? Is it the view of the Government that no suitable women are available?

—It is not the practice of Ministers to consult me on this matter. But Ministers have been reminded that the Register of Women is available for them to consult. It is disappointing if names of women suitable for appointment to the Austrade board were not forthcoming or if the women whose names were forwarded were not regarded by the Minister responsible as being appropriately qualified. But I think that the honourable senator has pointed to what is, happily, these days a rare example of a body without female appointees. I will certainly refer the matter to the Minister responsible, and I reiterate the remarks I made in my answer to Senator Crowley that the Register is rather light on with details of women with business or trade backgrounds. If the honourable senator who asked the question had in mind women who are appropriately qualified, he might ensure that they get on the Register. Senator Button can then make a more balanced selection of Austrade commissioners on the next occasion.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a supplementary response to a question Senator Bishop asked last Friday. As it runs to 2 1/2 pages, I seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows-

Last Friday, Senator Bishop asked a number of questions about Defence force resignations. I dealt with the matter of pilot losses and undertook to obtain answers from the Minister for Defence on the other questions about Defence Force retirement entitlements and standards of housing for Defence Force personnel. I am pleased now to be able to provide answers on these matters.

Senator Bishop asked whether the Minister for Defence is aware that resignations of Defence Force personnel with 20 years service are in many cases due to fears that superannuation entitlements will be reduced. The Senator also asked whether the Minister for Defence is aware that rumours about superannuation entitlements are generally rife among Service men and women at Budget time and whether steps could be taken to allay such fears and to prevent such resignations.

There is no evidence to support the Senator's contention that fear of perceived changes in Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits (DFRDB) Scheme entitlements is a key factor in decisions by Defence Force personnel to resign after 20 years service.

Defence Force personnel have access to authoritative sources of information and I believe the great majority of members would be careful to seek proper advice before making decisions which affect their future.
The Minister is aware that rumours concerning change to the Scheme arise from time to time, more particularly in the lead up to budgets.

The Government has clearly demonstrated its support for the DFRDB Scheme in its White Paper on Defence which states that in the light of the overall trend supported by the Government to improve and extend occupational superannuation throughout the community, the Government has no intention of reducing the basic Scheme entitlements.
The Government's statement in the White Paper should put to rest the unfounded speculation to which the Senator has referred.

On the matter of Defence housing Senator Bishop asked whether the Government is aware that some of the stock is below standard; whether some new houses are being built without ensuites; and whether some standard project homes for Defence Force personnel are having ensuites removed from their design.

The Government is aware of the serious shortcomings in the quality of such of the Defence housing stock. Since 1983 the Government has taken positive action to overcome the deficiencies which have existed for many years and has initiated and funded programs to substantially improve the stock. Clearly an ongoing and significant investment in Defence housing is necessary to achieve a lasting improvement in the situation and the Government has made a commitment to an expanded capital funding program of around $750m over this decade.

As well as increasing the financial allocation the Government has introduced legislation to create a Defence Housing Authority to manage the stock and streamline arrangements for the construction, upgrading and maintenance and to enable quicker disposal of unsuitable dwellings. Subject to the passage of the legislation it is planned that the Authority will commence operation this financial year.

Defence Housing Scales and Standards provide for a range of housing aligned to the rank structure of the Services. This range is intended to mirror community norms and expectations with the size and amenity of housing varying according to the status of the prospective tenant and the rent to be charged. Defence personnel of the rank of Major and above are entitled to ensuites. Unfortunately, many do not have them but we are progressively improving the situation. It is also a fact that some new houses do not have ensuites. These houses are for personnel below Major rank.

The Minister for Defence knows of no cases where standard project house plans have been modified by deletion of an ensuite facility with resultant higher house costs incurred by the Commonwealth. I would be pleased to pursue that subject with the Minister for Defence should Senator Bishop require any further information.
