FISHING INDUSTRY RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT BILL 1987 [No. 2]
This Bill gives effect to the Government's rural industries research policy insofar as the research and development requirements of the fishing industry are concerned.

The Bill replaces, but does not repeal, the Fishing Industry Research Act 1969 which has since its commencement provided a total of $28,540,000 to support research for the benefit of the Australian fishing industry.

The Fishing Industry Research Trust Account established by that Act has supported scientific and biological research in many Australian fisheries. It has provided funds for exploratory fishing projects, fishing gear technology studies, education for fishermen and research into the handling and marketing of fish products. CSIRO, universities, government agencies, fishing companies and individual fishermen have received funding from the Account to undertake research.

The account has funded a wide range of industry-related projects, for example, experimental longlining for tuna as the basis of Australia's entry into the lucrative Japanese sashimi market, squid jigging off Tasmania and development of a marketing database on the Viatel system which is attracting interest from exporters, Japanese importers and fishermen's co-operatives.
Full details of the operations of the Fishing Industry Research Act are set out in the annual reports of the Fishing Industry Research Committee.

The Australian fishing industry has, in my view, received important benefits from the operation of the Fishing Industry Research Act that have contributed over time to the welfare of the industry and its place in the national economy. The Bill provides a basis for this to continue under more modern and representative administrative arrangements consistent with the modern legislative framework for rural industries research generally.

The Bill makes two fundamental changes to the basis of determining the amount that the Commonwealth will match by way of appropriation to the Fisheries Research and Development Trust Fund that the Bill establishes.

The Commonwealth will match expenditure from approved State funds rather than revenue collected from industry and credited to those funds. And there will be a ceiling to the Commonwealth appropriation to the Trust Fund, equal in any financial year to 1 per cent of the average annual gross value of production by the catching and culturing sectors of the Australian fishing industry during the three preceding financial years, as determined by the Minister.

The mechanism for determining the amount of the appropriation will remain much the same as under the existing legislation. That is, the Minister will determine one fund under each State's fisheries law to be an approved fund and specified money in that fund to be approved money.

The Bill requires all those determinations to be tabled in Parliament and provides for their disallowance as if they were regulations. Before making any determination under part III of the Bill in relation to the trust fund, the Minister will have regard to the legislative and administrative basis of State funds and the moneys credited to those funds.

The Bill establishes administrative machinery closely resembling that provided by the Rural Industries Research Act. There is to be a Fishing Industry Research and Development Council, which will prepare 5-year plans of fisheries research and development and annual programs for giving effect to that plan, for approval by the Minister.
The Council will undertake the decision-making and administrative functions associated with the trust fund, employing staff in classifications approved by the Minister for that purpose.

The members of the Council appointed by the Minister will comprise an independent chairperson, a government member experienced in formulation of government policy and public administration, and not fewer than three or more than seven members with experience and knowledge of the fishing industry and fisheries research and a high order of general administrative and managerial ability.

The Bill provides for the Minister to appoint members of a Fishing Industry Research and Development Council Selection Committee, comprising an independent chairperson, a member with experience in fisheries administration or management, a member experienced in fisheries research and development, a member nominated by the Australian Fisheries Council and three members nominated by the National Fishing Industry Council.

The selection committee will, whenever the Minister requests, put forward so many nominations as there are vacancies on the Council, having regard to the mix of skills and abilities that the Bill requires the Council to possess. The Minister may reject any nomination and request the selection committee to submit another one. Previous rejection or non-selection is not a barrier to subsequent nomination.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill and commend the Bill to honourable senators.
FISHING INDUSTRY RESEARCH AMENDMENT BILL 1987 [No. 2]

This Bill provides transitional arrangements between the effective termination of the Fishing Industry Research Act 1969 and the proposed operation of the Fishing Industry Research and Development Bill 1987 already before the House.

The Bill amends the Fishing Industry Research Act in a major sense. It repeals the appropriation and abolishes the Fishing Industry Research Committee, the functions of which will be replaced by the Fishing Industry Research and Development Bill. The remaining shell will preserve the Fishing Industry Research Trust Account until the money in that account has been spent or otherwise disposed of.

The Government has decided to apply the money in the research account, after settling all outstanding accounts and recovering all moneys due to the account, to acquiring a fisheries research vessel for the CSIRO Division of Fisheries Research. Should that outcome not occur, the Ministers for Finance and Resources are to confer about the disposal of the residue.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill and commend the Bill to honourable senators.
FISHING LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1987 [No. 2]

This Bill makes amendments of an essentially administrative and procedural nature to the Continental Shelf (Living Natural Resources) Act 1968, the Fisheries Act 1952 and the Torres Strait Fisheries Act 1984.

I can inform the Senate that there will be further amendments of the Fisheries Act to give effect in Australian law to the multilateral treaty between the United States and the Pacific island countries that are members of the Forum Fisheries Agency with respect to the operation of United States tuna boats in the exclusive fishing zones of those countries. The treaty, which was signed on 2 April 1987, will come into force when ratified by 10 Pacific island countries and the United States.

The Australian fishing industry is undergoing a period of profound change and it pleases me to say that this Government has in considerable measure been keeping in step with those changes. The Government approaches management of our fisheries on a cooperative basis with the fishing industry.

We have established the Fishing Industry Policy Council of Australia to provide a forum for government and industry to discuss issues of mutual interest. In the long-established framework of the Australian Fisheries Council, we have strengthened the institutional framework for consulting with the relevant industry sectors about the management of our major fisheries such as northern prawns, tuna, south-east trawl, southern shark and North West Shelf crustaceans. Statutory management plans are already in place with the full cooperation of industry in the two first-mentioned of those fisheries. We are working toward having management plans in place for the others in the near future.

The Government has implemented the fisheries element of the off-shore constitutional settlement with all but two States, with which negotiations are continuing. The off-shore constitutional settlement creates the statutory basis on which the Commonwealth and the States can enter into formal legal arrangements whereby a fishery is managed under a single law, be it Commonwealth or State, from the coast to the outer limit of our fisheries jurisdiction.

Arrangements with Queensland in the Torres Strait protected zone have been in place now for more than two years. Four arrangements with Tasmania and Victoria have been in place since June 1986. In June 1987, a further 18 arrangements with Queensland, South Australia, Western Australia and Tasmania came into force.

This Bill forms part of a package that includes a Bill to restructure the Commonwealth's involvement in fisheries research and development. This will follow lines essentially similar to those in the Rural Industries Research Act, taking account of the unique institutional factors that make a separate Fisheries Research and Development Act necessary.

In 1986-87, the volume of fisheries production was estimated at 152,500 tonnes, with an estimated gross value of $639m. The fishing industry ranks sixth among all Australia's rural industries on a value of production basis. Exports of fishery products have increased from $230m in 1980-81 to an estimated $591m in 1986-87 and have significantly exceeded the value of imports each year during that period. There are more than 9,000 boats in the Australian commercial fishing fleet with an annual consumption of about 240 million litres of diesel fuel. Estimated annual per capita consumption has risen from 6.2 kilograms in 1979-80 to 7.5 kilograms in 1984-85, measured as edible weight. These figures give a general picture of a vigorous fishing industry which is making a very important contribution to the domestic economy and food supplies as well as to foreign exchange earnings.

Against this fairly active domestic background, the provisions of the Bill reflect a wide range of recent administrative experience accumulated by the Australian Fisheries Service and the State fisheries authorities which undertake the day to day administration of the Acts that the Bill amends.

The Bill brings the three principal Acts that it amends into line insofar as their administrative provisions are concerned. The Bill shifts the emphasis of the provisions authorising the Minister to make notices for the regulation of the fisheries, away from the notices to the prohibitions in them. This will facilitate the preparation of notices containing several prohibitions each requiring separate endorsements of licences.

The Bill strengthens the powers of officers so that they may be better equipped to enforce the three Acts. It does so in accordance with those principles of Commonwealth legal policy that have regard to civil liberties and individuals' rights, taking account of the special circumstances in which the principal Acts are enforced.

The difficulties of detecting fisheries offences at sea far from the nearest land and a magistrate who can issue warrants with reasonable facility, make it necessary to provide fisheries enforcement officers with powers that in other circumstances might seem excessive. The Bill provides powers in this regard that the Government considers to be an acceptable balance between the need for effective enforcement and the protection of civil liberties. The Attorney-General's Department has advised that the Bill conforms with Commonwealth criminal law legal policy.

The Bill provides a basis for ascertaining the state of mind of a director or other agent of a body corporate where it is necessary to do so in legal proceedings for offences for which the Acts provide a penalty for a body corporate.

The Bill is of an essentially machinery nature for the better administration of the laws affecting Australia's fisheries and has no financial implications. The explanatory memorandum summarises its clauses, thus making it unnecessary for me to take the time of the Senate in a detailed explanation of them.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill and commend the Bill to honourable senators.

In the May economic statement, the Government foreshadowed its preparedness to sell its interest in the Primary Industry Bank of Australia (PIBA). The Commonwealth, along with all the shareholders in PIBA, subsequently accepted an offer from the Rural and Industries Bank of Western Australia (R and I Bank) to acquire all of the shares in PIBA. The sale of PIBA was completed on 30 June 1987 and resulted in revenue to the Commonwealth of $2.5m.

PIBA was established in 1978 under the provisions of the Primary Industry Bank Act 1977 specifically to provide long term funding to the rural sector through a refinance facility. Prior to the acquisition of PIBA by the R and I Bank, the Commonwealth had a 12.5 per cent shareholding and the four major trading banks, and a consortium of the four State banks, each had 17.5 per cent of the shares.

The deregulation of the financial system resulted in there no longer being a need for direct Commonwealth involvement in PIBA. Also, the multiple ownership of PIBA by a consortium of banks and the Commonwealth was proving unwieldy at that stage of PIBA's development. In selling its interest in PIBA, however, the Commonwealth has sought to ensure that the rural sector would not be disadvantaged in its access to banking services previously provided by PIBA and that the rural sector would continue to have a voice on the PIBA board.

Following its sale to the R and I Bank, PIBA is now in a position to build upon the valuable service it has provided to the rural sector in the past. In particular, opportunities for accelerated growth and the development of new financial services by PIBA are expected to arise. This will be of particular benefit to farmers given that PIBA's prime commitment will continue to be towards meeting the funding requirements of the rural sector.

PIBA was granted a banking authority under section 9 of the Banking Act on 30 June 1987 and as a result the Primary Industry Bank Act 1977 is now redundant. The purpose of this Bill is to seek its repeal and to make certain consequential amendments to the Banking Act 1959.
Accordingly, clause 3 of the Bill provides for the repeal of the Primary Industry Bank Act 1977.

Clause 4 of the Bill contains certain consequential amendments to the Banking Act 1959. The effect of these amendments will be to ensure that the provisions of the Banking Act 1959 apply to PIBA in the same way as they apply to all other trading banks. That treatment is now appropriate following the granting to PIBA of a banking authority under section 9 of the Banking Act.
I commend the Bill to the Senate. In doing so, I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: Any Opposition senators who take part in this debate have a hide, unless they are prepared to preface their remarks by saying that they concede that their Party's policy, just four or five short months ago in the run-up to the election campaign, to close down the Australian Tourist Commission (ATC) was wrong. But when they are told that the railway will run on one rail instead of two, they jump out of the nearest window. That seems to be the effect that the word `monorail' has on people.

I just want to make it clear that what I am talking about is not the kind of monorail that is about to operate in Sydney. It does not have to be elevated. Of course, in Sydney it has to travel above the existing traffic and in amusement parks a monorail has to travel above the park so that people can look down and see the park from a great height. What I am talking about is a monorail system that will operate like a normal railway, at ground level, and be completely non-intrusive in the environment. Anyone who has been to Ayers Rock and the Olgas knows that it is a spectacular desert environment. Of course, it would be criminal to suggest the construction of a monorail that would intrude in any way on that environment. The more I consider the proposal of a monorail, the more attractive from an environmental point of view it seems to be. It would be used as a substitute-not as an alternative-for the road and it would have the great advantage of providing an extremely safe system of transport which would be non-degrading of the environment because there would be no erosion problems associated with it. It would allow complete control of the tourist traffic to the Olgas, which is an area of great sensitivity to the Aboriginal owners of the park. They would be able to keep an almost total control on the visitation to the Olgas as a result of such a proposal. In my view it is without question that it would be an extremely attractive addition for visitors to the Uluru National Park in terms of safe, dust-free and erosion-free transport.

It is not beyond possibility that, if discussions were held between the Government and an organisation such as Thomas National Transport Ltd, which of course has expertise in this form of transportation, some agreement could be reached whereby that proposal could be constructed as a joint venture between the Government and a private company and run on a revenue-raising base. The reason I suggest that is that I think it would have the further advantage in years to come of the Aboriginal owners of the park being able to operate it for the generation of income for themselves, in the same way as the Aboriginal owners of Kakadu National Park currently use the Gagudju Association in that park to run the very successful tourist ventures at Cooinda and the motel that is currently being constructed at Jabiru. I look forward to following through that suggestion and determining precisely how feasible or not it is.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a single track.

—Yes, on a single track. I simply conclude my remarks in this debate by saying that one of the great advantages that the tourist industry offers in the current economic circumstances of Australia is that it is the best value for money, as far as the community is concerned, in terms of the dollars invested. No other industry in Australia provides the level of employment per dollar invested that the tourism and hospitality industry does. There is no question that in the Northern Territory, with our three major tourist attractions of Kakadu, Uluru and Katherine Gorge national parks, currently receiving the extent of tourist visitation that they do, that is the case.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to comment on something that an Australian Democrats senator said the other day in participation in this debate and with which I agree. A major tourism seminar which I attended in the town of Jabiru a number of years ago was opened by the then Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, Ian Tuxworth, saying that the experts, the advisers to the Tourist Commission in the Northern Territory, were telling us that the key to selling the Northern Territory as a tourist destination was our wildlife, our wilderness and the Aboriginal aspects of our culture and our community. I do not suppose that that came as any great surprise to anyone; nevertheless, that was enunciated by the then Chief Minister and I believe that it is precisely right.

One of the great advantages, and one of the things that people find attractive, is that the unique Aboriginal culture of the Northern Territory and the spectacular Aboriginal art produced in the Northern Territory are being drawn from a living and not a dead culture. What depresses me at times is that the same people who are promoting Aboriginal people in the Northern Territory solely in terms of the extent to which they can be exploited on behalf of the tourism industry also assert in the same breath that they are not entitled to any real place in our society, are not even recognised as Territorians and, indeed-as has been said in some quite extraordinary statements that have been made by people in public life in the Northern Territory-are not really recognised as part of the human race. We cannot have it both ways.

I must say that one of the noticeable and great benefits already derived from Aboriginal ownership of both Kakadu and Uluru national parks is the extent to which that ownership is commented upon and sought after by our visitors to the Northern Territory. Just a week or so ago, in a fairly lively radio session on talkback radio in Darwin-a program not renowned for its radical leanings-a visitor from Queensland who had been to Katherine Gorge National Park commented that, having just visited Kakadu and being extremely impressed by having been shown around Kakadu by the Aboriginal ranger staff-the Aboriginal people who live in Kakadu National Park and whose country it is-he was extremely disappointed that the same emphasis on Aboriginal ownership and Aboriginal care and protection of the park was not being shown at Katherine Gorge. As a result of Mr Justice Kearney having brought down a recommendation in his report on the Jarwoyn land claim that Katherine Gorge should be included in the grant of land, that situation might be resolved in the not too distant future.

There is no question that government has a real role to play in the tourism industry in Australia. The Government should not seek to override or duplicate anything which is being done by the entrepreneurs who work in that industry. In fact, it is a contribution which is freely acknowledged by those entrepreneurs as being valuable and beneficial to them, and I hope that it will continue.

There is no question that the restructuring of the Australian Tourist Commission will be beneficial to the industry. I hope that, in future years, the annual tourism awards will continue to be the great success that they are. There is no doubt that, with all the care and consideration that has to be given to the social and environmental impacts of tourism on Australia, tourism will continue to be the great benefit to the Australian economy that it is at the moment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating the Australian Tourist Commission Bill and the Australian Tourist Commission (Transitional Provisions) Bill. The Opposition will be supporting these Bills, although amendments will be moved later during the committee stage. At this stage I think it is appropriate that I should declare, once again, that I have had a personal interest in the tourist industry for some years now in my home State of Tasmania. Senator Collins has just given us the benefit of information about his home Territory, the Northern Territory, and the importance of tourism to him. Equally, of course, tourism in my State is a vitally important industry. Consequently, any senators representing Tasmania will inevitably find that tourism is a very active issue in their home State. I have some concerns about the Australian Tourist Commission Bill. I have concerns as to whether the Commission will adequately represent and co-ordinate the needs of the whole of Australia so that we can all benefit from the hoped for increase in international visitors.

SPEECH.PARA: Last year was a very good year for the tourism industry in Australia. It was a year of major achievement. Let me refer to some information which my colleague Senator Puplick mentioned in his speech to show just what we are looking for in the coming year. It is expected that tourism will contribute in the order of $24,000m to Australia's gross domestic product, making it probably our largest industry in terms of turnover. We believe that it will contribute about $3,000m in foreign currency income and will employ in the vicinity of 405,000 Australians in a huge variety of occupations scattered over the whole country. Something which is often forgotten is the tremendous flow-on effects to other industries of the benefits of the tourism industry.

As I have said, last year was certainly a year of major achievement in the industry and it is hoped that the coming year will be better than ever. The Government is claiming full credit for that marvellous year. Frankly, I find that unacceptable. The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mr John Brown) is a master of self-promotion, but we know that behind every successful man there is usually a woman plugging along-and, in the case of the Minister, I think she has been plugging along quite well. Although we have a Minister spectacularly successful at promoting-John Brown-the Government can only really be seen in this industry as a facilitator and the Government cannot take all the credit. In this industry, we have had masses of businesses, large and small, playing their individual parts in bringing our product up to international standard. A lot of work has gone into making the Australian tourist industry one which will confidently appeal to overseas visitors. That takes a lot of effort by a lot of people. It is not a one-man band, despite claims to that end by the Minister.

Not only have all these small and large operators played their part; the Government has really played a part in the sense of its misadventure. By its economic mismanagement, causing the fall in the dollar, Australia has seemed a very attractive place for people to holiday in. I do not know whether the Government really wants to claim that, due to its mismanagement, we have had so many overseas tourists, but it is a fact. Many people have been attracted to holiday here because of the low value of our dollar. That has been an incidental benefit of the mismanagement which we have all had to face, which has caused problems in other areas, but which has been a blessing in disguise for the tourist industry.

Another thing that the Government cannot take credit for is the fact that so many other tourist destinations have become dangerous places to visit over the last two or three years. Australia, thank God, can still be regarded as a safe tourist destination. We should not underestimate the importance of that when we consider how successful our tourism industry has become and when we consider the growth that we have experienced. The ability to protect our tourists when they come here, in comparison with protection in other places, is very important in any assessment of how well we have been doing. I hope that the Government will see to it that our airports are safely protected in the future. We have been fortunate in not having incidents of terrorism. It is not something which we can take for granted and be complacent about as a nation. When we have cutbacks or a lack of manpower in some of the protection areas we must signal that there is concern that the safe reputation which we now have may not be one that we can enjoy forever, unless we work at it.

I think the time has now come when we must consolidate the gains we have had in the industry and make sure that the benefits are shared, not just by the big States but also by the smaller and more distant States. I am sure Senator Collins would agree that we do not want all the visitors ending up in Melbourne and Sydney. It is difficult to get tourists out of Melbourne and Sydney. This is one of the matters on which I have had a continuing interest concerning the work of the Australian Tourist Commission. I recognise that the Commission is trying to do something and to inform the tourists of other destinations in Australia, but I have long believed that not an active enough part is played by it in actually persuading tourists to come to parts of Australia other than Melbourne and Sydney. For so many foreigners, Australia is the Sydney Harbour Bridge and the Sydney Opera House, yet we know that in Sydney we have the most congested airport in Australia and Sydney causes the greatest difficulties for tourists who are trying to get accommodation. There is also a curfew on the airport. In comparison, other places have excellent international airports, good accommodation and the ability for planes to fly in around the clock, yet constantly we have this imbalance in our tourists entering Sydney as the major entry point. I am very glad that Sydney gets so many tourists, but I think we have to try to create a balance around the country so that the benefits are shared by all Australians and undue pressure is not put on that one entry point, with the frustrations and the delays to tourists that such congestion causes.

The figures for distribution of international tourists around Australia are quite revealing. I recall that northern Queensland gets at most 12 or 15 per cent of the international visitors who come to this country. My State gets only 3 per cent of the international visitors. It is a great shame if we cannot send out visitors to some of the most beautiful and special parts of our country. We have heard at length from Senator Collins about the beauties of Kakadu National Park and Uluru National Park. Having visited those parts of Australia, and as an Australian, I am very proud of them and glad to think that we have such beautiful places for visitors. But equally we have the Great Barrier Reef, we have the islands off the coast of Queensland, we have tropical and temperate rainforests and we have the beautiful island of Tasmania. We have so many places, yet we seem to be funnelling all our visitors into one little triangle in the south-east corner of Australia. It is important that we take a more active role in encouraging people to come to other parts of the country.

Therefore the decision that was taken to move the Australian Tourist Commission to Sydney seems to me a great pity. Inevitably when an organisation, which is very actively involved in selling Australia to overseas visitors, is located in the one area which is overcrowded with tourists, I believe that we must inevitably expect to find that its employees will develop a mind set on Sydney and that they, like so many Sydneysiders, will come to believe that Sydney is Australia. Those of us who come from other parts know full well that it is not. But it is very easy for Sydneysiders to think that Sydney is the hub of existence and that the world revolves around it. If the Commission is expected to sell the rest of Australia, I think it is a pity that it has moved to Sydney and its attitude will be contaminated.

I think the move to Sydney is an absolute fiasco. At a time of great economic difficulty in this country, it is a waste of the taxpayers' dollar to be spending $3.3m to move to Sydney an organisation that was established in Melbourne. Only four of the 45 people in the Melbourne office elected to move. The Government paid off people who were not prepared to move and gave them redundancy payments amounting to $1.4m. The largest share of the costs of relocation went in the redundancy payments for those 41 people. As I said, only four of the original experienced group in Melbourne have seen fit to take up residence in Sydney. I think the decision to move there was not the wisest to begin with. It worries me that it will add to this heavy emphasis on tourism beginning and ending in Sydney.

I am also disappointed to see that the Government has reduced the number of board members from 13 to nine. I am not a great believer in large boards or large committees, but I do not consider 13 to be large. I think that with 13 we had an opportunity to have a wider range of views and representation. I think nine is too small and that it limits opportunities for representation that the previous board of 13 offered. The automatic inclusion of members from each State and Territory, on a rotational basis, has been cancelled. I think that is unbelievable, a shame and most disappointing. In the past the States criticised the rotational system, saying that they were disadvantaged when they were not participating on the Commission board. In other words, they found that the ability to participate on the board was a great advantage, and they did not like it when it was not their turn to be on it. So the Minister used this criticism as a reason to cut out their participation entirely. That is just a nonsense. Does he honestly believe that this will resolve the dissatisfaction of the States? It could only have been made worse. The interests of the various States are so diverse that I believe there should be wider representation than we are now going to get.

Sadly, there is no more provision for industry to nominate board members. They will all be political appointments. Over the last 4 1/2 years we have had a very politicising government. As the years have progressed we have gradually come to see that no matter what the people who have a cosy relationship with the present Government are being appointed to boards. I am very apprehensive about what political appointments we are going to see this Government make to the new Tourist Commission. Industry will find that the voice it has from the board will be the Government's voice and not its voice. There is a very real danger that there will be nobody to keep the board accountable to the industry that it serves, and it is something about which I shall be satisfied to the contrary only when I see it operating more effectively than my fears would suggest will be possible.

In discussing the Australian Tourist Commission Bill, I want to refer to the tourism overseas promotion scheme (TOPS). This scheme has had its up and downs, but I believe it was very important for the Australian tourist industry. It is a great disappointment that the Government has seen fit to abolish it. In fact, I think that stronger language is really required, when we realise how many businesses have been left in the lurch by the Government through the abrupt cancellation of the scheme. It has been of great assistance to people trying to advertise overseas. As most honourable senators would realise, it is extremely expensive for a small business to advertise overseas, or even for a business of almost any size, without assistance from the Government and the co-operative arrangements that were in place. The Minister himself said not long ago that it was a cost-effective incentive scheme, and I agree with him. Its cancellation will very much restrict the abilities of firms to advertise overseas, and that does not mean just those particular firms; Australia will be advertised that much less overseas.

What worries me is that a number of firms have committed themselves and have suddenly been left without funds. The Government will say that they should not have committed themselves, as the rules were laid down as to how they would get reimbursement, and it is their fault if they went out on a limb and committed themselves. But I think in the present circumstances that could not be a fair rejoinder. The Minister committed $9m for the TOPS scheme in June of this year to cover 1987-88. As I said, this scheme has had its ups and downs. The Minister's commitment of $9m was made after there had been very real fears in the industry that the scheme was to be axed. I would like to quote from a speech which I made in the Senate on 12 May concerning TOPS. It was the result of inquiries that I had been involved in with an Estimates committee in that same month. I said:

Only a month or so ago, the Australian Hotels Association drew attention to the fact that of 33 organisations using that scheme, which were contacted by the International Tourism Organisation of Australia, 30 were experiencing problems with delays in approval, delays in payments or both. I asked the Department of Sport, Recreation and Tourism a question about that during an Estimates committee hearing. Officers agreed that they were having trouble and that the administrative situation was in some sort of chaos. They said that they were getting too many applications to be able to cope and that the Minister was in consultation with the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) on the question of forward commitment for future proposals. I understand that they are now somewhere between $8m and $15m in arrears on this matter.

The idea of the scheme was good, but the scheme itself was very defective because of the way in which it was being administered. When the Minister said that the applications which had been held up pending the resolution of the matter would be `processed forthwith', the industry had a fresh lease of confidence. He said that $9m would be committed and so the industry went ahead with its advertising, having been held up for so long while the scheme was in such a mess. So much for the Minister's word. As I said earlier, he is great on promotion but he obviously is not so great on winning his case in Cabinet. This $9m commitment made in June this year, which was to cover 1987-88, has been axed. Some of these firms that have gone out on a limb expecting that the Government's word was its bond are facing financial ruin. I urge the Government to look again at what it can do to help those people who acted on the commitment of Minister Brown.

The Government has just recently taken another action which has an impact on the tourist industry, and I think it is one to be criticised. I am very disappointed; it is a backward step, as far as I am concerned, for the depreciation allowance to be cut from 4 per cent to 2.5 per cent. The Government had previously increased the allowance to 4 per cent from 2 1/2 per cent, and the Minister was skiting about that in only May this year-making a great good fellow of himself. Once again, he does not seem to have carried much weight in Cabinet and we are back to 2 1/2 per cent again. It looks as though the Government has decided that the tourism industry has enough infrastructure which is built by Australians. Of course, Australians are the ones who also have to cope with the high interest rates that this Government has imposed on this nation. That puts them at a distinct disadvantage when they are trying to develop properties in this industry in competition with their foreign competitors. So we now have the prospect of foreign investors in this country buying up Australian real estate and developing properties often for the nationals of other countries and also making their profits out of Australians. But the Australian developer and the small business people who are so crippled with high interest rates have now had their depreciation allowance reduced by a government that is supposed to be encouraging this industry. In the tourism industry the depreciation allowance is of great importance.

Another little action that the Government has slipped into the tourist industry which I think is a very sneaky one is the arrivals tax. For the first time Australians will have to pay to get back into their country as well as to get out. It is a wonder the Government has not put a padlock on the door. Most overseas visitors also pay a departure tax in their own country when they leave. They now have to pay to get into their country of destination as well and then again when they leave. It is these little ways that governments find of milking the tourist that gradually start to make a country look like an expensive or unacceptable destination. I think the Government will get away with this measure because it will not ask those tourists to hand over their money as they arrive; it will slug it to the carriers-and that just simply makes Australia look like a more expensive destination in terms of travel costs. That is how it will get away with that. It will not have to deal with the fury of individuals, but it deserves to.

Tourism has become Australia's largest industry. It is also a very important industry, as I have said, in my home State of Tasmania. We do not believe that Tasmania is getting the share of international visitors that it should be getting. I think that this legislation will only make the situation worse in that Tasmania, as a State, will not have a voice on the board. It is also losing out from the axing of TOPS because operators in my State are largely small operators who have very little chance of promoting themselves overseas without assistance. I just query: How will my State have a voice on such an important board, the decisions of which will affect the State, on which it is not represented, and from which it is geographically quite isolated?

The Government has done a quite good public relations job for itself on its efforts in the tourism area, but when we look very closely at the achievements we see that the record is not so glowing. We have had the politicisation of the Australian Tourist Commission. We have the waste of funds in the move of the Tourist Commission. We have the mismanagement of TOPS. We have had the breaking of commitments and faith to the industry over the scheme. We have had the cut in the depreciation allowance. We are selling off the farm to foreigners and making it more difficult for locals to develop tourism infrastructure. The Government excuses itself over its inability to come to grips with the penalty rate problems of this industry. It has failed to deal with the problems of Sydney airport-with the curfew and the need for a second airport. And it has introduced an arrivals tax. I do not think its record is very glowing at all. We on this side of the Parliament support efforts to improve the tourist industry. We believe that it is good for Australia and we believe that it is good for jobs for young Australians, but we want to see the Government doing better.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In addressing the issues that are raised today by the Australian Tourist Commission Bill and the Australian Tourist Commission (Transitional Provisions) Bill, I want to concentrate on a number of key types of areas. I want to concentrate on what I see as the centralisation of the promotion function in Australian tourism. I would also like to look at, as have a number of honourable senators already, the structure of the board and also its salary structure. The issue of the relocation of the Melbourne office, of course, has already attracted some attention and it deserves further comment. I would like to look also at the scrapping of the tourism overseas promotion scheme (TOPS) and particularly the impact that this scheme has in smaller areas of Australia that are perhaps struggling and need this type of support. I would like to relate a few of my comments specifically to my electorate, the Northern Territory, which is, after all, the pioneer frontier of Australia. It is still seen with that image; it is still the great promotional front card of every pamphlet and brochure that is issued for Australian tourism. I would also like to concentrate a few comments on the promotion of Aboriginal activity in the tourist industry, which I think has been sadly lacking in any statement by the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mr John Brown) or indeed a number of other authorities.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bills before us today are based on the recommendations of the report of the Kennedy Inquiry into Australian Tourism. In that report there were 96 recommendations, the majority of which were directed at the future structure of the Australian Tourist Commission. All but two recommendations were accepted. I will be talking about two of the recommendations in that report: the one concerning TOPS, to avoid disruption to industry; and the recommendation to make the salary structure for board members more flexible. The Australian Tourist Commission will take over overseas promotion of Australia as a tourist destination. In the second reading speech of the Minister for the Environment and the Arts (Senator Richardson), he stated:
The major thrust of the Commission's activity will now be towards promoting Australia as an attractive tourist destination in the international market place.
In the next paragraph the reason for this is given as follows:

But it needs to be emphasised that rationalisation of the amount of money spent overseas by governments and industry is required to maximise the effects of those resources for the benefit of Australia's economy overall.

That needs to be looked at very carefully as a statement. If the Minister is attempting, perhaps in his ministerial aspirations, to aim for a more economic portfolio he might be compromising what ought to be seen as an area of major economic activity in the tourist area. We need to ask very seriously: What will be the role of State and Territory tourist commissions in overseas promotion? If a State or Territory wishes to promote its specific areas of tourist attraction and it does so in a sensible and rational manner with appropriate consultation with the Australian Tourist Commission, such effort should be seen as complementary to Australian Tourist Commission activity. I put to Senator Richardson and Minister Brown the question: What input will the States have into the Australian Tourist Commission? More specifically, I would like them to address the input industry groups will have into the Australian Tourist Commission. The number of Board members has been cut from 13 to nine and the appointment procedure of members of the Board is unclear. Clause 13 sub-clause (2) of the Australian Tourist Commission Bill states:
The Minister may appoint a person as a member other than the government member only if the Minister is satisfied that the person has expertise relevant to the Australian tourism industry.
State representation on the Board has been scrapped. The Minister in his second reading speech stated:
This Bill removes the current formalised State representation on the Board.
However, close consultations with the States is essential to the operations of the Commission and alternative and more effective consultative mechanisms are now being developed and implemented.
What are these consultative mechanisms? What is to be put in place? More important is the fact that industry groups will have no representation. I again quote from the second reading speech:

. . . the Bill provides for the Board members to be appointed by virtue of their individual skills, expertise and experience relevant to and in the tourism industry, rather than as representatives of associations, States, Territories or other bodies which may have particular tourism interests.

That statement seems to go round in circles and allows unusual, different and perhaps not necessarily conducive to tourism type appointments in this area. It is wise to give the industry some distinct input into how it is being promoted overseas. I refer to the statutory relationship with the Australian Public Service. It is interesting to note that although the Australian Public Service Board has been disbanded, the terms and conditions applying to employees of the revamped Australian Tourist Commission apparently remain firmly entrenched within the bureaucracy in that they are largely determined by the Federal Department of Industrial Relations. It is to be argued that the Australian Tourist Commission is involved in an industry which is essentially entrepreneurially orientated and must have the capacity to respond immediately and creatively to new and changing opportunities and circumstances. I would like to see the Minister address the particular points of how, within the structure, he will be able to maintain, while working alongside an industry that is largely entrepreneurially orientated, the capacity for the Commission to operate as effectively as it ought.

The Melbourne office was relocated to Sydney and the expenditure was $800,000 on each relocated employee. Out of 45 staff, 41 decided to accept the redundancy package offered and stay in Melbourne, involving a cost of $1.485m. Once the four remaining staff and some files had been moved to Sydney, the total cost was $3.2m. I refer honourable senators to the Estimates committee hearings on this matter. That is not a bad start for a body whose job it will be to administer, in an efficient fashion, funds for overseas promotion. Surely more comment and attention should be given to looking carefully at the financial situation.

The TOPS scheme was abolished as one of the 15 September Federal Budget initiatives. This broken election promise was made by the Minister, Mr John Brown, who assured the industry that TOPS would continue. On 4 June this year he said:
I'm happy to say that the Government has agreed to afford commitment cover for the TOPS of $9 million for 1987/88.
On 6 October 1987, in the other place, he said:

Certainly statements have been made by me prior to the election, at various forums, that the Government had committed $9m for the provision of TOPS payments for the year 1987-88. I might inform the honourable member that, despite the fact that the Government has decided to discontinue TOPS, that promise will be honoured, and $9m has been made available-$6m to honour commitments made with ministerial approval and the additional $3m for the Australian Tourist Commission for additional promotion.

If the Minister promised $9m knowing full well that $6m was to go in already approved funding, he must have had it in mind to scrap TOPS anyway because a $15m backlog of unapproved applications was being processed. I am familiar with tourist operators in the Northern Territory who have been left seriously out of pocket as a result of this measure. They budgeted for their overseas promotions expecting that assistance would be provided through TOPS. The pre-election statements by the Minister gave them confidence. Now they are in financial trouble. Let me quote from two industry leaders-one a pioneer establishing a new enterprise in tourism in the Northern Territory, Mrs Penni Tastula, the General Manager of Northern Gateway Pty Ltd. I have a copy of a letter that she wrote recently to Mr John Brown and I propose to quote parts of it. Mrs Tastula stated:
I have received advice of the cancellation of the Tourist Overseas Promotional Scheme and I am extremely disappointed in your failure to uphold the promises made to us at ATE in June this year.
I have a newly formed company in the Northern Territory and my sole function is the promotion of inbound package holidays to Northern Australia, using Darwin as a gateway port.
On the strength of your promises, I have budgeted for:
1 A full colour brochure for overseas distribution.
2 A special priced insert to attract inbound tourists during the wet season.
3 Participation in Australian Tourist Commission promotions TABS in Bangkok, the Jakarta Promotion in Jakarta and Royal Brunei Airlines Promotion Travel Forum in Brunei, Sabah and Sarawak.
4 Production of a promotional static display to use at the above promotions to enable me to emphasise the potential of the north as a tourist destination.
Mrs Tastula continued with details of how she put together her financial package. She arrived at a subsidy of over $10,000 for which she would have been eligible. Her letter continues:

I would not have undertaken promotions of this dimension, without having believed that your commitment to this scheme was sound. For a new small business, struggling to get established and promote tourism into remote regions, the withdrawal of this subsidy of over $10,000 after our commitments had been made, is devastating.
I ask that you reconsider your stand and at least allow current claims such as that of Northern Gateway to be honoured.

At another end of the tourist spectrum in the Northern Territory is a much longer established, larger firm, CATA Tours, or as it is often known, Central Australian Tours Association Pty Ltd. This firm, which is a sightseeing tour specialist in the Northern Territory, wrote to me on 15 October. I quote the Director, Keith Castle, who stated:
I would like to bring to your notice the problems now being encountered by this company owing to the TOPS scheme being removed for an export grant scheme.
This company, in conjunction with two of our member companies, made use of the original E.M.D.G. scheme which later became TOPS.

Part of this use was to establish overseas offices to further promote, sell and reserve products. This commitment, naturally is an ongoing responsibility and has proved to be successful. However, with the Australian dollar being weak compared with the United States dollar and English pound, the removal of TOPS means to this company a direct annual loss or reduction in profit of $A150,000 to maintain the necessary overseas promotions.
I would welcome your thoughts on this matter and your support to have the decision re TOPS reversed and reintroduced for genuine operators such as this company.

I certainly concur in the opinion that those two examples indicate the heartlessness and callousness of the Hawke Government in not properly honouring its own commitments and really evaluating and assessing where export marketing-which is really what tourism is all about-really comes from.

I want to talk for a few moments about the Northern Territory and its different tourist scene. It is interesting to note that at the national and international levels it is the Northern Territory-in fact, all the north of Australia, through Western Australia and Queensland-that provides the essential marketing image of why Australia is different. This still relates really to that pioneer and frontier part of Australia, where the climate, the topography and the people are different. As a consequence of media support in the past few years, some of it favourable and some unfavourable, we have attracted to Australia hundreds of thousands of tourists. The Azaria Chamberlain case, for all its tragedy and trauma and personal factors, provided a focus internationally that has highlighted Ayers Rock around the world. A tourist payola has derived from that unfortunate incident. The movie Crocodile Dundee, of international reputation and good fun, has, for example, made people see that the people of the outback of Australia have something very special to offer in the way of tourist destinations. The hard work of groups like the Northern Territory Tourist Commission, and similar bodies in both Queensland and Western Australia, has involved them in really going out of the way to prove that governments and industry can co-ordinate and liaise in these areas.

In the area of Aboriginal tourism, it is interesting to note that very significant economic and sociological advantages flow from the involvement of Aborigines in tourism. I highlight to the Senate the recent developments that have taken place at Kakadu, at Uluru near Ayers Rock, on the Cobourg Peninsula, and with the Tiwi Tours groups and organisations at Bathurst Island. In Central Australia, Aborigines from outstations such as Hermannsburg are becoming involved in very special tours. People are invited to go bush and experience unusual aspects. These are very unusual and different organised tours. Further, at Nhulunbuy in north-eastern Arnhem Land and on the Wessel islands the Aboriginal people are developing very special fishing experiences that will involve many people. This involvement of Aborigines in tourism enhances their economic situation and it provides the broader community with the opportunity to understand the cultural differences and the importance of Aboriginal culture in Australia. At the same time, it allows Aboriginal people to become involved in profitable and educational ventures for the future.

Yet, neither Minister Brown nor the Australian Tourist Commission has set out specifically to look at areas of research for consideration in relation to the potential impact by Aboriginal people on tourism in Australia. For that matter, nor has any detailed consideration been given to the question of how Aboriginal people can benefit from and be involved in the tourism industry. I believe that that matter needs to be carefully considered.

Naturally, this Bill is one that excites the industry throughout Australia. Just about every Australian family on at least one occasion during the year comes into contact with the products of local Australian tourism while on their annual holidays. However, I would argue that just about every Australian family is also involved at least annually in meeting at least one international or overseas visitor family. I think that that sort of impact into our lounge rooms, our businesses and the community demands much more considered and detailed work than is currently being given to this proposal by the Hawke Government that we are considering.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —From this debate it is clear that people do realise the importance of tourism in Australia, which brings in an income in excess of $20,000m a year. Some $3,000m of that amount comes from overseas tourists who come to Australia either on holiday or on business. The tourist industry is particularly important in the area that I represent, namely, the Australian Capital Territory (ACT). We are putting great emphasis on getting tourists to come here and on diversifying our economy and, of course, we are very mindful of the opportunities that will be available to us in 1988, with the activities of the bicentennial year and, of outstanding significance, with the opening of the new Parliament House. Thus, it is important that we look at the proposed changes that the Government is making to the Australian Tourist Commission.

SPEECH.PARA: The matter of its being moved from Melbourne to Sydney has been debated. In passing, I might say that if there is dispute between whether it should be in Melbourne or Sydney one should not forget that the national capital is here for exactly the reason of accommodating the great departments of state and government instrumentalities. I can understand the argument in this instance for the Australian Tourist Commission being in either Melbourne or Sydney, but it is interesting to note that, while the Government has declined to locate the Commission in the national capital, it seeks to retain control over it in the way that it does. I shall refer further to that matter as I address further relevant matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where is your electorate?

—My electorate is the Australian Capital Territory, where some 260,000 people live. The Kennedy Inquiry into Australian Tourism report forms the basis of the changes that are being made in this legislation. Some 76 recommendations were made, many of which have been adopted. One might think it is churlish to mention just the few that have not been adopted but, in fact, they relate to significant points, and I think we have to dwell on them. I think that the legislation has been marred by the decision of the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mr John Brown) and by the way that he has gone about the matter. I refer in particular to his refusal to give the tourism industry an opportunity to participate in the naming of members of the new Australian Tourism Commission.

SPEECH.PARA: The Kennedy report refers to this matter. It suggests that the number ought to be reduced. Senator Newman referred to the fact that the States will no longer be participating in the way that they have done in the past. The proposal is that the number of members on the board be reduced from 13 to nine. Recommendation 21 states:

That the enabling legislation of the Australian Tourist Commission be amended to enable the appointment of a Board of nine members, including the Managing Director and a senior departmental representative.

A smaller board might be more efficient, but whether leaving State representation off is in the best interests of tourism, I do not know. However, in most circumstances a board of nine members would certainly be a quite efficient group. Recommendation 22 states:
That appointments to the Board be made by the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism, with the exception of the Managing Director, who shall be appointed by the Board.

A provision that the Minister should appoint members of the board is in itself not exceptional, except that in this case the Minister has translated that to mean that he shall choose all appointees to the board. That is what is causing many of us a considerable amount of concern. Recommendation 23 suggests:
That the Board members be appointed by virtue of their individual skills, expertise, experience in the tourist industry, rather than as representatives of associations, State/Territories . . .

I can understand why one would want to have people on it who do have expertise in the area. This reminds me of the recent appointments made by this very same Minister to the Canberra Theatre Trust. He has failed to reappoint Ms Libby Smith, a woman with expertise in the theatre area. At the same time, Mrs Ellnor Grassby and Mrs Ingrid Murphy are to be members of the Theatre Trust. I am sure they both have something to offer but one wonders about the appointments that are made from time to time, especially when it is recommended that individual skills should be taken into account.

We have further evidence of the Minister's decisions in relation to appointments, including his failure to appoint Mr David Crossin to the Australian Capital Territory Gaming and Liquor Authority. He is a man of incredible experience, and there is now only one member of that Authority who has any background in racing. I could mention other cases where expertise, experience, et cetera have not been taken into account when this Minister has made appointments. That is one of the worries I have in relation to the future of the Tourist Commission: how will the Minister interpret individual skills, expertise and experience?

Clearly the industry would prefer to be involved in Board appointments. It is not right to say that it is happy with the arrangement which is now to operate. As I have said, the nine people appointed will be those whom the Minister chooses. I can see no reason why he should not include in the legislation the provision that the industry should, if not appoint two people, put up to him two or three names from which he can choose; people whom the industry regards as having skill, expertise and experience in the industry. It really is quite extraordinary for a Minister to feel that he is so almighty that he is the one best placed to choose the people who will be members of something as important as this.

I want to mention just a few things in relation to our experience in the ACT. The Minister has abolished the parliamentary Joint Standing Committee on the Australian Capital Territory, which has served the Parliament well, and he has abolished other authorities and advisory boards in the Territory which in the past have been available for those who have a particular interest to communicate with government. As I said, it causes me to worry about what will be the real implication for the Australian Tourist Commission. I raised this the other night in an Estimates committee hearing, and it was interesting to see the other Minister from the same department, the Minister for the Environment and the Arts, (Senator Richardson) come to his senior Minister's aid. He made what he thought was a reassuring comment, saying that the Minister was very popular with the industry, and he had no doubt the industry would have great faith in whatever nominations he was prepared to make. That is fine, but I do not believe that is the way the industry looks at the matter. I think that is presumptuous and ill-founded, and I think the Minister would have been much more convincing had he decided to invite the industry to put up names and give him an opportunity then to make the appointments. The Opposition will be moving an amendment to restore that right, and I would certainly urge honourable senators to support it.

We will also be proposing an amendment to clause 29, which involves some of the same problems and issues I have just referred to. Under clause 29 the Minister will have the right to give directions in writing to the Board in relation to the performance of its functions, and the exercise of its powers, and the Board, of course, shall comply with the directions. Sub-clause (2) indicates that the Minister shall not direct the Board unless certain things have happened, and the Minister will cause a copy of any direction to be published in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette and laid before the Houses of Parliament for a certain number of sitting days, and the annual report will include such directions. That would be fine, perhaps, but it really does take the Commission right into the heart of the Minister's office, especially when we find that sub-clause (4) says:
Subsection (3)-
that is, the sub-clause in the Bill relating to the publication of directions-
does not apply in relation to a particular direction if the Minister determines, in writing, that compliance with the subsection would be contrary to the public interest.

Where have we got to? We have a situation where the Minister has the right to appoint the board that he wants. He can give it written directions and, if he does not really want to, if he thinks it is not in the public interest-whatever that might mean-to disclose the fact that he has given instructions, he need not do so. I really wonder what sort of a commission we will finish up with on that basis. I cannot understand how anyone could feel that the Commission is being improved, bearing in mind the two issues I have referred to so far. The Kennedy report has stressed the need for the Commission to comprise skilled members who will have the ability to make decisions, who know more about the tourist industry than the Minister. But perhaps the Minister thinks that he does know more about the industry than those with experience in it. I suggest that, with the number of interests he has in his portfolio, that really would not be the case. We want the industry to have the maximum possible opportunity to consult with government and to have an input into the decisions being made. I think that the legislation falls short in this regard.

Many speakers have referred to the tourism overseas promotion scheme (TOPS). I cannot say that that has been referred to and then not mention it myself, because it is too significant that the Government has turned its back on the industry, and it has, by abandoning this scheme. When the scheme was launched in June 1985, the Minister in a Press release informed the tourism industry that TOPS had been developed to meet the industry's special needs. This was the Minister telling the industry that he knew all about it. He said:
It will have the advantages of producing a more co-ordinated and efficient promotional effort and will enable specialist advice to be given to prospective promoters.

In another Press release, of September 1985, he claimed that the scheme `would provide enormous benefits to the burgeoning tourism industry'. It had, he said, `been tailor-made to suit industry requirements'. It is not fitting too well now, is it? In the same Press release he said:
The new TOPS scheme removes the element of uncertainty of any previous export incentive schemes.
There is plenty of uncertainty now. He went on:
Tourism operators can plan marketing strategies safe in the knowledge that their expenditure falls within TOPS guidelines.
That is significant. He also said:
The other major advantage is the prompt payment of rebates. Previously, operators had to wait up to eighteen months or more for payments to be approved, processed and paid.

In April this year the Minister was claiming that TOPS, along with other programs conducted by the Government, was the best thing that had ever happened to Australian tourism, and as recently as 4 June this year he made a statement indicating that the Government had agreed to a forward commitment for TOPS of $9m in 1987-88. In September, only three months later, the Minister announced that the scheme would be terminated-after all those words, after all that build-up.

In the process, many who had anticipated approval had prepared applications for assistance and had put those applications in. Others had them ready but had not put them in. One might say that they should not have spent any money until approval had been given. On many occasions that would be a very valid comment, but I take honourable senators back to the Minister's promotional words:
Tourism operators can now plan marketing strategies safe in the knowledge that their expenditure falls within TOPS guidelines.

There was very little discretion, if any, for the Minister to refuse to approve schemes which were put forward. The guidelines were clear and any operator who wished to be involved could know what the guidelines were, could prepare his application within those guidelines and be confident of approval. Even so, to get approval considerable funds had to be spent to put up a package to meet the guidelines, and people have been left in difficulty. Some had put in applications which had been approved, but they did not receive their money even after applications had been processed.

In regard to one matter to which I referred specifically in the Estimates Committee, I am grateful to an officer who is present in the chamber. He has followed up the matter and tells me that the claim has been approved and a cheque will be sent to those concerned. But many others are waiting for money. People who spent money preparing proposals were certain in the knowledge that they had complied with the guidelines, but then suddenly in September of this year, following a statement in June that there would be money for 1987-88, they discovered that the scheme had been cut off and terminated. There is good reason to think that many operators in tourism are not just disappointed with the Minister's performance but rightly feel that they have been left high and dry and that the Minister has no understanding of the industry. People cannot operate on a stop-go basis. If they are attempting to build up tourist developments to attract overseas tourists they need to know that they will be able to proceed with their projects and will not have their market strategies cut off, as has happened. It is a disgraceful performance. The Minister should know that the industry is not pleased with him and is not impressed with his ability as an expert in the area.

One of the other recommendations of the Kennedy report was that the Commission be removed from its statutory relationships with the Public Service Board on industrial matters, and particularly terms and conditions of employment. It is interesting to note that this recommendation also has been rejected. The Opposition supports the recommendation. The recommendation indicates that it is necessary for a body such as the Tourist Commission to be able to operate more on the lines of a private sector activity, to be out in the market-place and not to be tied down by the restrictions, rules and regulations that generally cover Public Service operations. But for some reason the Government has rejected that. Again, it looks odd when one sees that the Minister would appoint the commissioners and that by way of clause 29 (4) he has virtually retained unto himself the ability to run the place from his own office.

The Government keeps saying how expert it is in affairs and how talented is its front bench. Now we see that the Minister is the one and only expert in the area of tourism. I believe that the Government should take back this Bill and have another look at it. It should consider what role it believes the Tourism Commission should be playing and what steps the Government should be taking to assist and work with the tourist industry to maximise the number of tourists who come to this country. At a time when it is necessary to earn export income, we need to do as much as we can to that end, rather than proceeding in a way that is counterproductive to the development of the proposals which many tourist operators have.

The Opposition will be supporting amendments that it believes will be significant in improving the legislation. I hope that the Government will seriously consider our amendments and our reasons for putting them forward. We want to increase the number of tourists to Australia. In the case of the electorate that I represent, we want to give an opportunity for tourism to expand and flourish. We want the tourist area to increase its percentage of the work force in the Australian Capital Territory from the present figure of 7 per cent. Canberra has many tourist facilities that are attractive to people. Well over one million tourists come to the Territory at present and I believe that we have hardly scratched the surface. But we need to use the expertise of those who have experience in the industry to make sure that we go about it in the right way. I hope that the Australian Tourist Commission will become a significant part of the industry, but let us not leave it in the state it is with the legislation that is now before us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to offer my comments on the Australian Tourist Commission Bill 1987, the purpose of which is to give effect to the restructuring and reorganisation of the Australian Tourist Commission in line with the recommendations of the Kennedy Inquiry into Australian Tourism which were endorsed by the Government in 1986. However, as Senator Reid has just done, I also want to draw attention to the fact that the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mr John Brown) and the Government have not seen fit to adopt one of the most important recommendations of the Kennedy report, namely, that the Australian Tourist Commission be removed from the Public Service Board terms and conditions of employment. Tourism is a competitive industry and needs entrepreneurial skills in a free enterprise environment. I believe that this recommendation of the Kennedy report should have been adopted so that employees can be away from the Public Service Board rules and regulations.

SPEECH.PARA: Tourism is increasingly becoming Australia's major industry and as such requires the sophistication of planning and growth management towards which the former legislation was not adequately geared. The potential for tourism growth in this country is enormous, and with the right sort of planning, research and development techniques Australia will become the world's number one holiday destination. I like to think that it is gradually getting there and doing very well indeed. That is the bottom line, and that is why a restructuring of the Australian Tourist Commission is welcome as it will enable the Commission to perform its functions more effectively.

However, I regret, as other speakers in this debate have regretted, the fact that in the restructuring of the Australian Tourist Commission direct representation of the industry on the board has been eliminated. The board has always had two representatives from the Australian Travel Industry Association (ATIA). We have on the board a very fine Queenslander, Sir Frank Moore, and he has given wonderful service to tourism in Queensland and, of course, in Australia as a whole. This is an aspect the Government should examine because Australia needs people with expertise such as Sir Frank Moore on the board. The Minister needs to be able to get advice from people like Sir Frank who have the know-how about tourism, to ensure that Australia will be promoted as an attractive tourist destination in the international market-place.

This is an area with which I am a little familiar because I have been overseas twice on behalf of the Queensland Tourist and Travel Corporation on promotional visits aimed at the North American market. I do not try to compete with Crocodile Dundee. I know I am not as smart as Paul Hogan--

TALK.START.PARA: —I think you would be much tastier.

—I am glad to hear that, Senator. I like to think that the little bit I did while there had some good results. I believe that people from America and also Japan are having a love affair with Australia at the moment. I was pleased when Sir Frank Moore asked me to go to the United States and do some media work to encourage Americans to come down under. When people come to Queensland they automatically go to the other States. I know Senator Tate would agree that they would love to go to Tasmania while they are in Australia; I feel sure about that. I had the opportunity to go to Dallas in Texas and to Los Angeles where I appeared on television, and only last May it was my privilege to open a new Queensland Tourist and Travel Corporation office in New York to encourage Americans from the east coast of the United States to come to Queensland, and indeed to Australia.
—Did you throw a scone on the barbie?

—I did not get to throw a scone on the barbecue, but I could have done so if I had had enough time. The trouble is that the Americans go in for pumpkin pies rather than pumpkin scones, so I did not really have the opportunity to do that. When I went to New York I said that I came from the land of the big pineapple to the city of the big apple because that is what New York is all about. I thought that all honourable senators might be interested to know that I have been doing my bit for tourism in Australia and Queensland.

SPEECH.PARA: Figures released by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development in March this year showed that Australia topped the developed countries league tables for the percentage increase of tourists and the rise of income from tourism. In 1986 we saw a substantial international tourism growth in the Australian tourist industry and a continued increase in capital development and investment. Hotel-motel accommodation capacity in Australia grew at accelerating rates during this year and employment growth for hotels and motels has been very strong over the last three years. Net inbound tourism has been the strongest component of the industry over recent years, reflecting the effects of substantial devaluation of the Australian dollar, especially against the Japanese yen and the United States dollar. In this context, campaigns promoting Australia as a travel destination have facilitated a substantial acceleration in short term overseas arrivals to Australia and a reduction in short term Australian resident departures. As a result, short term overseas visitor arrivals have exceeded resident departures since late 1986, reversing a pattern of net Australian resident short term departures that had been the norm until recent decades.

The Australian tourism industry is making a major contribution to improved economic performances through its beneficial effects on Australia's balance of payments. That is why this legislation that we are discussing today is very important. However, we all have to accept that there is a diversity of performance across different States and in particular regions. In terms of growth performance, it appears that northern and some eastern regions of Australia are recording stronger results than other parts of Australia. Of course, I suppose that I am biased, but I believe that Queensland is Australia's premier tourist State and thus makes an enormous contribution to Australia's tourist industry.

Last year tourism contributed close to $9 billion to Queensland's economy. Employment in the tourism and hospitality industries has achieved a growth rate of 130 per cent since 1979. More than 145,000 Queenslanders are employed in those industries. More than half of Australia's investment in major tourism projects, either under construction or firmly committed, is taking place in Queensland.
