When World Expo 88 is held next year Queensland certainly will be tourism-oriented. A display was held in King's Hall last week and I am sure that those senators who had a look at it had their appetites whetted to come to Queensland to see Expo. It will be a very exciting six months in Queensland. Expo, with its theme of leisure in the age of technology, was offered to Victoria by Malcolm Fraser when he was Prime Minister. That State was asked whether it would like to hold Expo for our bicentennial year in 1988. But Victoria said that it did not want it, so then it was offered to New South Wales. When New South Wales said that it thought it could not manage it, it was offered to Queensland. I believe that Queensland is a State with a vision, with a Premier who knows what is good for it and a progressive government. That government said it would take on Expo. I believe that Expo will be a significant contribution to Australia's bicentennial celebrations as it has the potential to advance trade and technological developments in our nation.

In reply to a question in the Senate recently, Senator Ryan informed me that the Commonwealth Government would contribute $20m to Expo. To date nothing like that amount has been received by the Queensland Government. Advice that I have been given from the Expo authority informs me that no Federal money has been given directly to the Expo authority. The $20m contribution that Senator Ryan mentioned the other day is for the Australian pavilion. All the other nations that are coming to Expo have to provide millions of dollars for their own pavilions. Thus, there actually has been no financial grant whatsoever to Queensland for the staging of Expo. An amount of $1.23m has been allocated for assistance to Third World countries for participation in Expo and also to give financial help to encourage other Australian States to come. I believe that the other States of Australia should have come without help from the Federal Government. They should have been willing to put in their money just as Queensland has been willing to put in its money. At least it now looks as if most of them will come. They probably think they will be left out of the party if they do not come. I believe that Expo is a significant contribution to Australia's bicentenary celebrations.

As a matter of fact, I was quite interested to read an article in one of our papers the other day which said that success for Expo 88 was assured. I was interested to note that the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Mr John Brown, said that the five State and Territory governments that had not yet agreed to take part in World Expo 88 were `crazy' if they missed their last chance. Expo now has 42 governments involved, making it the third largest special Expo ever. It is great to know that Brisbane's Expo 88-one of the expected highlights of the bicentennial year-is assured of financial success with 96 per cent of its site already booked by exhibitors and ticket sales running at seven times the expected rate. Sir Llew Edwards was talking to Cabinet last week; that is why the display was held in King's Hall. It is good to know that everything is going ahead very well.

Australia is set to see a boom in Japanese tourism with an increase of 35 per cent a year in the number of visas to come to Australia. Official figures prepared for both the Federal and Queensland governments show that an additional 100,000 Americans and 600,000 Japanese will visit Queensland by the beginning of the next decade. I listened to the Minister for the Environment and the Arts (Senator Richardson), in Question Time today, answering a dorothy dix question from Senator John Black of Queensland about the environmental park next to Mr Iwasaki's resort in central Queensland. I have been to that resort and have had a look at it for myself. When I recalled what that country looked like before Mr Iwasaki invested millions of dollars to build this beautiful resort, I wondered why he had done it because at the time nobody else really wanted it. He has put his money where his mouth is-not that I can understand his Japanese. Nevertheless he has invested a lot of money to make the most beautiful tourist resort. I recommend to honourable senators who have not been there that they see it for themselves and stay there because it really is very good. Senator Richardson, in his answer to the question, went on about how wicked it was that Queensland was going to give all these hectares to Mr Iwasaki. The whole strength of the matter is that the environmental park will be owned by the Government. All Mr Iwasaki has done is to offer to build 10 kilometres of expensive road and an expensive bridge over the Corio River so that guests staying at his resort will be able to walk through that environmental park, which will still be owned by the Government. I do not know where Senator Richardson got the information that he was giving to us in answer to that question today. Sometimes the media play things up so much that they do not really tell one the whole facts of the case. I thought that today's debate on the tourism legislation was an excellent opportunity to speak about a great tourist development in central Queensland.

The figures I have given in relation to the number of Americans and Japanese who will come to Queensland during the next decade represent about half the total for the six States and the two Territories combined. The Australian tourist industry can also expect an influx of tourists from Britain, continental Europe and Asian countries, both for World Expo 88 and for other bicentennial attractions, which will prove to be a catalyst for inbound tourism. Talking about continental tourism, it was my privilege in May this year to open a new office in Munich for the Queensland Tourist and Travel Corporation (QTTC). People might ask why the QTTC is opening an office in Munich when the Australian tourist industry office is in Frankfurt. The QTTC believes that when the new international airport is opened in Munich in the early 1990s it will be the right place for the Queensland Tourist and Travel Corporation office to be.

When I was walking down the mall in Munich I was delighted to be tapped on the shoulder by a girl who asked me whether I was Mrs Bjelke-Petersen. I answered yes, thinking that everybody over there would be speaking in German. She said, `I come from Warwick in Queensland'. So one can walk through a mall in Germany and meet a girl from Warwick. I went 20 paces further down the street and, lo and behold, I met four young people who also asked me whether I was Mrs Bjelke-Petersen. I said, `Yes. Are you from Queensland?'. They said, `No, we are from New South Wales, Victoria and New Zealand'. But they knew me. It is nice to be known by people from other places. Perhaps it says something for being a senator. Perhaps it says even more for being the wife of a man who has been Premier of Queensland for almost 20 years.

Tourism is clearly the growth industry of the next decade and will provide job opportunities for many thousands of people, security for families and overall economic prosperity for decades to come. It is timely, therefore, that this restructuring of the Australian Tourist Commission has been proposed to increase the number of visitors to Australia from overseas and to maximise the benefits to Australia from overseas visitors. I am certainly very happy today to support the amendments that are to be moved by the Opposition to the Australian Tourist Commission Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon the Senate is continuing discussion on the Australian Tourist Commission Bill 1987 and the Australian Tourist Commission (Transitional Provisions) Bill 1987. I have a number of concerns, although not with the principal Bill. It is a very good Bill, long-awaited and much needed. I have general concerns about the whole area of tourism that bother me, which I will come to later in my speech. I want to address some comments made by the previous speakers from the other side of the chamber, but before doing so, I quote the functions of the Commission, as set out in clause 7:

SPEECH.PARA: 7. The functions of the Commission are:
(a) to promote Australia overseas as a tourist destination;
(b) to enhance awareness overseas of Australia as a tourist destination;
(c) to co-ordinate the overseas promotional efforts of the Australian tourism industry, in co-operation with State and Territory tourism authorities and with the Australian tourism industry; and
(d) to enhance awareness in Australia of the Australian tourism industry.

I have heard most speakers in this debate. A number of Opposition speakers have not read, or if they have read they have not understood, what the functions of the Commission are. I know that some licence is given in debates such as this to range far and wide but it has gone a wee bit too far. I am not going to go through the Bill addressing it clause by clause. Quite enough has been said. As we all know and as we have all been told innumerable times, the Bill is the result of the Australian Government Inquiry into Tourism established under the chairmanship of Mr Jim Kennedy. The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mr John Brown) established the inquiry to consider an Act of Parliament that had been in existence for 20 years. This Bill will bring this dynamic industry and the Commission up to date. As I said in my opening remarks, the Bill has been long awaited.

The Kennedy committee of inquiry did not make its recommendations in isolation. Its consultation ranged far and wide throughout the community and all States. A number of interested parties made representations directly to the inquiry. In turn, the Government, upon receipt of the report from Mr Kennedy, considered it in great detail before finally bringing the Bill down. One of the most important recommendations the Bill has taken up is the question of State representation on the Commission. Most of the speakers I have heard in this debate have disagreed with the recommendation of the inquiry and the provision in the Bill that the States cease to have direct rotational representation on the Commission. I think this is a very good thing because, as we have witnessed in this chamber during debate on this Bill, there is a great deal of State rivalry.

One could imagine what would happen if a commission had representation from three States, with three States locked out and not represented at all. Obviously, the debate would weigh in favour of those States which had direct representation. Like Senator Newman, I think it was, I am not in favour of large boards. The smaller the better-the more business one can get done and the less waffle one will have to endure if one is a member of the board. To have given each of the States direct representation would have made the Commission far too large and unwieldy. So the Government has taken up the recommendation of the Committee and done away with direct State representation. In the long term interests of this very dynamic industry that is a very good thing and the Government and the Minister, in particular, have to be commended for it.

Another thing which Opposition speakers have made a great line about in the debate is the matter of industry representation. Again, I think there is a lack of understanding by honourable senators opposite as to what the Bill is about. The Minister's second reading speech is enough to set the record straight on what the Government is about in putting forward this Bill in its present form:

Accordingly, and in line with the report's recommendations endorsed by the Government, the Bill provides for the Board members to be appointed by virtue of their individual skills, expertise and experience relevant to the tourism industry, rather than as representatives of associations, States, Territories or other bodies which may have particular tourism interests. It is also envisaged that a Board appointee will have extensive commercial experience at a senior level, and have a demonstrated track record of successful management.

To meet that criterion one would have to come directly from the industry and have had an association with the industry over a period of time. One does not get to senior level of management without some necessary qualifications and experience. Hopefully, that argument can now be put to rest.

I want to respond to a couple of other things. I was not surprised when Senator Puplick used this debate the other night to have another crack at the wages of workers, and in particular the penalty rates paid to workers in this industry. Senator Puplick and the rest of us senators in this place work weird hours. Unfortunately, the hours that we work are not recognised and we are not paid for them. I think somebody mentioned today that politicians get about $4.50 an hour. But many people who work in the tourism industry actually get less than that. They can make up their wages by being rostered on duty at weird and unusual hours-by working through the night, by starting very early in the morning or by finishing late at night-and having their social lives completely and utterly disrupted. That is compensated for by virtue of payment of penalty rates. Of course, many people in the industry do not even get penalty rates, despite the weird and wonderful hours that they work, because a vast number of them are on casual rates and do not have a permanent job.

People really need to look into this matter before they make bland statements about overpayments in the industry. It did not surprise me that that came from Senator Puplick, but I was surprised when the Australian Democrats jumped on the band-wagon. The other night Senator Jenkins also mentioned that this was `an aspect that would need to be examined'. One expects such statements from the conservative side of politics, but it is a little bit too much from the people who pretend, or at least used to pretend, to be the conscience of the political system in this country. I am not really surprised that this was said because we have from time to time witnessed the Democrats saying one thing and voting the opposite way. That comment could come from a member of the Opposition benches just as easily as from us. But I hope that when the Democrats pontificate in the community they will in turn openly admit that they are joining with the conservative forces in this country in attacking the wages and conditions of workers in this industry.

The tourism industry is a dynamic industry and a growth industry. It is a very important industry. It is estimated that some 400,000 people are employed in the industry. It is also estimated that overseas visitors bring in some $2.5 billion. Not all, but a lot of the effort in this area can be attributed to the responsible Minister, John Brown. John Brown is a shy, retiring individual who is not given to boasting and bragging about his achievements. But we have to be humble enough to recognise that we have on our side of the Parliament a brilliant individual, and we are lucky to have him promoted into the best Cabinet and the best Ministry that this nation has ever seen. I pay a personal tribute to Mr Brown in saying that.

It has been alleged on a number of occasions that the honourable member for Parramatta, John Brown, is claiming all the credit for the growth and the dynamism of the Australian tourism industry. That is not true; it really is not true. If people want to refute what I am saying, I refer them to what Mr Brown said in the debate in the other place on 7 May and they can see for themselves what he said. Mr Brown has been criticised for not directly putting industry representation on the Board. A certain individual has been named in this. John Brown, like everybody else, has his detractors. His detractors mainly come dressed in fancy dress, in white shoes and probably safari suits. They serve an interest. John Brown serves Australia. `Brownie' is willing and able to listen to his detractors and move on.

Talking about moving on, it is probably about time that I moved on to speak about the matter that I particularly want to talk about in this debate. I am motivated to do this because of the amendments put forward by the Australian Democrats. Although I have not had a chance to talk to the Minister for the Environment and the Arts (Senator Richardson), who is at the table, I hope that he will look favourably on these amendments because they are very important. A couple of weeks ago I was lucky enough to visit the Bungle Bungle region in the Kimberley in Western Australia and to see for myself one area of immense beauty. I am not going to stand here and claim that Western Australia is a more beautiful State than any other State in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —But it is.

—I do not disagree with Senator Knowles, but I am not going to claim that. If we are talking about the most beautiful country in the world, we could probably get into a disagreement. I heard our Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) say words about a certain European nation that he visited recently. I did not disagree with him. But I do not think we need to argue about the States. It is Australia, the nation, that is important. The Bungle Bungle region of Western Australia is of particular beauty. It is a rediscovered area of mountain ranges in the north-west of Western Australia. It is extremely rugged terrain made up of many high ridges, deep gullies and stratified rocks. It is reputed to be over 350 million years old and it covers 270 square miles. It has been rediscovered and, unfortunately, it is currently being visited by tourists-not always by tourists who have an interest in the environment, an interest in protecting the environment they are looking at, an interest in preserving it for the future generations.

SPEECH.PARA: Even though it is a very rugged and very isolated area, and only a small number of people have been to it, a lot of damage and desecration has been done. It is an area that needs to be protected, and protected very soon. In my short visit to the Bungle Bungle region I witnessed a number of acts of desecration, not the least of which was the disturbance of an Aboriginal burial site that had been used for countless generations, one would assume. All that remained in that burial site was one human bone; the rest had been souvenired away. It makes one wonder what the human race is like when people can visit an area to see its beauty and walk away with the remains of a fellow human being as a souvenir.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope you didn't leave any cigarette butts up there, Senator.

—I tried not to. The Western Australian Government, in particular, has to act quickly. It has to act in the interests of the nation because Bungle Bungle does not belong only to Western Australia; Bungle Bungle belongs to Australia as a whole, to the people of Australia and to the world. It is an area from which we can benefit. If a proper management plan is implemented after a detailed study of the area, this area could perhaps in years to come rival some of the areas which Senator Collins talked about this afternoon, such as Ayers Rock, the Olgas and so on. But this needs to happen reasonably quickly.

SPEECH.PARA: While I was there on my very short visit, I noticed another piece of desecration-done by a government department, the Department of Conservation and Land Management of the Western Australian Government. We were met by a ranger who just happened to be in the area at the same time as the Federal Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand). The park ranger is not stationed there on a permanent basis, but he knew that the Minister was coming. He was waiting for a fencing contractor. Apparently, a bulldozer had been put through an area without any consultation with the local people and a fence was being put up to stop cattle roaming through the area, which would not do a great deal for tourism. We need tourism, but it cannot be at any price. We have to protect what we have and preserve it for future generations.

To change the subject somewhat, Senator Collins used a one-track argument when he talked about a concept for which he recently received a little publicity-a monorail, a single-track railway, or a `people mover' as other people have called it. During the debate earlier today I was reminded also of some pending Government action which might be detrimental to the tourist industry. Of course, that action is the recent decision by Caucus to ban smoking on internal air flights. I was just wondering whether our Government would look to putting on a single-track people mover from Canberra to Perth to cater for smokers who will not be able to travel on the smoke-free aeroplane. Such a mode of transport would probably do more damage to human beings and to the environment than anything else, including smoking. Perhaps that is something that can be done in the future.

The final point that I want to make before I sit down is a point that puzzles me somewhat. Recently I had cause to return to Ireland and visit two towns that are less than 10 miles from the border that separates that nation. Everyone here would know about Ireland because we get constant news about it stating that it is an area of great trouble, violence, gunfire and so forth. I am not refuting that; it is a sorry nation. I wish that it were not so, but it is. The forces of law and order are present and members of the police force, even in those troubled areas, do not walk around with guns on their hips. I find it amazing that whatever State capital one goes into in a peaceful country such as Australia, one finds members of the police force, even though they are only on point duty, with guns on their hips. It often makes me wonder what overseas visitors think about our nation when they see this happening. They must wonder what kind of society we live in. I know that it is a matter for State governments to look at rather than the Federal Government. But it must be something of concern because I have visited, and I have heard evidence from, so-called police states overseas and I do not believe that this is the practice in those states. It is something of concern to me which probably needs to be looked at, and we might get opinions from overseas visitors.

In conclusion, I commend the Bills to the House. A number of furphies have been raised in the debate so far. I hope that people will read my comments about the Bungle Bungle region, take them with the sincerity in which they were given and establish a framework for consultation and co-operation to protect this one small area of a very vast and beautiful nation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-A great many points were raised in the speeches that were made during the second reading debate on the Australian Tourist Commission Bill and the Australian Tourist Commission (Transitional Provisions) Bill. I will try to cover as many of the points as I can. I wish to begin, not where the second reading debate began, but with Senator Collins's question concerning the monorail from Ayers Rock to the Olgas because my office has been deluged with phone calls about my response to the proposal, if that is what it can be called. I would like to begin by answering all those calls in a few words here.

SPEECH.PARA: The first thing to note is that no one is studying a proposal for a monorail, a people mover, a railway, or anything else, from Ayers Rock to the Olgas. An idea has been floated, loudly and considerably, during the course of today. As a result, I think people have jumped to a number of conclusions which they probably ought not to have done. As I have said, the reality is that there is an idea and a number of people in the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service have believed in this for some time. The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mr John Brown), having had a tour of the area, has given his views on it, and that is fine. There have been a great many problems with the road, as a number of people have spelt out today, here and in another place. It is true to say that the road is dangerous, difficult to maintain and it would be extraordinarily costly to do anything about it. In any event, funds are not available for that purpose at this time. So any alternative that would make the lives of tourists safer ought to be examined.

I do not criticise anyone for doing that. I just point out that there are three prerequisites for a proper examination of this idea. The first pre- requisite is that there be an actual proposal-there is not one yet; the second prerequisite is that if there were we would need to have a proper environmental assessment under the legislation; and the third prerequisite is that we would need the agreement of the Uluru Board of Management. Given that none of those three is in place at the moment I see no reason to get myself too excited about it. It will not happen on Friday afternoon. I suspect that it will be a long time before any of those three prerequisites needs to be examined. So on that basis I propose to say no more.

Before getting on to the substantive matters that were raised during the debate, I would like to make one other comment concerning Senator McGauran's reference to me and a number of other people-and I think I am quoting him correctly-as `slick nouveau'. I think it is true to say that the old country money of Victoria has been looking through somewhat jaundiced eyes during the last couple of decades as power has slipped from its fingers. One Victorian grazier managed to reverse that trend for a time. However, I think it is true to say that, for most of them, the trend they have been witnessing for the last few decades will continue in the next few, and thank God for it. I am not even sure what a `slick nouveau' is. If the suggestion is that it is nouveau riche I hardly qualify. I may have been invited to the party but I think I was one of the few people there who were not millionaires. I would hardly call myself slick. All I can say is that it was a great party, John Farnham was fantastic and the only disappointment I have is that my memento of the occasion, the cufflinks that were presented, were knocked off by a party or parties unknown. Whether that was a guest or a member of the staff has never been established to my satisfaction. Unfortunately, that has somewhat coloured my memory of an otherwise great event.

TALK.START.PARA: —Was that a plug for a new set of cufflinks?

—I fear that the lapse of time between the party and now means that my cufflinks have gone forever. I am reminded, though, that one person at the party, upon receiving the gift, took the cufflinks out of the bag and replaced them with his old cufflinks. No doubt the person who purloined mine also purloined those but I am sure that he was disappointed when he opened the package.

SPEECH.PARA: I should turn now to more substantive matters. The first one that I would like to raise, given that it was common to a number, if not all, of the speeches today, concerns the move of the Australian Tourist Commission (ATC) office from Melbourne to Sydney. I have noted a great many comments about it. It should be noted, firstly, that the ATC's own submission to the Kennedy Inquiry into Australian Tourism argued for the retention of Melbourne as the head office, but also argued for the strengthening of the Sydney office. In its submission to the inquiry it referred to the `need to service journalists, publicists and members of the travel trade who, by virtue of Sydney's position as the major international gateway, tend to land there first'. The maintenance of two offices was obviously expensive. One can understand why that cannot continue forever if we are trying to rationalise operations. A number of submissions to the inquiry raised the issue of the head office location and the confusion associated with having the two offices. A close assessment of the Commission's activities confirms that there were a number of advantages in consolidating the two offices. Without going into an exhaustive list, let me make a few obvious points. The Australian headquarters of virtually all international airlines are in Sydney. Qantas Airways Ltd has its headquarters in Sydney, a high percentage of key inbound tour operators' headquarters are in Sydney, the headquarters of most advertising agencies naturally enough are in Sydney, a high percentage of international tourist industry executives with whom the Tourist Commission has to deal are in Sydney, and a high percentage of Australia's industry meetings take place in Sydney. So moving to Sydney not only would combine efficiency and rationalise operations by putting two offices into one; it must over time save the Government money by bringing the office to the industry rather than, as too often happened in the past, making the industry go to it or flying people up from Melbourne to go to the industry. While we can look upon this as a once only cost, the reality is that, even in communication costs alone, we are looking at an immediate saving of $250,000 a year, according to the Commission's estimates, and those savings can only grow. The costs for relocation this year are: salaries and related expenses, including termination payments, $1,486,000; administrative and operational expenses, that is the physical costs of moving, $1,797,000, including some $60,000 to close the small Sydney office.

The reference to four staff moving to Sydney is misleading. It is not unusual, when an office moves from one city to another, that not all of the staff want to go. Obviously the change from Melbourne to Sydney is a big one. Personally, I cannot understand why anyone who lived in Melbourne would not jump at the opportunity to move to Sydney! Nonetheless, there are people in that category, and this exercise has demonstrated that there are quite a few. A substantial number, 20, of the Australian Tourist Commission staff have remained with the organisation. Some of these were already in Sydney and some were overseas. So the reasons people did not move from Melbourne were personal and were not related to the operation of the Commission itself. Further, some of those people were nearing retirement, and they have now been replaced by younger and more aggressive staff. We all hope that the Commission, or Tourism Australia, can now go on from strength to strength.

One other point raised concerned the immigration service charge. I do not wish to say much about it, but I hardly think it will be a great dampener on tourism in Australia. The United States of America already has in operation both a Customs service fee and an immigration inspection fee of $US5 each. I have not looked at the market today so I do not know exactly what that is in Australian dollars, but it certainly is more than $A10; it is probably about $A12 or $A13. As I said, I am not certain of today's events-and these are, as people say, uncertain times. The fee is consistent with the cost recovery principles that have been adopted by the Government, and given that it was after all the Fraser Government that introduced the $10 departure tax in one year, and then the next year dropped in, not so casually, a 100 per cent increase to $20, it is hardly a responsible move for those opposite to complain.

We also had a great deal of comment on the ending of the tourism overseas promotion scheme (TOPS). We have seen quite a bit of drama in the chamber over that, I think drama not shared by a great many people in the industry. I wish to go through a few points on both the history of the scheme and the impact of the Government's decision so that we can all work out where we are. The scheme began in May 1985, when $5m was allocated to it. It was subsequently reduced to $3m, and in any event less than $2m was expended. Four million dollars in notional approvals was carried forward for payment in 1986-87. The low rate of expenditure was due to the time taken for operators to become familiar with this scheme. In 1986-87, $5m was appropriated, all of which was expended. Six million dollars in potential claims was carried forward to 1987-88, although applications with a notional value of $14m had been processed but not approved. TOPS guidelines state that an application is not valid until the Minister has specifically approved it. Approvals are based on 70 per cent of funds expended on legitimate promotional activities after meeting an annual $5,000 threshold.

In August 1986 the Minister had to cease approvals after he had reached the limit of the funds available for that year. A forward obligation of $4m was approved in October 1986. Some operators had carried out promotions during the interregnum. When forward commitments were available these were approved retrospectively. So approvals continued until February 1987, when that level of forward obligation had been committed, and approvals again ceased. In June 1987, $9m was agreed to as an allocation for 1987-88, and a further $2m of applications were approved on 29 June. In the Budget it was announced that the scheme would close but that all applications approved, totalling $6m, would be paid; that the $3m left out of the $9m allocated would go to the Australian Tourist Commission for co-operative programs.

Obviously the scheme had been popular with operators. Its introduction coincided with the boom, and no doubt helped to keep it going. It is impossible to assess specifically what the effect of the scheme was. Information from operators is that they will have to curtail some of their overseas activities, but with increased funding Tourism Australia no doubt can take them over. This scheme's open-ended nature meant that the cost to government could have gone anywhere. No responsible government could have allowed that to continue, and therefore the decision taken by the Government this year was, in my view, appropriate. Those operators who were prepared to spend money without approval, given the specific nature of the wording requiring ministerial approval, will have to accept the risk.

Senator Puplick raised a number of matters about tourism training which I would like to cover. Far from ignoring the wide-ranging recommendations contained in the reports of the Tourism Training Review Group and the 1986 Sprokkreeff Committee released earlier this year, the Minister personally, and the Government generally, have initiated a series of actions to deal with the complex issues involved. The progress in implementing the 1985 report recommendations was evaluated by the Sprokkreeff Committee and is acknowledged in its report. The extent of increased public and private sector support for industry training merits recognition more widely. I want to go through some examples, giving some specifics and some statistics. Annual Commonwealth allocations to the National Tourism Industry Training Committee (NTITC) have been more than doubled since 1983-84 to $1.2m in 1987-88, while industry contributions have increased to around 40 per cent of the Committee's budget; and $71m has been spent since 1982 on tourism training facilities in technical and further education colleges providing 3,000 extra places. A further 14 facilities are proposed for construction in the next triennium. Seven projects will be funded in 1988, including $7.7m allocated for the Australian Capital Territory School of Hotel and Catering Management. Largely as a result of ministerial representations following the release of both reports, the Commonwealth Government has accorded the tourism and hospitality sectors higher priority in resource allocations. Total expenditure on the industry through labour market programs, Commonwealth Employment Service (CES) placement services, capital funding and educational assistance was estimated at over $70m in 1986-87. Tourism and hospitality have been further recognised in the 1987-88 Budget as one of the key areas of shortfall where additional resources are to be allocated for education and training to generate the skills required to cater for industry growth.

The Commonwealth has also taken action to streamline procedures for recruitment of trained staff. The CES hospitality service has been very effective in securing specialised staff placements, particularly for major new developments and major events. Immigration procedures for temporary entry of skilled staff are being facilitated to help reduce current shortages while maintaining employer commitment to training. Many of the report's recommendations on policy issues related to training, however, involve the responsibilities of State authorities and a range of government and industry organisations. Accreditation and industry recognition of courses is being extended, and the results of NTITC research are being applied to establish career paths and minimum national standards in core curricula. The development of core curricula in hospitality, travel and tourism courses is well advanced at tertiary institutions. I mention also the establishment of a chair of tourism at James Cook University, the proposed development of a national centre for tourism and hospitality studies in the Australian Capital Territory and the introduction of short training courses and videos in the Japanese language and culture.

Most significantly, at the national level, Mr Brown has initiated action in a number of areas within the Federal tourism portfolio to implement major recommendations of the reports. These cover the undertaking of a labour force survey in conjunction with the NTITC and the new Bureau of Tourism Research; the extension of the national tourism awards to encourage excellence in training within both the government and industry; and support for closer industry-education co-operation in tourism studies in the school system and in tertiary institutions. A resolution of the Tourist Ministers Council urging a higher priority for tourism training has been conveyed to the Australian Education Council. I mention also developments in training and education in the Australian Capital Territory which will serve as a model for the rest of Australia, the extension of the national tourism awareness campaign and an increased focus on training and career awareness. All of that should surely prove not only the Government's commitment but also that the Government has lived up to that commitment. It is determined to maintain and raise the standards of the industry and also to increase the standard of skills of its work force. I would suggest that no Minister could have done more.

Having said that, I wish to deal with a number of things that were said about the Minister, because the Minister seemed to come in for quite a deal of comment from a number of Opposition senators, including, of course, Senator Puplick. No mean carrier of a bucket is Senator Puplick! We have seen him in action before. Today we heard him again, rivalling Rex Jackson as the person to hold the title of `Buckets'. Looking at the role of John Brown I can say only that, having listened to Senator McGauran, Senator Puplick and Senator Newman, there has been the venting of a great amount of spleen-the spleen, of course, that comes from envy; the envy of the powerless for someone who is in a position to do something. John Brown has shown extraordinary leadership for tourism in Australia and he has a record to be envied. That envy was obvious during this debate.

In 1983 tourism was not regarded as a serious industry in this country. In 1987-88 tourism is taking its place as one of Australia's great industries, and the growth rates that have been achieved in Australia have been achieved nowhere else in the world. Much of that can be put down to the extraordinary efforts of John Brown. I want to go through some of John Brown's record and compare it with that of the Fraser Government. Honourable senators opposite may have some memories of what that government did for tourism but I want to make sure that they have a really good memory of just what it did. Let us go through the record of John Brown and the Government in the last few years. Tourism is now universally regarded as one of Australia's major industries, contributing 6 per cent to gross domestic product and providing jobs for 6 per cent of the work force. Seventy thousand jobs have been created in tourism alone since this Government came to office. A further 25,000 will be created through this year and to the end of 1988 as a result of the continuing increase in tourism growth. When we came to office, the net value of the tourism industry was some $8 billion. It is now conservatively estimated at $24 billion. International visitor arrivals have increased from just under 1,000,000 when we came to office to an expected 2.2 million in 1988.

It was claimed by Senator Puplick and a number of others that this can all be put down to a drop in the Australian dollar. That apparently is not the view of American tourists who visit this country. A recent United States communication research survey done by HBH-Creamer has indicated that some two-thirds of American tourists said they did not know about and were not influenced by the fall in the dollar in their coming to Australia. Only a third of them believed that it was any factor at all. No matter what the value of the currency is, tourists will not come to a country unless they have heard about it and heard about it favourably-and that is what John Brown has been responsible for during the last four years. He has done a magnificent job.

The value of the remarkable increase in funding for the ATC under John Brown should not be forgotten. It has more than trebled and is now more than $30 million. There has been an enormous increase in major tourism plant with the value of plant under construction at over $10 billion and with $8 billion worth of plant already at an advanced stage of planning. John Brown can personally take credit for launching the Hogan campaign. He was the one who was searching for that idea in the first place. One would be flat out remembering who in the Fraser Government was ever a Minister responsible for tourism. For all those honourable senators opposite who wish to complain, let me go through some figures for the Fraser Government. The Fraser Government increased Tourist Commission funds from $7 1/2m to $10m in seven years-that was that Government's record-and decreased its staff from 140 to 75. Those were the Fraser Government's priorities. In contrast, this Government, with John Brown leading the way, increased funds from $10m to $30m in three years and we are giving it an additional $6m this financial year. That is some contrast, but it does not end there.

Let us look further at just how much the Fraser Government-and many honourable senators opposite-cared when they had a real say. That Government introduced a 20 per cent sales tax on tourist boats in August 1980-and it stopped the industry stone dead. It was over, finished. When this Government came to office there just was not a tourist boat industry any more. Under John Howard it was gone. As a result of what this Government did-which was simply to take off the sales tax and retrospectively return the money to those from whom it had been purloined in the previous few years-the industry is undergoing a construction boom in Australia and, I might say for the benefit of Senator Bjelke-Petersen, particularly in Queensland. That is something for which the honourable senator has a Labor government to thank. I only hope that in the honourable senator's next contribution to this debate she will acknowledge what we have done-in contrast to those nasty Liberals who picked on the Nationals again and in their own peculiar style managed to hurt a Queensland industry. It was a shame.

If we need any further proof of what the Fraser Government did for tourism in Australia we ought to look at what American travel writers think. They usually have a fair idea of these things. They were around during the years of the Fraser Government. They never came to Australia; not many Americans did either. No one had heard of it; no one cared. Last week more than 400 American travel writers gathered at a conference in Melbourne. John Brown addressed that conference and, when their president go up to thank him, all he could say was: `What we really want to hear from you, Minister, is: how have you done it? The world cannot believe the transformation'. They are the words of their president.

Let us look at the position of tourist developers. They were given a 4 per cent depreciation allowance, which is now down to 2.5 per cent. Negative gearing has been restored. The Government has allowed a 5:3 ratio for depreciation on the construction of lift wells and air-conditioning. These things have been done for that industry and no one on the other side could ever have dreamed of them. In order to consider what would have happened if honourable senators opposite had come to government, of course, we should really remember what they were about. They were going to demolish the industry. They were going to abolish the whole tourism department. Tourism would have gone back to where it was under the Fraser Government-in a nowhere land. That is something that this Government and John Brown will never allow to happen.

I know Senator Stone is not here at the moment, but as far back as 1973-he might not remember back that far but a few of us do-he signed a report that recommended a reduction in the Tourist Commission dollars and its imminent abolition. Fortunately, the government of the day was more enlightened, and today's Government is more enlightened still. It should be remembered that the Opposition pledged a $1.2 billion cut in industry support during the last election campaign. By the way, there is no doubt, that, for all the bleatings about TOPS, there is no way it would have survived at all under a Howard Government. The hypocrisy involved in Senator Puplick and others getting up and criticising this Government's decision is extraordinary. I know he is a wet and does not always agree with dry decisions. But, nonetheless, he had a say. He was the member of a party and he went along with the policy. I have not read anything in which, during the election campaign, he criticised the abolition of the then Department of Sport, Recreation and Tourism. Perhaps he can produce a sheaf of papers and Press releases to show that I am wrong, but I will bet that he cannot. The reality is that this Government has built the tourism industry from nothing into one of Australia's great industries, and John Brown will continue that process.

In my last few words perhaps I should correct something else that Senator McGauran said, as he is now in the chamber. He foully libelled Sir Peter Abeles when he claimed that one reason for moving the Tourist Commission was so that it could be put in a building owned by Sir Peter Abeles. I have to inform the honourable senator that he does not own the building or have a share in the building. So I think the honourable senator should go back to school-obviously he missed out-and I look forward to seeing tomorrow his apology to Sir Peter Abeles for making not only an ill-advised statement but also a pretty poor effort in treating a citizen who must read the statement with surprise and disgust, as I am sure it will be greeted by all fair-minded Australians. Senator Bjelke-Petersen has also walked into the chamber. I heard some of her contribution earlier. I know that she is very concerned about Mr Iwasaki. I am told that the development is magnificent. That is something I have never disputed. However, I dispute the need to give him another 20,000 acres of national park.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are not giving it to him.
—I know that the National Party cannot win in Cabinet in Queensland any more, but it is worth noting that the proposals have been opposed bitterly by such people as Minister Muntz--
—They don't understand.

—He does not understand? That is interesting; I will inform him of the honourable senator's comment. All I can say, having read his comments in the paper, is that he thinks the Premier of Queensland does not understand. That is now the opinion of the majority of Australians and the majority of Queenslanders, not to mention a majority in his Cabinet and his Party.
