PROCTEXT.PARA: AUSTRALIAN TOURIST COMMISSION BILL 1987
Clauses 1 to 5-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 6 (Principal objects of Commission).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 2, after paragraph 6 (b), add the following word and paragraph:
``; and (c) to ensure that Australia is protected from adverse environmental and social impacts of international tourism.''.

The Australian Tourist Commission already has two principal objects. The first-the whole point of the Australian Tourist Commission Bill-is to increase the number of visitors to Australia from overseas. As a tourist commission Bill, that is what the Bill is about. The second offers to the people of Australia protection to maximise the benefits to Australia from overseas visitors so that people gain something. Paragraph (c) follows on. At the same time we want to ensure that what we are offering to our increased number of visitors from overseas continues and is not destroyed. In other words, as a number of honourable senators have said during the debate, what people from overseas mostly want to see is the landscape and the beauties of Australia which in many cases are unique. Although tourists want to come here to view our landscape, it is unfortunate that they do not always respect them. One hears of people scribbling on Ayers Rock, leaving their autographs in heritage buildings and taking a little piece of this and that home with them. It is for this reason that I have moved this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition is not minded to support this amendment because, quite simply, we do not believe that the Australian Tourist Commission is the appropriate body to undertake what is a very serious responsibility as far as the Australian environment is concerned. Detailed in the publication of the Australian Heritage Commission entitled Tourists and the national estate: procedures to protect Australia's heritage are a number of recommendations about the sorts of attitudes and policies which should be put in place by those authorities which are primarily responsible for the protection of the natural environment from the man-made environment as it may be impacted by tourists.

SPEECH.PARA: It seems to us that that responsibility lies primarily with the authorities which are the custodians of the site or building in question or the respective management authorities of the natural areas which are potentially at risk from tourist activities and other forms of human degradation of the pristine values concerned. Therefore, because we do not see this as being the role of the Commission per se, we will not support the amendment. I rise simply to make the point that the objective of the amendment which Senator Jenkins has moved is a very important objective and one which we believe ought to be pursued. It is simply our view that the Tourist Commission is not the appropriate body to undertake it.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government accepts the amendment from Senator Jenkins. I would be the last to oppose any additional environmental protection. The relevant authorities are encouraged to abide by the regulations of the Australian Heritage Commission and I do not see that any extra encouragement could do any harm.

—In that case, I ask the Minister what steps he proposes to take to ensure that Australia is `protected' from adverse environmental and social impacts of international tourism. Why does the Minister restrict this to international tourism when the greatest amount of damage which is done is done by domestic tourism? What does he intend to do positively to give the Australian Tourist Commission, firstly, the authority and, secondly, the resources to protect the environment? Will he indicate to the Committee the legal authority which the Australian Tourist Commission will have that will allow it to protect the environment and to protect Australian society from alleged deleterious social impacts of international tourism? Will he also explain to us why it is that only international tourists, and not domestic tourists, are to be picked on in this regard? Will he provide us with an explanation of why the acceptance of this meaningless amendment is anything more than the sort of unintelligent tokenism for which this Minister is becoming extraordinarily distinguished?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Puplick for his attempt at civility. I have looked at the words and, as I said earlier, I would be the last to oppose any additional attempt to ensure that our environment is looked after. Surely that is not only what I am here for but also, one would hope, what we are all here for. As far as why we are picking-I think those were the honourable senator's words-on international tourists, it is a little difficult to pick on anyone else in a Bill that deals with international tourism. I would hope that the new body, as constituted under the Australian Tourist Commission Bill, would be able, through its promotional campaigns, to ensure that our environment is protected and that international visitors are made aware of all of the wonders of our environment and what they can do to protect it. I would not see this as being in any way a problem. I am sure it is something the new Commission will be delighted to take on.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clause 7 (Functions of Commission).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Page 2, after paragraph 7 (d), add the following new paragraph:
``(e) to closely monitor and report the effects of international tourism on Australia's natural environment and society.''.

The functions outlined in clause 7 are obviously designed to promote Australia as a tourist destination, to enhance the awareness of that and to co-ordinate the necessary promotions. The function given at paragraph (d) is `to enhance awareness in Australia of the Australian tourism industry'. I consider that the further function in the suggested new paragraph (e) is necessary to ensure that all the previous functions given in clause 7 do not result in destroying our natural environment or the framework of our society as it exists at present. Therefore, I consider that the Commission will also need to undertake a monitoring and reporting role of the effects of international tourism on our natural environment and society.
Amendment agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clause 8 (Powers of Commission).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (3) Page 2, paragraph 8 (1) (b), leave out ``the'' (first occurring), insert ``sensitive, environmentally and socially sound''.
I have moved this amendment for the reasons that I have previously stated.

TALK.START.PARA: —Once again, the Opposition considers that this is an absolute nonsense of an amendment. The legislation is designed primarily to withdraw the Australian Tourist Commission from day to day involvement in domestic tourist operations, and to change its focus to primarily one of dealing with the international promotion of Australia in terms of the recognition of Australia and the promotion of Australia as a tourist destination. This amendment requires the Commission to perform certain functions. The preamble to clause 8 provides that the Commission shall have power to do `all things necessary or convenient to be done', and then various functions are listed. With this amendment they would include providing information and advice to assist the `sensitive, environmentally and socially sound' development of the Australian tourist industry. I am at some considerable loss to know exactly what the `sensitive' development of the Australian tourist industry involves. As to what is `socially sound', again, I am at a considerable loss to understand that term of legislative draftsmanship. I do not know whether the Government will accept this amendment, but if the Minister intends to accept it, I would be grateful for some explanation of it. I am fascinated beyond belief as to what are Senator Richardson's definitions of the terms `sensitive' and `socially sound'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not brought in the Oxford Dictionary this afternoon; nonetheless, I hope that we would all be about not promoting insensitive or environmentally and socially unsound development of the Australian tourism industry. So, I do not see any problem arising from accepting the wording involved. One notes that there are all sorts of amendments and all sorts of words used. In relation to Senator Puplick's own draftsmanship, he speaks of `normal private enterprise terms and conditions'. One wonders what they are. I will be fascinated to hear details of that from the honourable senator later. But I can see no problem with the wording of the amendment and nor can I see any problem from the Commission in relation to this.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clauses 9 to 12-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clauses 13 and 14-by leave-taken together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (4) Page 4, after subclause 13 (2), insert the following new subclause:
``(2a) At least one of the persons appointed as a member by the Minister shall be a person who has environmental or sociological expertise relevant to the tourism industry.''.

This amendment is in accord with the previous amendments. There is no reason why one of the nine board members-and it has already been established that people on the board should be involved with the tourism industry-should not also have knowledge of and a sensitivity towards environmental and sociological aspects of tourism. I see this person as having the responsibility of liaising with the various environmental agencies which need to be involved in relation to development that may involve tourism, and I refer to developments that might involve putting up facilities for tourists. Liaison in this matter would be very sensitive and also very necessary: sometimes the requirements of people involved in tourism are not the same as the requirements of those involved in protection of the environment. So, a very special kind of person needs to be involved in that sort of liaison. There is no reason why such a person should not be included on the board.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take it from the Minister's indication that the Government is of the mind to accept this amendment. I simply record once again that I think this is really getting to the stage of making an absolute nonsense of the procedures of appointment of members to the Australian Tourist Commission board. The Opposition understands clearly the arrangements which have been arrived at between the Minister and the Australian Democrats: I simply indicate that we regard this proposal as simply reducing the status of the measure to an absolute farce. I formally record that we are opposed to this amendment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have to say that I am enthusiastic about supporting this amendment. I am delighted that my colleague the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mr John Brown) is also happy with it. I would have thought that to ensure that the membership of the Commission had among its numbers a person with the sort of expertise referred to in Senator Jenkins's amendment would be essential. This would certainly be welcomed by all those people in the environment groups around the country who are concerned about the tourism industry and its direction. I know it would certainly be appreciated also by many people in the industry itself who are concerned about where the environment groups stand on so many issues. I would have thought it would have been a logical way of resolving some problems, and the Government is more than happy to accept it.

—I wonder whether we can be told in what manner the Minister intends to inform himself about who is environmentally or sociologically an expert in relation to the tourist industry. If we are to make changes in that area it would be interesting to know how the Minister will choose such people.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would have thought that the Minister would, before he appointed anyone, look pretty carefully at the curriculum vitae of the candidates and make sure that they did have such expertise. If he is not sure at that point, perhaps he can interview an applicant himself and make himself certain. I would not have thought it terribly difficult to find the sort of person referred to in this amendment, and not very hard to verify such a person's qualifications.
—That may be so, but where does the Minister get the curriculum vitae from in the first place? Where does he get the people to consider?

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —From my experience, a number of people are pretty keen to serve on such bodies. Normally the Government does not have to scour the countryside to make appointments. One often finds that people do wish to have greatness thrust upon them and in doing so they tend to extol their virtues to the Minister who has the power of appointment. So I do not think there will be any problem in that respect. One could imagine that a number of people in the industry now would more than qualify on either or both of the criteria outlined, and it would not be beyond the capacity of the Minister to approach them and see whether they are prepared to serve.

—It strikes me that during debate on these amendments Opposition senators seem to be at somewhat of a loss-perhaps it comes from their experience-to understand that there are in fact people in the tourism industry who are environmentally and socially sensitive. I am motivated particularly by the fact that one such person has been designated a national treasure by this nation. His name is Mr Wilf Reichelt, who lives in Nhill, the town in which I was born. He has developed an enormously successful aspect of the tourist industry by nurturing mallee fowl in the west Wimmera. I am sure this project is reflected throughout the country. It is not just the Iwasakis of this world who are building tourism in Australia, and I do not think the Opposition should be so concerned that it will be difficult to fulfil the new provisions brought into this Bill by Senator Jenkins's amendments which, most thankfully, are supported by the Government. I just rise to reassure the Opposition that a number of people actually in the tourism industry are well qualified in this area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —This piece of tokenism gets worse as it gets allegedly more explained. The functions and powers of the Australian Tourism Commission are set out in clauses 6, 7 and 8. The objectives of the Commission are to increase the number of visitors, and to maximise the benefits to Australia of overseas visitors. The functions of the Commission are to promote Australia overseas as a tourist destination, to enhance awareness, to co-ordinate promotional efforts and to enhance awareness in Australia of the Australian tourist industry. The powers of the Commission are to do various things to promote tourism-to provide information, to conduct promotional activities, to undertake research, to distribute things which have the approved mark on them, to establish offices and do all the rest of it.

SPEECH.PARA: What the Commission does not have the responsibility to do is actually evaluate tourist projects or indeed designate which tourist projects shall go ahead and which shall not. If the function of the Commission were to do those things, there would be a very sound argument for having a person on the Commission who could bring to bear the skills designated in the proposed amendment Senator Jenkins has moved. But arguing over whether a person has sociological and environmental experience when the Commission itself is not primarily charged with doing anything other than promoting and increasing tourism seems to me to be symptomatic of the tokenist approach being taken in this regard.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suggest that it is the Australian Democrats who are totally confused about the role of the Australian Tourist Commission, and there is absolutely no confusion within the Opposition as to what the role of the Commission will be. We know that there are tourist operators who are sociologically and environmentally conscious. There is absolutely no doubt about the ability of people to fill this sort of role in an area where that sort of expertise is required. There is no need for the Australian Democrats to go on in a patronising manner as they are doing now. The point I make is that there are people who have the expertise to fulfil the role set out in this Bill, to fulfil the marketing and promotional role that is required. The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mr John Brown) ought to look to the industry and get some advice from it as to what people would best serve the purposes of the Commission. It is the Minister's arrogance in taking unto himself the sole role of choosing all nine members, whatever the criteria, that I think is an affront to the Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —I like to be neither patronised nor matronised, and I am sure that Mr Brown is in the same situation. When one looks at the functions of the Australian Tourist Commission as listed by Senator Puplick, a number of things spring to mind. One would hope that in the promotion overseas, in whatever country, of Australia as a tourist destination, the Commission would not be involved in any encouragement of an interruption, as an example, to significant Aboriginal cultural feelings which are held very dear. One could also imagine some extraordinarily sensitive environmental sites that would come under that category as well.

SPEECH.PARA: But also, under sub-clause 7 (d), we are to enhance awareness in Australia of the Australian tourism industry. So even within the country the Commission has a role, as well. As Senator Puplick said earlier, we should not be picking on international tourists and leaving out domestic tourists. Perhaps in the fulfilment of sub-clause 7 (d) the Commission, aided by the sort of person referred to in this amendment to clause 13, would be able to enhance awareness in Australia of the industry without upsetting any delicate sociological balances or any delicate environmental balances.
Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 4, after subclause 13 (4), insert the following new subclause:
``(4a) Of the members appointed pursuant to para- graph 12 (e), at least 2 members shall be appointed by the Minister from persons nominated by the Australian Tourist Industry Association.''.

(2) Page 5, subclause 14 (2), at end of subclause, add ``, provided that if the member was appointed following nomination by the Australian Tourist Industry Association, the person appointed in that member's place shall be appointed from persons nominated by the Australian Tourist Industry Association.''.

As the role of the Australian Tourist Commission is primarily an industry role, we believe that the persons appointed to the Board should reflect certain industry skills in a more specific and more direct fashion than the Government is proposing at the moment. It is certainly the case that the Government has intimated that the members appointed to the Board will have certain expertise and certain skills. If my memory serves me correctly, in discussion of recommendation 22 of the Kennedy report of the Australian Government Inquiry into Tourism, the question of whether people should be directly representative of associations, and indeed of State governments, was considered. The Kennedy inquiry concluded that such representations should be people with the appropriate industry skills. The Opposition, however, believes that the peak organisation, the Australian Tourist Industry Association (ATIA), should have the right to put to the Minister nominees to be considered for appointment to the Board of the Commission.

Section 6 of the Australian Tourist Commission Act 1967, under the heading `Constitution of the Commission', indicates specifically that there should be direct industry representatives, they being representatives of industries in Australia connected with tourism. Since the original enactment of that legislation, the growth and development of the tourist industry in Australia has been largely co-ordinated through the growth of the Australian Tourist Industry Association. At the second reading stage, I adverted to the attacks made by Mr John Brown on the Association as being part of what he saw as some New Right conspiracy and to his attacks on certain persons connected with the Association as being members of the so-called white shoe brigade. Nevertheless, given the Minister's attitude on these matters, we are not moved by the personal attack made by the Minister both on the Association and on individuals. We believe that ATIA should have the right to nominate.

When one has a clear peak organisation such as ATIA, it is interesting how selective the Government can be in regard to the sorts of peak organisations that it wishes to recognise and to provide with the right to be represented. For instance, there is never a case when the Government is looking to establish some new board or corporation where it does not believe that the rights of the workers involved should be represented by the appointment of representatives from the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) to those institutions. Whatever one may think about that, that is the Government's consistent argument in relation to a peak organisation within an industry in the development of what it sees to be the appropriate model. Whether that happens to be appropriate or not is not the issue for debate at the moment. But in the Government's corporatist approach to these things, the ACTU is recognised and provided with representatives, or when it comes to wage determinations, anomalies hearings or the like, it is the Confederation of Australian Industry or the Business Council of Australia. In the health industry it is the Australian Medical Association or the Pharmacy Guild of Australia. The Government goes out of its way to give those organisations direct representatives on the governing boards or on the important structures which it establishes.

The problem is that the Minister has a view about the ATIA and about individuals connected with that Association. He is therefore not prepared to concede the sort of direct industry representation from the peak council which we believe ought to be put forward. I do not want to anticipate the debate, but I understand that the Australian Democrats will seek to move an amendment to my amendment. I will deal with that when it has been formally moved. Nevertheless, we believe that ATIA should have the right to submit to the Minister certain names for appointment as two of the members of the nine-member Board, that the Minister should be at liberty to draw from that list which has been submitted to him, and that section 14 (2) also should be amended to ensure that any replacements are dealt with in the same fashion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am fully in agreement with Senator Puplick that there should be direct industry representation on the Board of the Australian Tourist Commission. However, when I looked into the amendments, I was puzzled as to why the Australian Tourism Industry Association (ATIA) had been singled out. This is why I shall also be moving amendments to the same two clauses. The Kennedy report of the Australian Government Inquiry into Tourism, from which most of the recommendations for the Australian Tourist Commission Bill were taken, states on page 16:

SPEECH.PARA: There are numerous tourism industry organisations. Although they essentially represent private-sector interests, federal and state bodies are represented on many because of their involvement in the industry. Two major industry bodies are described below . . .

The two described are the Australian Tourism Industry Association and the Inbound Tour Operators Association. The second association was formed in 1972 and serves primarily the overseas visitor market. Personally, I could not see the logic in singling out the ATIA as opposed to a second association which dealt primarily with the overseas visitor market. This is why the amendments that I shall move will state that, of the members appointed, at least two members shall be drawn from representative national tourism organisations. I seek leave to move my two amendments together.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment (1), leave out proposed subclause (4a), insert the following new subclause:
``(4a) Of the members appointed pursuant to paragraph 12 (e), at least two members shall be drawn from representative national tourism organisations.''
Amendment (2), leave out the proposed amendment, insert the following amendment:

Page 5, subclause 14 (2), at the end of subclause, add ``, provided that if the member was drawn from a representative national tourism organisation, the person appointed in that member's place by the Minister shall be drawn from a representative national tourism organisation.''

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —While the Australian Tourist Industry Association (ATIA) would describe itself as a peak council, one wonders whether it can live up to the definition. In the view of other significant organisations within the industry, it does not. If one looks at the operation of the Australian Tourist Commission in the past with a larger Board, where a number of bodies were able to nominate members, we can get some idea of what would happen if the Government were to adopt Senator Puplick's amendments. It is the case that with the reduction in numbers from 13 to nine the States will no longer have direct representation; they will not be nominating members. It seems just a smidgin incongruous if one can say to the State of New South Wales, Queensland or wherever that it cannot have a nominee, yet an industry association-not the peak one but an industry association-lays claim to some spots on the Board as of right. The Government cannot accept that. The Australian Federation of Travel Agents, the Inbound Tour Operators Association, the Australian Hotels Association and so on will not accept it either. I have no doubt that, given that the Government had received numerous requests for representations from all sorts of bodies on the Board of the last Commission, it would not be possible, if there were to be a smaller Board, for us to agree to them all. That being the case, the Government rejects Senator Puplick's amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: I think Senator Jenkins's amendments go a long way to overcoming the problem. The Government has never had an objection to industry representatives and indeed always intended that there be such representatives. Therefore, Senator Jenkins's amendments are acceptable to the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am grateful that the Minister for the Environment and the Arts (Senator Richardson) has confirmed the view that we have formed about the Government's reaction to our nomination of the Australian Tourist Industry Association as the peak body to be represented. I am grateful also for the Minister's advice. We will not support Senator Jenkins's amendments, and indeed will divide.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That Senator Jenkins's amendments to Senator Puplick's amendments be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —The question now is that Senator Puplick's amendments, as amended, to clauses 13 and 14 be agreed to.

INTERJECT.PARA: Clauses 13 and 14, as amended, agreed to.
Clauses 15 to 22-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first of the four amendments which relate to the same issue arises in relation to proposed new clause 22a. We are seeking to insert in the legislation a requirement that the Minister observe normal private enterprise practice and conditions in relation to a number of matters. The first is in relation to the terms and conditions of appointment to the Board. The subsequent amendments are to clause 39, relating to the Managing Director; to clause 42, relating to employees; and to clause 43, relating to consultants. They all touch upon the same central issue, that is, that in the Commission's operations it should be encouraged to observe the general practices which are common in the private sector rather than those which are fundamentally characteristic of the public sector and of the control of the Public Service Board, in particular.

SPEECH.PARA: A great deal has been made rightly in this debate of the recommendations of the Kennedy inquiry, the Australian Government Committee of Inquiry into Tourism. The Kennedy inquiry was established to advise the Australian Government on the best ways to conduct its tourist operations and, in particular, the restructuring of the Australian Tourist Commission. One of the matters which came directly before the Kennedy inquiry was the question of terms and conditions of employment. On pages 100 to 102 of volume 1 of the Kennedy report, there is a great deal of discussion on this matter. In essence, it is summed up by the submission of the Western Australian Tourist Commission, which is quoted on page 101 of the report:

The Public Service jurisdiction places unnecessary restrictions on the Australian Tourist Commission insofar as the administrative procedures, employment of staff from outside the Service and hours of operation are concerned.
Australian Airlines, in its submissions, said:

Financial restrictions and the public service structure of the Australian Tourist Commission are significant impediments to the Australian Tourist Commission's ability to attract management and staff with strong marketing skills, a prerequisite for the Australian Tourist Commission to ascend to a leadership role.
The Association of Australian Convention Bureau Inc., in its submission, said:

The Public Service conditions that currently constrain the activities of the Australian Tourist Commission inhibit a result-geared mechanism necessary to measure effectively the activities of the Commission.

The Kennedy report goes on to analyse what the Government had said in its policy discussion paper entitled `Statutory Authorities and Government Business Enterprises'. It quoted from that paper as follows:
Those bodies-
that is, statutory authorities-
not staffed under the Public Service Act will generally be required by statute to co-ordinate pay and conditions of employment with the Public Service Board.
The report then goes on to say:
We consider that such a strong case could be mounted in favour of the removal of the Australian Tourist Commission from its current statutory relationship with the Public Service Board.
Of the 96 or 97 recommendations of the Kennedy report, this is the most important recommendation which was not picked up. In effect, two recommendations were not picked up. Recommendation 46 states:
The Committee-
that is, the Kennedy committee-

therefore recommends that the ATC be removed from its current statutory relationship with the Public Service Board in industrial matters, particularly terms and conditions of employment. In so recommending, we note that the ATC will continue to be subject to review by the Co-ordination Committee within the Federal Department of Employment and Industrial Relations.

We regret that the Government did not see fit to pick up that recommendation. In the examination of the Department in Estimates Com- mittee F on Thursday, 8 October, I asked representatives of the Commission what their general view was of the Public Service Board control of the Commission or the capacity of the Commission to operate on more normal private enterprise guidelines. I asked Mr Rowe, from the Commission, what his view was in relation to that recommendation of the Kennedy Committee. I quote from the Hansard record of Estimates Committee F on 8 October. Mr Rowe said:
What that recommendation would have allowed, of course, was more competitive salaries in the commercial sense, to get the right people for the key jobs around the world. What it has meant-
that is, the rejection of the recommendation-
is that we have recast our structure and have employed a lot of new staff based on the existing system, with government levels of seniority, et cetera.

What we are seeking to achieve in this series of amendments, the first of which is to insert new clause 22a, is a more genuinely private enterprise approach to the operations of the Commission. New clause 22a relates to the question of the appointments to the board and proposes:
In determining terms and conditions of appointment pursuant to section 22, the Minister shall observe normal private enterprise terms and conditions of appointment.

As I have said, our amendments then deal with the position of the Managing Director, the position of employees and the positions of consultants. We believe that, if the Tourist Commission is to operate effectively, it should not be required to operate, as it were, with one hand tied behind its back. It is competing on behalf of the Australian nation in a very competitive, cut-throat world. We have a great responsibility to ensure that we have a commission which is free from unnecessary constraints in order to attract to Australia the maximum number of tourists. To do that, the Commission must be able to offer terms and conditions of employment and salaries which are commensurate with those offered in the private sector, both within Australia and at an international level. We are competing in a very difficult international environment.

It is our belief that by passing these amendments, the first of which is now before the committee, we will have the opportunity to establish the Commission on a more private enterprise-based set of principles, which will allow the Commission to attract the sort of people necessary and to offer them the terms and conditions of employment which more genuinely reflect what they could earn and what they could expect to achieve within the private sector and within the internationally competitive sector. Therefore, I have pleasure in proposing to the committee the insertion of a new clause 22a which will be the first clause to give effect to that principle. I move:
(3) Page 6, after clause 22, insert the following new clause:
Minister to observe private enterprise practice
`22a. In determining terms and conditions of appointment pursuant to section 22, the Minister shall observe normal private enterprise terms and conditions of appointment.'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —These clauses have presented the Australian Democrats with something of a dilemma and have been discussed at length. We did discuss what `normal private enterprise terms and conditions of appointment' means. I thank Senator Puplick for going down that path. I am fully aware of what he is aiming at in relation to these clauses in the Bill. However, for some companies, normal conditions can also mean lurks and perks and megabucks for top executives and shareholders. Some of these lurks and perks have caused both the Fraser Government and the Hawke Government to introduce anti-avoidance taxation legislation, earning them the contempt, I am very sorry to say, of their private enterprise friends.

SPEECH.PARA: It must also be observed in the present circumstances that the Cabinet has already endorsed changes in the guidelines for statutory authorities and government business enterprises along the lines of the Green Paper released in June 1986. These proposals have yet to be approved by Caucus, as I understand it. The Opposition is suggesting these changes to the Australian Tourist Commission alone. I am not sure that this is the right time for such changes in any case, but I do not see why they should be made to only one government enterprise just because this legislation happens to be before the Parliament right now.

I believe that the changes approved by Cabinet will include the establishment of financial targets for each authority as a trade-off for the many controls that are permanently exercised over government authorities. These include controls over salaries, industrial relations, borrowings for capital purchases and land acquisition and sales. I would welcome the opportunity to examine such changes in detail and to seek the views of those currently employed by the relevant organisations. The Opposition's amendment is not an acceptable basis for embarking on yet another process of deregulation at a time when the clamours for government control, regulation and assistance are only beginning following the recent share market collapse. The Democrats cannot support the four amendments on those lines.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government opposes the amendment on a number of grounds. Are they the terms and conditions of appointment that would apply in the case of a company like Peko- Wallsend Ltd, whether it is running a battery factory or a coal mine in the Hunter Valley? The purpose of this amendment is relatively simple. Clause 29 deals with the capacity of the Minister to give directions to the Board. Clause 29 (1) provides that the Minister, in certain conditions:
May give written directions to the Board in relation to the performance of the functions, and the exercise of the powers, of the Commission, and the Board shall comply with the directions.
Sub-clause (2) provides:

(a) has informed the Board . . . that the Minister is considering giving the direction; has given the Chairperson an opportunity to discuss the need for the proposed direction . . . is satisfied that, because of the existence of exceptional circumstances, it is necessary to give the direction to the Board in order to ensure that the performance of the functions, or the exercise of the powers, of the Commission does not conflict with major government policies.

I have no objection to any of those types of arrangements. They are perfectly normal and perfectly proper where a statutory authority, a board or a commission operates, and the Minister is entitled to insist that policies of the Government, where they are potentially in conflict with those of the Board, or where the Board is not paying attention to the policies of the Government, should prevail. Sub-clause (3) of clause 29 then provides:
where the Minister gives a direction to the Board . . .
the Minister shall cause a copy of the direction:
(i) to be published in the Gazette as soon as practicable . . .
(ii) to be laid before each House of the Parliament within 15 sitting days of that House giving the direction . . .

Again that is perfectly normal and proper parliamentary practice. We then have a quite extraordinary sub-clause (4), which provides that sub-section (3), that is the sub-section which requires the Minister both to publish in the Gazette and to lay before Parliament the directions:
does not apply in relation to a particular direction if the Minister determines, in writing, that compliance with the subsection would be contrary to the public interest.

This is the most extraordinary power that the Minister seeks to take to himself. In order to demonstrate to the Committee just how extraordinary it is, I draw attention to the Reserve Bank Act 1959. This Act provides for the relationship between the Treasurer of the Commonwealth of Australia and the Reserve Bank of Australia. It provides much the same as sub-clauses (1), (2) and (3), that the Treasurer may give directions to the Reserve Bank and that the Reserve Bank shall in fact obey the directions of the Treasurer. Sub-section (7) of section 11 of the Reserve Bank Act states:
The Treasurer shall cause to be laid before each House of the Parliament, within fifteen sitting days of that House after the Treasurer has informed the Board of the policy determined . . .
(a) a copy of the order determining the policy;
(b) a statement by the Government in relation to the matter in respect of which the difference arose-
that is the difference between the Board of the Reserve Bank and the Treasurer-
(c) a copy of the statement furnished to the Treasurer by the Board-

in certain circumstances. In other words, a direction which the Treasurer of the Commonwealth of Australia gives to the Reserve Bank through its Board has to be presented to the Parliament. There is no exception to that. Apart from perhaps legislation dealing with the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation or some other piece of national security, I cannot imagine anything which is more fundamentally sensitive than a direction which the Treasurer may give to the Reserve Bank when there is a conflict between the two. Under the Reserve Bank Act, the Treasurer does not have the capacity to conceal from the Parliament, on the basis of some spurious public interest, the nature of the direction which he has given. Frankly, if the relationship between the Treasurer and the Board of the Reserve Bank is of such a quality that it is not protected from the scrutiny of the Parliament, I simply cannot imagine how it is that a direction given by the Minister for tourism to the Australian Tourist Commission should attract a greater protection than that given by the Treasurer to the Board of the Reserve Bank. If the Minister wants to give directions, he is perfectly entitled to. If he wants to give instructions to the Commission, he is perfectly entitled to. That is proper and that is why he is the Minister. But then to turn around and say that he can determine in writing that it is contrary to the public interest to inform the Parliament of the direction which he has given seems to me to be absolutely ludicrous.

What we will not permit, if we have any say in the matter, is for him to have the power to give directions to the Board and not to tell the Parliament that he has given those directions because of some spurious public interest criteria, criteria which the Government would not even permit to the Treasurer in his dealings with the Reserve Bank of Australia. COMMONWEALTH BORROWING LEVY BILL 1987

The purpose of this Bill is to provide for the imposition from 1 July 1987 of an annual levy on all borrowings, including raisings of money otherwise than by borrowing, by Commonwealth semi-government authorities. The levy is imposed in place of the Commonwealth guarantee charge introduced in 1986-87.

The Commonwealth guarantee charge was introduced to take account of the favourable interest rates paid by Commonwealth authorities where their borrowings are explicitly guaranteed by the Commonwealth. The Government's objective in imposing the charge was to ensure that the effective cost of borrowings to authorities was more directly comparable with that faced by private sector borrowers, thus ensuring that authorities take full account of the cost to the community of their investment decisions.
Following a review of the operation of the charge in 1986-87, the Government has decided that the arrangements should be modified in three respects:

First, the charge on explicit Commonwealth guarantees should be replaced by a levy on all borrowings by authorities. This is because the authorities' government-owned status confers advantages in financial markets similar to those which arise from an explicit government guarantee. The cost of funds to Commonwealth authorities appears to reflect an expectation by lenders that the Commonwealth will stand behind those authorities whether or not an explicit guarantee has been given;

Second, the levy should not apply to Commonwealth-owned financial institutions, such as the Commonwealth Banks and the Australian Industry Development Corporation. These institutions gain only little advantage in terms of borrowing costs from Commonwealth ownership beyond that arising from their status as financial institutions;
Third, the rate of the levy should be lowered to more closely reflect the benefit authorities gain from Commonwealth ownership.

These modified arrangements are to apply to borrowings undertaken on or after 1 July 1987. Borrowings undertaken in 1986-87 which were subject to the Commonwealth guarantee charge will continue to bear that charge until they mature.

The Bill provides for the imposition of the levy at a rate not exceeding 0.5 per cent per annum, the rate of the Commonwealth guarantee charge applying in 1986-87. It is intended that, in respect of 1987-88, a levy at the lesser rate of 0.125 per cent per annum will be imposed by regulation.
The levy imposed by this Bill is expected to raise revenue of some $1.3 million in 1987-88, while ongoing revenue from the Commonwealth guarantee charge is estimated to amount to $7.6 million.

The impost is now described as a levy because it will apply comprehensively to borrowings and will not be related to the provision of a guarantee, which in most cases could be sought by authorities at their discretion.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
COMMONWEALTH BORROWING LEVY
COLLECTION BILL 1987
The purpose of this Bill is to provide for the collection of the Commonwealth borrowing levy imposed by the Commonwealth Borrowing Levy Bill 1987.

The Bill defines the borrowings in respect of which the levy may be payable to include all borrowings and other raisings of money which the Commonwealth authorities subject to the levy Bill are empowered to undertake, and provides for the making of administrative arrangements to collect the levy.
The Bill also provides for the repeal of the Commonwealth Guarantees (Charges) Act 1987 except insofar as it applies to borrowings undertaken in 1986-87.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Egg Industry Research (Hen Quota) Levy Act 1987 so as to clarify the incidence of the levy imposed by that Act and collected under an associated Levy Collection Act.

The amendments sought stem from advice received by the Government before the levy legislation in question had completed its passage during the last sittings. Plans for incorporating the amendments at that stage were, however, frustrated by the dissolution of the Parliament.

The levy imposed by the Levy Act is paid by egg producers to support research programs financed jointly by industry and Government. It is levied on hen quotas held by egg producers under State or Territory licences, that is, on the number of laying hens a producer is entitled to keep. As a matter of convenience and economy, collection of the levy in the States is undertaken on behalf of the Commonwealth by State Egg Boards.

When the levy legislation was awaiting debate in the Senate, after being passed by the House of Representatives, advice was received from industry that the provisions defining the application of the levy did not appear to cater for some variations in State hen quota practices. Examination of these practices against the relevant provisions confirmed that there was room for doubt as to the adequacy of the provisions concerned.

Amendments to remedy this shortcoming were drafted for introduction during the debate in the Senate, but in the event, this course could not be followed. Senate debate on the levy legislation was brought on when the Autumn Sittings were all but ended and the house had already concluded its legislative business. This meant that if the amendment process were initiated at that time, it could not be completed before the dissolution of the Parliament and the legislation imposing the levy would lapse.

As the arrangements embodied in the levy legislation depended on the levy commencing on 1 July 1987, significant problems would have resulted if no levy mechanism was in place by that date. Accordingly, it was decided to seek passage of the legislation as it stood and to pursue amendment of the Levy Act in the Budget Sittings.

All State authorities concerned with collection of the levy on the Commonwealth's behalf were informed of the intention to amend the Levy Act and of the nature of the proposed amendments. This has enabled levy collection to proceed on the basis to be confirmed by the amendments.
Against this background, I will now explain the genesis and intent of the amendments contained in the Bill.

When the Levy Act was being framed, the definition of the term ``hen quota licence'', which largely governs the incidence of the levy, was formulated on the premise that State licences issued to egg producers in all cases specify a hen quota which is the maximum number of laying hens that may be kept. This formulation was adopted after examination of relevant State legislation.

It has come to notice, however, that because of the varying ways in which individual States express and notify hen keeping entitlements in actual practice, the definition in question is-at least on a narrow interpretation-at variance with administrative procedures followed in some States.

In order to remove any doubts as to how the levy should apply, the proposed amendments will alter the definition of the term ``hen quota licence'', add a definition of ``hen quota'' and make appropriate changes to all provisions of the Levy Act where these expressions occur. The effect of these alterations will be to establish clearly that the levy applies to operative hen quotas-that is, actual hen keeping entitlements-irrespective of how or where these are specified by the States under their administrative procedures.

The levy was applied from 1 July 1987 with first payments due on 1 September 1987. As I mentioned earlier, by virtue of prior arrangements with State authorities collecting the levy, the application of the levy has proceeded from the outset on the basis to be confirmed by the amendments. Accordingly, it has been necessary to include a provision making the amendments retrospective to 1 July 1987. It should be stressed, however, that the proposed changes will not impose additional liability on levy payers.
Indeed, the position with regard to financial impact is that the amendments will not increase the financing commitments of the Commonwealth or the industry.
I commend the Bill to Honourable Senators.
