The Labor Party is always opposed to any wealth creation and this was a chance for some wealth to be created so it said, `Let us move in and attack it'. We opposed that legislation but could not get the support of the Democrats to knock it out so we accepted the amendment which inserted the sunset clause.

The Government is now proposing to remove altogether that sunset clause and that means that not only will this cash bidding system be able to continue beyond the sunset period but also the legislation is wide open and can be imposed upon any oil explorers. It is not in any way limited to what was then thought to be the highly prospective areas adjacent to the Ashmore and Cartier Islands. Two years down the track it has been established beyond any doubt that they were not highly prospective but only moderately prospective areas, and I will come to that in due course.

As late as noon today my information was that the Democrats still had not made up their minds what they would do with this Bill. They were still consulting the Government. Originally the Democrats said that they were opposed to it but that they would let the Government have a go for a couple of years, so they put in a sunset clause.

TALK.START.PARA: —Read the Hansard.

—We shall find out tonight what the Democrats are prepared to do now that they are faced with a crunch situation. Democrat senators can interject as long as they like but the truth of the matter is that we want to see where they put their bottoms in this chamber when they vote. We want to know whether they will be voting with members of the Opposition who are opposed to the Bill or whether, as usual when there is a crunch situation, they will support the Government and allow it its legislation.
—Get them to do another deal on logging.

—Another deal on logging-deals are being done all over the place. The only time we ever see the Democrats voting against the Government is on some innocuous issue on which they think there are a few votes, a little voting niche from which they may be able to get some support. But on a crunch issue such as this of vital importance to the oil explorers of this nation, we shall see where they vote.

SPEECH.PARA: The arguments against this legislation which we outlined in 1985 have changed little. The truth of the matter is that there has been a continuing downturn in off-shore oil exploration and that downturn only strengthens the arguments which we made in 1985. Australia is running out of oil. Bass Strait, the major producing area, is two-thirds exhausted already. When I say that it is two-thirds exhausted, I mean that two-thirds of those areas which we have already discovered are exhausted. Of course, there may be other areas which have not yet been discovered but under this Government's guidance we have not yet been able to ascertain those areas. Worse still, Bass Strait will supply only 65 per cent of Australia's liquid fuel needs this year and little more than 40 per cent by 1990. Australia will then be facing an oil import bill of up to $3 billion in today's currency. Given this fact people would expect us to be undertaking massive exploration but clearly this Government does not expect to be in office in 1990. If this amending Bill is passed the Liberal and National parties, as usual, will be left to clear up the mess.

Cash bidding, imposed by the original legislation and extended and adopted by this amending legislation, is nothing more than an impost dressed up as an auction system for the right to undertake the risk of exploration. There are no guarantees of success in this industry. The work program, which currently applies to the bulk of applications for oil exploration permits-that is other than the Ashmore and Cartier Islands areas-has successfully operated for years and with our serious balance of payments problem it would be a most inappropriate time to produce any impediment at all to petroleum exploration. But this Bill will enable the Government simply to do that.

The Australian Democrats cannot make up their minds about whether to oppose the legislation. Unlike the Government and the Democrats, who are also unlikely to be around in the 1990s, the coalition recognises that Australia can ill-afford the diversion of high cost risk capital from exploration budgets. If oil is found the Government will get its revenue from taxes. There is no need to get up front and to stop people from exploring by imposing fees on them before they even get a chance to go out and find the oil. If the oil is found the Government will get its opportunity to obtain tax revenue from those companies.

The cash bidding system concept elsewhere has been linked to areas of high prospectivity. That is a jargon word in the oil industry which relates to likelihood of success. In the United States of America (USA), the United Kingdom (UK), off-shore, and Norway the cash bidding concept applies. The USA has tried, in fact for the past decade, to find some other leasing method. In the interim it has shut out industry from some of the most promising acreages of the whole outer continental shelf. As a concept, it is totally inappropriate to Australia, which is rated with the lowest prospectivity for oil discovery. Frankly, governments get into trouble with off-shore programs as seen in the UK and Canada, where they became too greedy and sought too much. Governments get into trouble when they forget that the reason for granting exploration rights is to accommodate exploration; it is not for the purpose of enriching national treasuries or to cater for special interest groups.

It is quite clear that the reason for this legislation is simply to raise revenue. This legislation ignores the real need to encourage exploration by removing impediments. Many overseas governments, for example in Canada, China, India, Malaysia, Nigeria and Norway, are in fact relaxing their imposts to help maintain industry activity in the wake of the oil price collapses. It is hardly surprising that in these circumstances more than 50 Australian-based companies have expanded their petroleum exploration interests overseas-not in Australia, but overseas. They have mainly gone to Indonesia, to the United States, Papua New Guinea, China, New Zealand, the United Kingdom and Canada. The fact that this Government refuses to acknowledge the relationship between tax levels, especially those imposed before exploration has begun, and exploration and discovery activity, is a major cause for concern, given the rapid decline in current reserves of oil in Australia.

This legislation illustrates the Government's determination to ignore the advice of the experts, such as the Australian Petroleum Exploration Association and the Australian Institute of Petroleum Ltd, which are opposed to it. Further, the Northern Territory Government is opposed to the measure, and until 1985 the Western Australian Labor Government also opposed it. Premier Burke is at this stage strangely silent on the proposal in this Bill. We do not know what will happen in regard to Western Australia. I note that Senator Richardson has come into the chamber; I would bet my bottom dollar that if New South Wales had off-shore oil this Bill would not have been introduced. If there was something to be gained in New South Wales, the honourable senator opposite would be making dashed sure that this Bill was not put through. However, he does not have to worry about such consideration for New South Wales. So, the States of Australia which do have off-shore oil will have to suffer this impediment imposed on them.

The Government has rejected the concerns expressed by the oil exploration industries; it rejects the concerns expressed by the States and the Northern Territory. The Government claims that it has reviewed the effectiveness of cash bidding. We ultimately managed to get the results of that review, and I might say that we had to put in a freedom of information application in order to get that. Finally, the Minister for Science and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones) produced that review. However, it proved to be nothing more than a document which set out the arguments that the Government had put back in 1985. We know what the arguments are. Senator Walsh keeps producing those same sort of arguments in the chamber day after day. Here is a possibility that some companies might create some wealth, and the Government wants to get its share of that wealth before they do. We have seen Senator Walsh pushing these ideas through Cabinet, the Caucus and the Parliament. When we managed to get hold of this document, which was supposed to be a review of the effectiveness of this policy, it turned out that it was simply a regurgitation of the same quasi-economic arguments that we hear daily from Senator Walsh, who is worried about what he calls rorts being perpetrated by some companies which may be able to make a profit as a result of getting out there and spending very substantial amounts of money on oil exploration. The review simply asserts that we ought to have cash bidding because, in effect, the Government needs the revenue.

An objective review would have shown that the oil explorers had voted with their feet against this Government's imposts. The oil explorers have deserted Australian oil exploration in droves. In 1983 there were 49 exploration wells and 49 wild cat wells off-shore in Australia. Now, in 1987, there are only 16 exploration wells and 11 wild-cat wells. Exploration expenditure has fallen from $520m in 1983 to a mere $130m in 1987. The reality is that world oil prices are low and uncertain. Australia's known oil reserves are rapidly diminishing, and petroleum exploration has been severely cut back as more companies look to greener pastures. Among the companies recently announcing the acquisition of United States gas or oil interests are Lennard Oil NL, Lakes Oil Ltd, Peko Oil Ltd, Stirling Petroleum NL, Bligh Oil and Minerals NL, BHP Petroleum Pty Ltd, Barcoo Petroleum NL, Orca Petroleum NL and Bridge Oil Ltd. They are Australian companies which have gone to the United States to undertake exploration work.

I see that Senator Richardson is bored by all this, but I can assure him that the oil exploration industry of Australia is not bored by all these problems that the Government of which he is a part is imposing on it. I refer to the penalities and the taxes which this Government is imposing on the companies in that industry. It is not giving them a chance to go out there and explore for oil in the places where they might be able to find it. The companies involved might be prepared to have a go if only the Government would give them the opportunity to do so.

The Government simply does not appear to understand that our off-shore explorers have failed to find an off-shore oil field in excess of 50 million barrels, and yet Australia needs to find the equivalent of two or three such fields every year if it is to maintain fuel self-sufficiency at 50 per cent by the year 2000. That is a very significant factor. The companies involved in exploration have been unable to find off-shore such substantial fields. Our known crude oil reserves are about 1.9 billion barrels, and at current consumption rates of some 170 million barrels a year those reserves will last for only another 11 years.

In his second reading speech the Minister argued that cash bidding is a more efficient and equitable system than the work program system, especially in areas where competition is expected to be intense. But the truth of the matter is-and by contrast-that the industry argues that the work program which applies to the bulk of applications for oil exploration permits has operated satisfactorily for some years. While that system is more regulatory-and that, of course, worries us-it has still proved to be far superior to the cash bidding system which is being imposed by this Government. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) claims that exploration risks and costs are reduced by cash bidding because the system is more flexible. However, under the cash bidding system successful bidders need give no undertaking of what work will be done or when it will be done. This is hardly the way to provide the systems and the incentives to encourage the pace of exploration in the face of declining reserves. The work program favoured by industry requires such a commitment.

Furthermore, the prospectivity of the Timor Sea has now been brought into question. The cash bid concept, as I mentioned before, introduced in 1985, was introduced in the belief that because prospectivity in that area was supposed to be high the Government stood to collect substantial income and it was not going to allow any of these exploring companies to make windfall profits. But we now have the benefit of hindsight. Subsequent drilling in the Timor Sea has delineated reserves at less than 20 million barrels at Jabiru and about 40 million barrels at Challis.

TALK.START.PARA: —Fourteen.

—My colleague corrects me-it is 14 million barrels, not 40 million, at Challis. This suggests that the area is more likely to contain simply a number of small fields, not one gigantic field which the Government had anticipated. But still the Government persists in coming back with this legislation. Even though the Timor Sea, Ashmore and Cartier fields have been reassessed and oil prices have collapsed, to date not a single well has been drilled on any permit awarded on a cash bidding system, and only very limited seismic work has been carried out in only one permit area. I ask the Government: Is this the basis on which the cash bidding system has been reviewed? As a large part of Australia's remaining undiscovered oil reserves are believed to be located off-shore in generally deeper water, the Government should be doing everything it possibly can to encourage off-shore oil exploration, with its attendant high costs and high risks.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government is deluding the people by claiming that cash bidding is one way that the Australian people can receive some compensation for the resources that belong to all Australians. But first the oil has to be discovered, and then recovered. Cash bidding is a real impediment to both the discovery and the recovery process. No convincing evidence has been put forward by the Government to support cash bidding, and no plausible case has been put forward for the removal of the sunset clause. Australia is running out of oil. A tax rate of up to 91 per cent on existing production and a proposed additional tax of 70 per cent on new discoveries provide little incentive for oil producers to go out and look for it. Adding the impediment to oil exploration proposed in this amendment Bill is patently absurd, and the Opposition will oppose the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have observed during my long life that if a person really has nothing to say in a debate, has no facts at his or her disposal, that person simply abuses those who disagree with his or her point of view. That is what we have heard tonight-a litany of abuse, very few facts and certainly no sustainable philosophy. Senator Lewis said that we should not expand the cash bidding program, which in fact is what this Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Legislation Amendment Bill would do. He said that in fact the program should be eliminated entirely. He called off a list of companies that had gone overseas, that had gone to the United States of America to participate in the oil industry. But apparently Senator Lewis does not realise that the US has a cash bidding program which has been successfully run for a number of years, and the companies are still happy to go to the US and operate under such a program. So I do not think we can give much credence to anything that Senator Lewis said. He also seems to ignore the low price of oil and the increasing cost of exploration. He ignores these facts and tries to say that exploration is decreasing simply because of some legislation that the Government has put in place. This is simply not so. He lives in his own world. Obviously he does not participate in the real world of oil exploration or economics.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill before us is basically an enlargement of the legislation we passed two years ago. Time does fly when you are having fun. The cash bidding legislation came before us two years ago and we passed it. We were quite pleased that it passed, although we did put in a sunset clause because at the time the oil industry was saying that it would hurt the small Australian oil companies. That may be a contradiction in terms; I do not know whether there is such a thing as a small Australian oil company. They all seem quite large. But still the industry claims that they might be hurt, and that is why we agreed to cash bidding.

TALK.START.PARA: —After last Tuesday there are a few.

—After last Tuesday a lot may be smaller than they once were. It turns out that their operation has not been hampered; they are not going to the wall. There is no lasting difficulty for the small oil companies. In fact, no one has been disadvantaged by this program at all. Of course the oil companies will complain no matter what. They are a bit like the farmers in that respect.
—And the Poms.

—And the Parliament. They will complain. I suppose it is the job of their lobbyists, such as the Australian Petroleum Exploration Association, to complain. The Bill will abolish the special arrangement with Western Australia whereby disagreements in the Joint Authority are resolved on a Premier-Prime Minister basis. It is about time. Why should Western Australia, with all respect to those in the chamber, be singled out for special treatment and have its difficulties resolved by a special conference between the Prime Minister and the Premier when no other Territory or State has that privilege.
—`Premier' not `Preemier'.

—I do have trouble with the language, as does even the honourable senator. I do not think that Western Australia, for all its accomplishments in the arts and other areas, should be singled out for special treatment when it comes to oil. Therefore, the Australian Democrats are firmly behind the move to abolish this special arrangement.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill will allow matters which were previously dealt with by the Joint Authority at the discretion of the Commonwealth Minister to become automatically matters for Joint Authority decision. This, too, is a step in the right direction, and Senator Lewis should agree with this because it will allow these matters to speed more swiftly through the decision-making process. The Bill will also abolish the over the counter award of petroleum exploration and production titles. Of course this is because we do have cash bidding, which makes it unnecessary to have the over the counter award of production titles.

An important facet of the Bill is that it will allow a location to be declared over all of the blocks which cover a petroleum pool or pools found in a permit area, and remove the restriction on the maximum size of the location, presently a maximum of nine blocks. This is very important, and I am sure Senator Lewis would approve of it because it means that, if a pool extends over a number of artificial lines on the map, it can be produced effectively and efficiently rather than having to be either left unproduced or produced inefficiently because of some artificial constraint put on by those who drew the lines in the first place. So this is a recognition of the reality of geology, of the fact that these pools do not necessarily obey the lines drawn by human beings.

The Bill will protect confidential information contained in instruments evidencing dealings registered under section 81 of the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act 1967. This is another very worthwhile part of the Bill because, if people are actually investing large amounts of money in petroleum exploration, they simply do not want this information to be bandied about. It should remain confidential. On the other hand, the Bill allows for the 1985 amendments to section 118 of the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act, which provide for improved public access to data and information, to apply the data and information supplied under the Act prior to the proclamation of the 1985 amendments. When it is not to the economic disadvantage of an oil company, information should be freely available to the people. This comes under the principle of freedom of information, and I am sure that Senator Lewis, who obtained some information under the Freedom of Information Act, would approve. I believe that there is a lot in the Bill that Senator Lewis does approve of, and I wonder why he has not mentioned those aspects.

The Bill also provides for the Commonwealth Minister to direct the Designated Authority to obtain documents related to petroleum operations being carried on in the adjacent area. This will add to the free flow of information. It removes the sunset clause on the cash bidding legislation to allow that legislation to remain in force after 21 November 1987. The sunset clause, as I have already mentioned, was put in by the Democrats. We did so because of the fears expressed on the lines I have mentioned. There is no reason that this sunset clause should not come out.

Let us look at the oil companies themselves and at what they have been doing and saying. I have an address given to the Australian Pipeline Industry Association 1987 international convention by Keith Orchison, Executive Director of the Australian Petroleum Exploration Association. This was in Adelaide on 28 October 1987. Mr Orchison kindly sent me this. It is the same line that the oil companies, not only in Australia but around the world, have been using. I have been working in this area for 20 years, and it has not changed in that time. Basically the industry is crying wolf. It is like the little boy in the fable who liked to get attention by crying wolf. He would come running home to his family and say, `Wolf! Wolf! There's a wolf'. They would all go rushing out, and the boy would get what he wanted, which was attention.

The oil companies have been shouting, `We are running out of oil' and all the parliaments and congresses around the world and their legislators have been giving them what they wanted, which is basically open slather. But even as the wolf in the fable did not appear for a very long time, this has not appeared in the 20 years that I have been dealing with these issues. I am a geologist and have worked for the oil companies; I have also worked as an environmentalist trying to pound some sense into their heads in the United States. I have found that they have used the same line over and over again. Keith Orchison kindly included some of their very low key advertisements. I have one in black and red which reads, `Oil imports: oil production' and shows that we are importing more oil. The message is:
Unless we find more of the black, we will find ourselves more in the red.

Is that not a wonderful statement? Some advertising person must have spent a lot of time on that. I have another interesting one that says, `Australia is running out of oil'. The implication is that we are soon to freeze to death in the dark if we do not give the oil companies everything they want. I have heard this before. I heard it in the United States. In the United States, after the Santa Barbara oil spill of 1969 a number of us, scientists and politicians, got together to try to limit off-shore oil drilling in the United States because obviously the technology was not up to it. There were a number of blowouts, a number of disastrous ecological occurrences there because of the oil spills, and we obtained a moratorium on off-shore drilling. At that time the oil companies said, `Oh, there will be dire consequences and you people will run out of oil. You won't be able to run your cars, your power supplies will go off' and so on. They found that they could improve their technology and they did not go broke. The technology was improved to the point where the oil companies' record is better than it was. Drilling for oil off-shore is still a finite hazard and there have been spills. There is no way to contain an oil spill off-shore in the open sea. Skimmers will not work, booms will not work, various artificial methods will not work, and this is an area where more attention should be paid to research into alleviating the disastrous consequences of oil spills.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where will that money come from?

—The money should come from the oil companies because those companies are using the people's resource, and that resource includes not only oil but the environment. It is time that we internalised those externalities of the environment. Why should we make the environment pay for low cost, shonky, ill-prepared operations when the environment belongs to all of us? Why should the environment pay? The oil companies should pay.
—But if you allowed them to make a profit, they could do those things.

—Talk about profits, I have never heard the oil company saying that they do not have enough profits. They may complain that they would like more. During the oil crisis, which was engineered by the oil companies in 1973, their profits were climbing at 400 per cent a year. Do not talk to me about profits in the oil companies. What about exploration? Implicit in all the material given to me by Keith Orchison is that exploration will solve our problems. This is a very short term way of looking at things. Is the world made of oil? Is there an infinite supply of oil? If we just keep exploring forever, will it solve our problems? Of course not. We are living on the never-never. When are we to start paying our dues? When are we to start being responsible and to say, `Yes, Australia is running out of oil, and let us start implementing the alternatives before we actually run out of oil'? A stitch in time saves nine.
—You are on the nuclear argument now.

—There are other arguments. I am talking about oil at the moment. I think that we should stick to this greasy subject. We have implicit in all this the idea that exploration and increased oil production are good. But when will the oil companies allow us to start harnessing our renewables? The technology is there. During my tenure as a university professor at the University of Santa Barbara one of the west coast managers of Exxon Oil spoke to my environmental pollution class. One student said, `Why aren't you oil companies interested in solar power?' He said, `Well, if we could get a blanket and throw it over the sun and then have a hole in the blanket and sell the hole, sure, we would be interested in solar power'. He was being very honest. The attitude of the oil companies is that, unless they can control all facets of this product, if they cannot bring it out of the ground, refine it and sell it, they do not want to know about it. They are moving into the renewables industries, but only very cautiously and only as a hedge against the day that they may take off.

SPEECH.PARA: We have to start now getting away from the attitude that merely to drill for more oil will solve our problems. We have to stop listening to the oil companies. We must stop kowtowing to them-and the Government kowtows to them. The Opposition does so as a knee-jerk reaction, and the Government does, too. It is time that we took a good, hard look at what will benefit Australia, not the oil companies, many of which are owned overseas anyway. Australia can benefit only when it is not merely self-sufficient in oil, but truly self-sufficient in all forms of energy so that we can continue to operate into the future.

This Bill is a step in the direction of putting the oil industry on notice that it will not get exactly what it wants. It will get an adequate profit out of this, it will get a good enough deal, but it will not get exactly what it wants. As for Senator Lewis saying that we have not made up our minds, we have had our minds made up for months, and indeed for years, even since we passed this legislation in the first place. I wonder why he can make such a statement. Certainly he never talked to me about whether we had made up our minds. I do not know who he is talking to. Perhaps his bug into our party room is not working correctly-we do not know-but we have always been in favour of cash price bidding since we passed the Bill in the first place, and we are in favour of it now. The legislation before us is a logical consequence of the legislation which has gone before. It is time to renew the cash price bidding program, which has proved itself to be worthwhile. The Australian Democrats support the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support Senator Lewis in opposing the petroleum (Submerged Lands) Legislation Amendment Bill 1987. When considering how to respond to the remarks made by Senator Sanders, I decided that there was not much to respond to, except to draw the attention of the Minister for the Environment and the Arts (Senator Richardson) to the fact that Senator Sanders may be a serious competitor to Senator Richardson as a born-again greenie. If I were Senator Richardson, I would be on my guard.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition opposes this Bill, as do most other organisations in Australia, such as the Australian Petroleum Exploration Association, which represents more than 100 companies-not only the large companies, but the small and medium companies as well-the Australian Institute of Petroleum Ltd, most State governments and the Northern Territory. Cash bonus bidding is really nothing more or less than a tax on exploration. The Government's excuse for introducing this legislation is that the present program bidding or work bidding system is difficult to administer; yet the majority of exploration areas will continue to be subject to the present arrangement in every State of Australia. That is the way that areas are let for exploration in almost every mineral, including oil, coal and so on. How can the Minister argue for the introduction of a new system because the old system does not work when the supposedly old system will continue operating in most cases? Cash bidding is simply nothing more or less than a revenue raising exercise for the Government. It is a tax on exploration. The purpose of the legislation is made very clear in the Australian Labor Party Platform, Constitution and Rules, which I quoted the last time this matter was debated. On page 168, under the sub-heading `Taxation' it states:
Labor will-
this is worth listening to-
replace existing taxes on petroleum production with a resources rent tax-
which, as we all know, is phase 2 of this proposal-
in conjunction with front-end payments by tender for the right to explore highly prospective areas.

I know that Senator Lewis has drawn attention to what he calls highly prospective areas or what have been termed `highly prospective areas'. Australia is not in a highly prospective oil province. It never has been and probably never will be. I can recall very clearly some 20 years ago when the problem that really exercised the Menzies Government of the day was what on earth we could do because it was apparent that we would be importing more and more oil, which, of course, would have an adverse effect on the prospective balance of payments. Probably more importantly, we would be relying on somebody else for the supply of liquid fuels in this country. I can recall speaking to a real oil geologist-not the failed geologist who has just spoken-who came from Switzerland. At the time his view was that Australia did not have the geological structures that would rate it as a prospective area with the possible exception, perhaps, of the Bonaparte Gulf. As everybody knows, the then Government encouraged as many people as were prepared actually to explore for oil in Australia because of what it perceived to be, quite correctly, a problem down the track. As most people realise, on the advice of an American geologist, Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd (BHP) decided to put down a wild-cat well in Bass Strait. BHP was not confident of the advice given so it decided to share the cost of that well-because it was expensive-with the Exxon company or Esso Australia Ltd.

TALK.START.PARA: —A bad decision.

—Senator Richardson says that that was a bad decision, but it is a very risky area. I am sure that, coming from New South Wales, Senator Richardson, with his great experience of numbers, would also have spread the risk. BHP decided to share the risk-a risk from Australia's point of view, although not by world standards-and as a result the Bass Strait oil fields were discovered. Generally, Australia has not been a great oil province and in the main the discoveries that have been made have been made off-shore.

SPEECH.PARA: I will talk briefly about the work program bidding system. This is the system that is used by all State governments. Like any system, it does have its imperfections. However, it has operated satisfactorily for many years and is supported by the oil exploration industry. Of course, the reason why the industry supports it is that it knows where it is going. It knows that when it puts in a program it must be a program that is acceptable. The industry knows that the program must be one that will be attractive to the incumbent government, whatever government that may be, so that it will say, `Yes, let us adopt this particular proposal rather than the others'.

It is opportune to give some brief details of how this process continues to work in the States and, until a year or two ago, worked with the Federal Government of the day. Proposals are generally made by a number of consortia, either together or on their own, and they highlight a number of matters that I believe are very important. I say this because the cash bidding system is simply a matter of cash bidding and to hell with the sort of program to be developed and the sort of exploration program to be done. The Government is not interested in that. All it wants is the up front money. I think that was reflected in the proposal within the Labor Party's Platform, Constitution and Rules to which I referred earlier. Under the existing system a consortium or a group of companies first of all has to show a technical ability with a proven track record. It is usual for the curriculum vitae of key people to be provided in detail. Secondly, the consortium has to show not only its financial capability to carry out the exploration but also the ability to go into production, should the exploration be successful. Thirdly, consortia generally must show a proposed level of Australian control and equity at each level which has some influence on decision making. Fourthly, a detailed work program is required which shows an understanding of the genealogy of the area, gleaned from nearby work or work carried out previously; a program of exploration including required seismic surveys, the type of drilling and the pattern of the proposed work and a preliminary development program should viable reserves be discovered. A decision is then made on the proposal considered most likely to provide the best exploration program and hence development.

The work program bidding system is more regulatory but superior to the cash bidding system in that it requires a firm commitment from companies to undertake development. That is really the basis of the difference between the two programs. By contrast, the cash bidding system does not require successful bidders to give any undertaking whatsoever of what work will be done or when it will be done. This is not the way to encourage the pace of exploration in the face of declining reserves in Australia today.

The Government says that it has reviewed the effectiveness of cash bidding and rejects the concerns expressed about it. The review has assessed these concerns in the light of experience from the one and only cash bidding release to date. The cash bidding trial has been a one-off exercise and could not pretend to be a comprehensive or conclusive study of the effects of cash bidding on oil exploration. It has been claimed by small Australian producers-and I certainly agree with them-that cash bidding will disadvantage the smaller Australian companies. Small Australian companies involved in exploration will be squeezed out of cash bidding by the large foreign concerns because they will not be able to finance their offers or their payments at a cost equivalent to that of larger companies. It should also be borne in mind that often the larger organisations do not really have a time frame-they do not have the incentive to worry about finding, exploring and developing a resource. They can wait.

The Minister's inadequate response to this problem is that the Government has always acknowledged that it would be difficult for smaller companies to participate in off-shore exploration because of the costs and risks involved. He also stated that the Government expected no change to the existing practice in the industry of forming consortia to bid for permits.

It is a matter of great concern that cash bidding will deter exploration, and exploration is something we vitally need in Australia today. It is absolutely essential. Cash bidding is a tax before discovery and must reduce the funds available for genuine exploration. The following point is not often grasped. If front-end money must be paid by a genuine exploration company there is only so much money in that bucket. This will therefore reduce the amount of money that is able to be spent on genuine exploration. A portion of money which would have been spent on drilling holes and buying seismic equipment or employing people to operate that equipment will go into the bottomless pit of government revenue. It is estimated that the $30m paid recently in the cash bid for the Ashmore and Cartier permit could have been directed to another five or six wildcat wells.

In the Minister's second reading speech he admitted that the impact of cash bidding on exploration activity in other areas held by companies involved in bidding could not be assessed. Australia's future as a self-sufficient oil producer is becoming increasingly uncertain. It has been mentioned by Senator Lewis and, in his roundabout way, by Senator Sanders that Australia has been consuming more oil than it has been discovering over the past 10 years. The problem is being compounded by an alarming fall in off-shore exploration investment. As I mentioned earlier, the most prospective areas in Australia are off-shore. That is relative because, compared with many other parts of the world, Australia, including its off-shore areas, is not prospective. In 1983, $520m was expended in off-shore exploration. By 1987 that figure has dropped to $130m. Similarly, in 1983, $47m was invested in wildcat wells. In 1987 that figure has fallen to just $11m.

If we are to remain self-sufficient the Government should be doing everything in its power to encourage off-shore oil exploration where a large part off Australia's remaining undiscovered oil reserves are believed to exist. I mentioned earlier that the most highly prospective areas, in a not very prospective country, are off-shore. Instead, the Government wants to impose a punitive front-end tax on off-shore exploration, while admitting that it does not know what the full impact of that will be.

Australia is currently 80 per cent self-sufficient for its oil supply, but without future oil discoveries net input costs will cost this country, in 1987 dollars, an estimated $3.2 billion a year by as early as 1990 or 1991 and $5 billion by around 1995. Revenue from cash bidding will pale into insignificance compared with the very large dent in our balance of payments that oil imports could make if this situation were allowed to continued. It is not just the dent in our balance of payments; it is also the reliance on something that is absolutely essential to the ongoing industry of this country. We may have to rely on another country and not be sure of obtaining supplies. It was that uncertainty during the first and second oil crises that moved many of the countries dependent on energy imports into coal developments from Australia-to the benefit of Australia, I agree. Australia is in a very fortunate position. We must not let it go. We must not go back, particularly now, to the situation we were in in the early 1960s when we were concerned about where we were going to get our oil. One does not have to be a genius to realise that it does not take much of a disturbance in the oil producing countries for the oil supply to be cut off.

There is nothing in the legislation to suggest that cash bidding will be limited to the so-called highly prospective areas. The Government could extend the system to all areas of oil exploration. I presume that that is the intention of the Bill, irrespective of where they may be as long as they fall within the constitutional powers of the Commonwealth. A recent article in the Bulletin headed `Painful Energy Decisions Ahead for the Government' kicked off by saying, `Australia is running out of oil'. The article goes on to cite the figures I gave earlier relating to net input costs to this country. One would be a fool to imagine that those figures will not change. It would not take much for those figures to double. That is the sort of thing that we have to consider.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or halved; it could be cut in value.

—They could be cut in value, but not long ago the forecasts were that we were going to be short of oil and that the price was going to go up substantially. A lot of investments were made on that basis and people had their fingers burned. I am convinced that it is only a matter of time before that will occur. There will be shortages and reductions in the supply from volatile areas overseas. When that occurs, the price will increase substantially. We must be in a position to maintain our production. Oil exploration is to a country or an oil company what research and development is to industry. If one cuts back on research and development in industry one is doomed to failure. If one cuts back on oil exploration in oil provinces there is no doubt that one will suffer the consequences.

SPEECH.PARA: I reaffirm that the Opposition opposes this Bill for the reasons given. We believe that every incentive should be given to more oil exploration in Australia. Disincentives should not be given, encouraging explorers to go off-shore and seek oil somewhere else where the conditions are better.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we are debating the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Legislation Amendment Bill 1987 which proposes amendments to a number of Acts, including the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) (Cash Bidding) Amendment Act 1985. According to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) the purpose of the Bill is `to improve the administration of petroleum exploration development activities in Australian off-shore waters and correct some of the anomalies in the legislation'. The main purpose of the Bill is to entrench cash bidding for the award of exploration permits and to increase the power of the joint authority over off-shore exploration. The industry has suffered a dramatic decline since this Government took office, a government-I remind the Senate-that promised lower fuel prices to the consumer and greater flexibility and exploration. Nothing could be further from the truth in terms of what has been delivered since March 1983.

SPEECH.PARA: The Hawke Government has the dubious distinction of being responsible for changing the whole climate in the industry from one that provided significant advantages during the term of the coalition Government to the more adverse situation we are seeing today. These changes are due largely, if not solely, to a range of taxation measures brought in by this tax junkie Government, such as increases in company tax, the capital gains tax on farm-out deals, the fringe benefits tax on remote area costs, the proposed resource rent tax and, of course, let us not forget, cash bidding. To add insult to injury, if that was not all bad enough, and to highlight the insensitivity of this Government's approach, it has imposed these additional burdens at a time when international oil prices remains very weak indeed.

This Government's average tax take levels are a disincentive when it is considered that oil reserves are far more difficult to find in Australia. Relatively greater expenditures are needed to locate the oil in the first place and therefore producers can generally expect a lower return from oil investments in Australia. It therefore follows that Australia's tax regime should be lower than that in other countries in order to attract foreign capital as well as Australian investment. But, of course, that is not so under this Government. As we have heard tonight, cash bidding legislation with a two-year sunset clause was passed in November 1985 when the Australian Democrats did another one of their well-known backflips in order to do a deal with the Australian Labor Party so as to force Federal intervention against logging in Tasmania. When Senator Sanders made a great outburst of rage during Senator Lewis's address this evening, I thought there was some hope of light at the end of the tunnel and that the Democrats may have seen the folly of their ways. But then I listened very carefully to Senator Sanders's address-what for, I am not too sure-and of course the Democrats have not changed their attitude. They are still barking up the wrong tree, they are still doing deals and they can still not see that they made the wrong decision in 1985 purely and simply, as I have said, based on the logging deal in Tasmania.

Here we are, two years down the track, and the Democrats are still blinded by doing deals with this Government. Of course, Senator Sanders's whole address was so flippant on such an important issue that it is almost a disgrace to the Parliament. I would expect someone who purports to speak in an advisory capacity in such a portfolio to have more sensitivity to the plight of Australians generally and to the plight of this industry. But, of course, we have long since learned what to expect from the Democrats.

Cash bidding replaced work program bidding whereby exploration leases were given on the amount of exploratory work promised. Cash outlays were not deductible against other taxes, including the proposed resources rent tax, which I add has already been rejected once but is going to be retrotted through this Parliament. Anything for more tax is the motto of this Government. It will do absolutely anything to get more tax out of anybody who moves.

The amazing and illogical thing about this Government is that the revenue raised by cash bidding is more than likely to be less than what would be derived from taxes on production. Therein lies the lunacy. This Government brings in cash bidding but does not look at the taxes that could be derived from a higher rate of production. The coalition and the industry have consistently opposed the concept of cash bidding, as did the Western Australian Labor Government back in 1985. Members of that Government are Senator Richardson's mates and they are the ones who opposed it in 1985. Of course, curiously, the Burke Government has been very silent on this same issue this time around, and one could well ask why. We will be left to wonder why.

This Bill seeks to abolish the special arrangements previously established whereby the Federal Minister could not exercise any power on a matter unless satisfied that the Western Australian Minister's decision would endanger or prejudice the national interest. The decision then became one for negotiation between the Prime Minister and the Premier, not the Joint Authority. But the crux of the Joint Authority decisions is that the final decision rests with the Federal Minister, and the States will lose all power. I will never support a Bill that comes into this place that means that the States will lose all power in such a vital area as exploration. Yet Premier Burke must be quite relaxed about this whole thing, as evidenced by his deafening silence on the matter. As I have said, we may well ask why. He was so vocal in 1985 that cash bidding would be a disaster and yet in 1987 the silence from him is absolutely deafening. The Bill takes away the special rights that Western Australia obtained in the early 1980s, and Premier Burke and Western Australian Labor senators just simply do not care, do not have a clue or do not want to know.

Cash bidding has had adverse effects on off-shore exploration in the United Kingdom, Canada and the United States of America, where in 30 years only 20 per cent of off-shore exploration areas have been leased. Yet Senator Sanders-admittedly he is rather ashamed of being a former American-had the audacity to tell the Senate this evening that cash bidding in the United States had been a very successful program. What absolute and utter rot! The evidence speaks for itself in that, as I have said, in 30 years only 20 per cent of off-shore exploration areas have been leased. It is a disgrace that Senator Sanders stands in here and sings the sermon that it has been successful in the United States. It has been a disaster in the United States, the United Kingdom and Canada. This Government, as with so many of its other decisions to adopt tax measures that have been implemented in other countries, now wants to lead this country down the same dark path, and quite intentionally so, in the same way as it did with the capital gains tax and all those other things. Because other countries have such taxes, this Government believes we must have them no matter how disastrous they may have been in those other countries.

Let me just examine the state of the industry and trace its continuing decline since this Government came to office. In 1983, 49 exploration wells were drilled. In 1986 the figure was 29 and in 1987 there have been 16 so far. In 1983, 47 wild-cat wells were drilled. In 1986 the figure was 20 and in 1987 there have been 11 so far. I am being very generous in adding the `so far' to all of these, but let us give the Government the benefit of the doubt. But we are still looking at 49 exploration leases versus 16, and 47 wild-cat wells versus 11. As my colleagues Senator Lewis and Senator Parer have already said, expenditure has reduced dramatically from a level of $520m in 1983 to $130m so far this year.

Employment in oil exploration fell by 33 per cent in 1986. Australia has been consuming more oil than it has been discovering for the past 10 years-in fact double the rate. The Federal Government's own estimates of discoveries reveal that Australia will need to import 320,000 barrels of crude oil by 1992-93. Just imagine the cost of that to all Australians. I do not just mean the cost that a lot of people associate with increased costs in oil, that is, what they pay when they pull up at the bowser. The decline in Australian production and its self-sufficiency will have important ramifications for Australia's balance of payments, government revenue and security of supply. The only realistic solution to the problem is to find more crude oil and to have realistic petroleum policies, of which this is not one.

It is the fundamental responsibility of the Federal Government to provide greater incentives and give greater encouragement to off-shore exploration than it is currently displaying. As I have said, the Treasurer (Mr Keating), the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) are all tax junkies. They are not happy unless they are introducing another tax. They do not have a fix until they have put down another tax. They are tax mad. They have to have another tax. They are absolutely killing this industry. They have no idea of how all these tax measures that they are putting down impinge on the Australian community as a whole. It is just tax at any price.

Let us not be mistaken about the fact that the world oil price has fallen. The domestic price of Bass Strait crude oil has fallen. Australia's production outlook has deteriorated. Australia's outlook for self-sufficiency has worsened. Off-shore exploration expenditure has fallen and is expected to fall even further. Australia has become less attractive to explorers, the overall economic situation has deteriorated, high interest rates have been sustained, business taxation has increased, yet this Government wants to bash the last breath of air out of the industry's lungs. With all that has preceded it, this Government wants to go further. It wants to entrench cash bidding. We had the tokenism of the Australian Democrats two years ago in putting in a sunset clause. The Government had no intention whatsoever of saying, `Let us pull out the sunset clause'. It was just a measure to try to appease both sides at the time. As I have said, this Government is quite happy to bash the living daylights out of what is left of the industry.

The Government needs to have a real rethink on this whole issue and, in particular, the issue of cash bidding. My only hope was that the Democrats would have made a responsible decision. I suppose that it is a bit of a joke in itself even to contemplate such a thing. I would have hoped that they would have made a decision with only the consideration of Australia's future in mind and not the consideration of what they could get out of the Government for voting with it as they saw fit to do in 1985.

I think this Bill is a great tragedy for Australia and for the industry. These decisions are long term decisions. This Bill needs to be defeated if ever the plight of the industry and Australia is to be turned around. I support the opposition to this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope that Senator Knowles will remain in the chamber having said, `We know what to expect from the Australian Democrats', and I hope that she will listen to what I have to say. She has used a number of non sequiturs and has not based any logical argument on the observations which, to some extent, she has correctly made. It is true that the rate of discovery of new oil in Australia exceeds the rate at which that oil is being exploited. But Senator Knowles apparently has failed to notice, as have several other honourable senators, that on a world-wide scale the rate of oil exploitation exceeds the rate of new discoveries and has done now for quite a number of years. Furthermore, both Senator Knowles and Senator Parer have noted that the price at the moment is weak. Yet, given the nature of this limited non-renewable resource, they now wish to exploit that resource at an even faster rate.

SPEECH.PARA: The points on which Opposition senators have based their case are predicated on a view of resources which fails to take into account the non-renewable nature of liquid petroleum, which is one of the class of fossil fuels, all of which are in limited supply and will run out-in the case of liquid petroleum certainly within the next century. To support one of the points that Senator Parer made, the indications are that petroleum prices will be rising by about 1992-93 as North Sea oil goes into decline. There will be a shift back to a situation in which the Middle East countries will then be in the strong position that they were in in 1972 and 1973.

The present low price of oil on world markets, and markets everywhere, reflects only the immediate supply and demand. It takes no account of future shortages. One of the things that many of us in the conservation movement, including a number of Democrats, have been concerned about for a long time, is that we should be putting in place ways of conserving these resources, not ways of increasing their consumption. The view that we need to increase our rate of exploration and exploitation takes no account of the needs of future generations for these resources. I point out that the uses to which petroleum may be put, and to which it is put in our generation, go well beyond the needs for transport where most of the petroleum is used by our generation. I point to the uses in the manufacture of unusual chemical building blocks which go into the plastics, drugs, dyes and a whole range of other things. It may well be that the profligate use of this resource by our generation will be condemned by later generations because we will have denied them the opportunity of using that very valuable resource for these other purposes.

The Opposition's view is also predicated on the view that there are no alternatives other than simply using oil at a faster and faster rate. Apparently, members of the Opposition have not heard of conservation, nor have they heard of the very severe consequences of increasing the rate of consumption of petroleum and fossil fuels. Briefly, I would just like to mention that there is now universal credence among the world scientific community given to concerns over the increase in carbon dioxide in the atmosphere as a consequence of burning fossil fuels which is leading to a greenhouse effect. To put a few figures to that, before the beginning of the industrial era, the concentration of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere was about 270 parts per million. Currently, it is about 340 parts per million and it is rising at the rate of about half a percentage point per year; that is, half a percentage point compound.

In addition, because we have built a profligate exploitative technological system on the use of fossil and other fuels, we are also increasing a number of other gases in the atmosphere. The nitrous oxide concentration in the atmosphere is increasing at about 0.6 per cent per year, methane is increasing at about 1.1 per cent per year and freons, the gases which are used to expand foams in refrigerators and air-conditioners, are increasing in the global atmosphere at between 5 per cent and 7 per cent per annum. As a consequence it is expected that there will be an increase in the global temperature of between 1 1/2 and 4 1/2 degrees over the next 40 to 50 years and a rise of approximately one metre in the sea level, with quite disastrous consequences on a global scale.

As I have said, these effects are now accepted by the World Meteorological Office, the International Council of Scientific Unions, the National Academy of Science in the United States of America and the Australian Academy of Science. These are the sorts of effects which will face our children. They are not dim, distant effects; they are effects which are just around the corner. In fact, many people who are now alive will see those effects. Against that background, we need to look very seriously not at further exploration and exploitation of fossil fuels but at increased efficiency. I would like to pick up a point which was made by way of interjection. Nuclear energy was mentioned as one alternative. The sixth report on environmental pollution, the so-called Flowers report in Great Britain, looked at this situation quite closely and showed that the move to nuclear energy would actually increase the demand for fossil fuels and not decrease it and that, as I have said, the greenhouse effect is due to a number of other gases, which is predicated on the increasing use of resources generally and an exploitative attitude which needs to be turned around. I would also point out-this should be fairly obvious to anybody-that oil is principally used as a source of mobile energy, whereas nuclear energy can be used, and is used at the moment, only as a fixed source of energy for the generation of electricity. So nuclear energy is not a substitute for oil.

We therefore need to move to a situation in which oil and indeed all other fossil fuels are used much more efficiently. I believe it is possible to save $2 billion to $3 billion a year-forecast by several speakers this evening-in oil imports by the years 1991-92 and into the future. To go down that path will provide long term benefits, which simply attempting to increase the rate of exploration and exploitation will not do. Indeed, we have left it rather too late properly to put in place these alternative technologies. We should have been doing this much earlier. Simply to put off these developments for a further five or six years, because currently the price of oil is low, is to leave to our very near future a problem which will become extremely difficult to solve. To put into place some of these energy efficient alternatives requires relatively long lead times.

As an aside, I would mention that I think the Government has made a mistake in relation to its car plan in that insufficient emphasis is placed on the efficiency of motor vehicles, when in fact they use about 40 per cent of all the liquid petroleum used in this country. I believe we could have developed vehicles which would use only half as much petroleum and provide the same service in terms of distance travelled.

Petroleum and, indeed, all other non-renew- able resources in Australia are owned by all the people; they are not owned by the oil companies. It is right and proper that the oil companies should pay for the right to exploit any of those resources. As a consequence of that and of the observation that we need to conserve these resources, both for the reasons that they are limited, non-renewable resources and that their exploitation is posing, and will pose, an increasing and severe environmental problem for which there is no solution, I believe we should very strongly support this Bill.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take the opportunity to speak for a few minutes on a matter concerning French Polynesia. Today at Question Time I asked a question of Senator Evans, the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden), about the situation that had developed in French Polynesia or, as I like to call it, French occupied Polynesia. I must admit I have a prejudiced view in some senses about the French administration in that country. In 1983 I visited that country as a guest of the Polynesian Socialist Party, Ia Mana Te Nunaa, and while I was there I publicly expressed my support for the cessation of the French nuclear testing program and for independence for French Polynesia. When I did so it was indicated to my host by the French secret police that it would be a very good idea if I left the country forthwith. As I was leaving the next day, I did not take heed that I should leave immediately. It was interesting to note when I was leaving that there was a considerable display of gendarmes present with guns, et cetera at the airport just to make it clear that they did not think I was a desirable visitor to the country. Since then I have always had a passing interest in the situation in Polynesia.

SPEECH.PARA: As a member of the Australian Labor Party's foreign affairs committee, I have debated and moved motions at our national conference supporting independence for French Polynesia or, as I like to call it, French occupied Polynesia, a phrase that sends the French Government into apoplexy when it hears it mentioned. The French try to tell us that Polynesia is a part of France. To me that is like saying Bulgaria is part of Australia or Iceland is a part of the Argentine. That is the myth, the rationale, that the French use to stay in French occupied Polynesia. It is there as a subterfuge only because the French Government wishes to continue the French nuclear testing program.

It is one of the great tragedies for Polynesia that in 1963, as a result of the French withdrawing from Algeria, President De Gaulle had to find another place where he could test nuclear weapons to develop the so-called force de frappe. In my view he chose Polynesia because it was the place furthest from metropolitan France. If one says to the French, `If French testing is so safe why don't you do it in Sardinia, the central Massif or the Pyrenees?' they say that the geological shape of the rocks and the mountains in those areas means that it is not safe. I think it is probably safer to test where there are underground rocks than on a coral atoll in the South Pacific.

Since 1963 the French have established in Polynesia a major military establishment. It has drastically affected the cultural life and the social fabric of that country and, tragically, in a very adverse way. We all have a notion that Polynesia is paradise, and this goes back to when the first European explorers found this beautiful country and a very friendly people. That is the image tourists still have of Polynesia.

It is a terrible shock to go to Papeete, the capital of Polynesia, and find that just a few blocks away from the city centre are some of the worst slums imaginable. I find it incredible that the French would build three or four-storey concrete blocks of flats, which were obviously designed by the French housing commission for Paris or northern France for a cold climate, in Polynesia without air-conditioning, without appropriate ventilation and without any consideration for the surrounds or the Polynesian style of living. There is a terrible situation in Papeete of very disparate examples of wealth. The French civil service is made up of people who have gone there to develop and become part of the French nuclear testing program. The French civil service and a small number of Polynesian people who have been able to become part of the French middle class are living a very comfortable lifestyle. However, at the bottom end of the scale the overwhelming majority of the Polynesian people live, in my view, in one of the worst colonial situations one would see anywhere in the Third World. It is a disgrace to the French administration that that situation exists. It will tell people that it spends hundreds of millions of Australian dollars on development in Polynesia but it does not tell people that most of that money goes towards providing a lifestyle for the French civil service involved in the French nuclear testing program or the administration.

Australia and certainly the Australian Labor Government are to be commended for the effort they have been making in supporting independence for New Caledonia. That has my full support and, I believe, the overwhelming support of the Australian people. However, because of our strong support for independence for New Caledonia, the issue of independence for French occupied Polynesia has not been given the coverage or publicity it should have in Australia. We will not end French nuclear testing in the South Pacific until we get independence from the Polynesian people. Those two issues-independence and the cessation of French nuclear testing-are intricately woven together.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you have the same view about the indigenous population in Fiji?

—I certainly have the view that where there is a democratic constitution it should continue. There is no democratic constitution in Polynesia. It is considered by the French to be a part of France and therefore the Polynesian people do not have independence. The French will certainly say that in the 1950s there was a referendum on some sort of self-government and the Polynesian people did not vote for it. The way the referendum was put it was almost impossible to vote otherwise. That leads me to the historical perspective of French colonial rule in Polynesia and the dreadful situation that occurred with one of the great patriots of Polynesia, a man called Pouvanaa, who volunteered to fight for the French in the First World War against the Germans in the trenches of France. He was a major figure in the Polynesian community. When he returned to Polynesia after the First World War he was an advocate for independence and self-rule for Polynesia.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1940 Polynesia was the first territory of France that declared in favour of Free France and General De Gaulle. Pouvanaa was one of the major people who argued that De Gaulle and Free France should be supported, not the Vichy regime that the administrators in New Caledonia were trying to support. This meant that Australia had to intervene to stop New Caledonia from becoming a part of the neo-facist rule in the world at that time. Pouvanaa supported De Gaulle in 1958. He was clearly the leader of the French Polynesian people. When De Gaulle had to shift the nuclear testing program to Polynesia, Pouvanaa opposed it and called for independence. On a trumped up charge brought by the French administration, Pouvanaa ended up getting 10 years gaol for opposing the French rule of General De Gaulle. He spent eight years in a gaol in Marseilles, which nearly killed him. He did not return to Polynesia until the late 1960s or early 1970s. His health was wrecked and he was never again able to fulfil the role of the leading proponent of independence for the Polynesian people. He died in the mid-1970s. Pouvanaa's treatment was a disgraceful episode and, in my view, it is the equivalent to the Dreyfus case of trumped up charges to get rid of a political opponent to De Gaulle's program of French nuclear testing. De Gaulle knew that independence could not be given to French occupied Polynesia while he needed to test nuclear weapons. In my view the history of France in this region has been all but disgraceful.

Since the 1970s a number of Polynesian people have got together to start a campaign for independence and to oppose the French nuclear testing program. I must say that it has been one of the honours in my political career to have met Jacqui Drollet, the Leader of the Ia Mana Te Nunaa Party, which is both in favour of independence and opposed to French nuclear testing. It has yet to become a major Party, but that Party is represented in the Tahitian Territorial Assembly. I had the opportunity today to speak to Jacqui Drollet in Papeete about the episode that took place last Friday concerning the waterside workers' strike and the reaction of the French people and the French military forces. I understand from Jacqui Drollet that by this time he will have issued a public statement explaining the position of his Party and of the Polynesian people towards that episode.

I want to relate to the Senate what really happened. The waterside workers went on strike because, among other things, they wanted more workers employed to work on the wharfs, including work involving shipping material to Mururoa Atoll. They went on strike for several days. As explained to me by Jacqui Drollet-and I have no reason to doubt the veracity of his remarks or his integrity-last Friday, in typical Polynesian style, the people concluded the time that they had spent on the picket line with a prayer meeting, as they are all Protestant Christians, and at five o'clock while they were praying and leaving the picket line they were attacked by several hundred French Foreign Legionnaires, armed military gendarmes and other military people. They were attacked with batons and, as I understand, tear gas. Several people were injured and a number of them were arrested. Clearly, it was a provocative act by the French Administration in Polynesia against a peaceful industrial strike. I think the French should stand condemned for that.

Since five o'clock last Friday Polynesian time French officials have said nothing in any of the public statements that have been made that gives the lie to what I have just stated. Obviously, in a city the size of Papeete, when that episode occurred the word got around about the provocation of the French military forces. Many young Polynesians who for several years had become increasingly resentful about the way that the French had been administering Polynesia went on what has been described as a riot, a rampage. Jacqui Drollet admitted that between 50 and 60 shops were absolutely destroyed, and obviously they were looted, and cars were burned. Jacqui Drollet said that it was a culmination of a number of years of frustration that the French authorities have not addressed-and this relates not only to the political issues of independence or French nuclear testing in Polynesia but also to the economic and social issues pertaining to the standard of living of ordinary Polynesians in that country.

As I have said before, the French make great claim about the money that they pump into that country, saying that they spend enormous amounts of money, but it does not get to the ordinary Polynesian worker, the ordinary Polynesian family person. Unemployment amongst those people is high and they have bad housing, a bad education and no opportunities for the future. They are the frustrated ones, especially the young people who were part of the riot. I think that when those circumstances are understood it becomes apparent that the riot was a manifestation of the other ills prevalent in that country and that it was not something that took place as some sort of off-the-cuff criminal activity. I believe that we must ask the French to address these social and economic problems, and that is not to mention the political problems of independence for Polynesia.

In the past couple of days some extraordinary statements have been made by French spokespeople. The French Security Minister, Robert Panraud, said during a radio broadcast in Paris today that he saw `no direct proof that Australia or New Zealand was involved in the weekend's unrest in Tahiti'-it was a backhanded attack on Australia and New Zealand-`although those two countries do not apply a policy of defending the Western world in this part of the world'. That statement was made in Paris, which is 15,000 kilometres from Polynesia. It is part of the French paranoia to say that the real reason that Australia is against French nuclear testing, in favour of independence in New Caledonia and in favour of independence for Polynesia, is that we want to get the French influence out and to play a hegemonic role in the whole region, applying it to both ourselves and New Zealand. However, that betrays the fact that it is the French who are about hegemonic policies; it is their attitudes that are hegemonic and not ours.

In supporting the idea of independence for New Caledonia and Polynesia, I indicate that I would hope that both countries will keep part of their traditions coming from the past 150 years of French involvement. I see nothing wrong with having that French culture as part of the culture of those countries. The Polynesians in Tahiti make no bones about the fact that they will continue to use the French language and that they will continue with French culture and use French institutions, for example. I think that that is to be supported. However, as to the question of independence, the people of Polynesia will make that choice themselves and they will not rely on being dictated to by the French Government.

I think that the Australian people and the Australian Government have every right to be extremely critical of the role that France is playing in that part of the world. I hope that in coming years not just the Labor Party but all political parties in Australia and all interest groups in the Australian community will indicate their support for independence for French occupied Polynesia, because not only are we anti-colonialist but above all else it will mean the end of French nuclear testing in the region. As far as I am aware, all political parties in Australia, and certainly 99.9 per cent of Australian people, are opposed to French nuclear testing in that part of the world.

My final comment deals with the role in particular of a certain other gentleman in the French Administration, Gaston Flosse. Until February this year he was the Chief Minister of the De Gaullist Party in the Polynesian Territorial Assembly. On the election of the Chirac Government he was offered the job of Minister for Territories in the South Pacific. Not only has he been assiduous in promoting French interests in New Caledonia and in Polynesia but he has been touring all the other countries of the South Pacific. For example, I believe that he was the person responsible for making an offer to Colonel Rabuka in Fiji, along the lines of, `Are you interested in having some sort of joint military exercises? Are you interested in sharing military intelligence?'. He has also recently been in other South Pacific countries and made offers of aid from France, to increase the French influence and to reduce the hostility, as he would see it, of other South Pacific countries towards French nuclear testing and French colonialism in the South Pacific. In my view, the tour undertaken by Gaston Flosse around the South Pacific should be monitored closely by the Australian Government.

In conclusion, I want to place on record my full support for Jacqui Drollet and all the other people of French occupied Polynesia who support independence and the cessation of French nuclear testing. They are in a very difficult position. They are discriminated against politically, but they are very brave people and I hope that in the not too distant future, before I get too old, I and all other Australians will have the opportunity to welcome Polynesia into the United Nations as an independent country. I hope that that is a view all other members of the Parliament, in both Houses, would share. I thank the Senate for the opportunity to speak tonight.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Home Affairs, upon notice, on 14 September 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: In which States of Australia (including the Northern Territory) does `provisional' Federal electoral enrolment also result in `provisional' enrolment at the State level, with the enrolee being automatically placed on the State roll when the person attains the age of eighteen years.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: In Victoria and South Australia `provisional' enrolment at Federal level of 17 year olds will also result in `provisional' enrolment at State level, with the enrolee being automatically placed on the State roll when the person attains the age of eighteen years. QUESTION.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister Assisting the Minister for Community Services and Health, upon notice, on 15 September 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Minister for Community Services and Health see the article in the Sydney Morning Herald of 26 August 1987 which was titled: `Alcohol a life sentence for babies'.
(2) Given the alarming statistics in the article, will the Federal Government legislate to ban the advertising of alcohol on radio and television.
(3) Will it also encourage State governments to ban the advertising of alcohol in newspapers and magazines.

(4) Has the Minister's Department done a study of the economic feasibility of equating the level of excise tax levied on alcohol products with the actual alcohol content of the product; if so, what were the results of the study; if not, will the Minister's Department undertake such a study with a view to initiating a policy whereby the level of excise tax levied on alcohol products begins with no excise tax being levied on products with less than 0.1 per cent alcohol and increasing thereafter, at a level to maintain the existing amount of revenue raised by this tax.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) While it is not the Government's intention to ban alcohol advertising from television and radio there is a need for the alcohol and advertising industries to be more socially responsible in relation to alcohol advertising generally.

I am particularly concerned at alcohol advertising which is attractive to our youth, and this has already been the subject of discussions between a delegation of Ministers of the Ministerial Council on Drug Strategy and the Media Council of Australia. It will also be reviewed at the next meeting of the Ministerial Council on Drug Strategy on 6 November 1987.

Community education on alcohol consumption is an important part of the Government's strategy to prevent alcohol misuse. A very valuable recent educational aid is the National Health and Medical Research Council publication `Is there a safe level of daily consumption of alcohol for men and women?'. On the question of alcohol consumption and pregnancy it states (page 32)-`At our current level of knowledge, responsible drinking during pregnancy must be considered to be abstinence'. The publication deals with a range of alcohol related issues, and a copy is available from the Parliamentary library.

Later this year, under the National Campaign Against Drug Abuse (NCADA), a national campaign on alcohol is to be launched which will focus initially on adolescent alcohol abuse. This will complement a range of other initiatives under NACADA which aim at educating people in the responsible use of alcohol.

(3) Not at this time. In discussions with my colleagues in the States and Territories I will seek a continuation of their current activities in pressing industry to adopt a more socially responsible stand on alcohol advertising in all media.

(4) The matters raised lie within the responsibility of the Treasurer. He has advised that the excise levied on potable spirits is applied on the basis of alcohol content whilst the excise levied on beer (per volume of beer) is applied at a reduced rate for lower alcohol beer. He also advised that there are no plans to change the excise arrangements to levy excise on all alcoholic beverages on the basis of alcohol content.
